name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement: Cambridge Analytica's use of Facebook user data and data protection (2018/2855(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Facebook Cambridge Analytica case was, in many ways, a wake—up call for all of us. We were reminded once again that in the digital world our personal data can be misused, abused and used against us. We were reminded again that cybersecurity and disinformation are a serious threat for free and democratic elections and that the digital arms race is not a thing of the future. It is happening right here and right now.  It was a clear warning sign that the election periods are particularly prone to disinformation and manipulation by private and foreign interests and that the European elections are not immune to this threat. We must strengthen our joint response to dangers to our democracy. The Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal was not an isolated case as, since then, we have learned of new data breaches. Every such new case confirms the importance and the urgency of acting. Every such case confirms that the new EU data protection rules are not a privilege. They are a necessity, as you point out in the draft resolution. The Commission shares many of your concerns concerning data protection and misuse of the research argument, and calls for algorithmic accountability. We also support wholeheartedly the call for the prompt adoption of the European political parties regulation by the co—legislators. We also take note of some new ideas for future regulatory action and electoral safeguards. The Commission has already been working to ensure fair and resilient elections or to deal with disinformation, which covers some of Parliament’s ideas.  While we should not shy away from reinforcing our regulations where necessary, Europe is better equipped now than ever before with the powerful tools provided by the new data protection law, which were not in place at the time of the Cambridge Analytica breaches. It is important to enforce the existing rules at their full capacity.  I am in regular contact with the Chair of the European Data Protection Board and the Chair of the UK Data Protection Authority, who is leading the investigation into Facebook and Cambridge Analytica. We fully support the coordinated response of the EU data protection authorities.  I have also raised the US investigation into the matter with the Chair of the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), Mr Simons, who was in Brussels last week for the second annual review of the Privacy Shield. He reassured me that this investigation is a key priority for the FTC and that it is ongoing. We have to wait for the final outcome of the investigation, but we will watch this very closely and stay in contact with the FTC. But we also need to look beyond the case itself because it sent shock waves through the core of our democratic system. Our current election rules, practices and habits stem from our non—digital past. Campaign spending limits, strict rules on political advertising, including transparency on who is campaigning and who paid for it, the silence period, the role of the media in disinformation – all the offline rules – must be enforced online in the digital world. One thing is clear: the upcoming elections will not be business as usual and we cannot treat them as if they were. We cannot be naive and we have very little time to act. The Commission therefore encourages Member States to establish and support a national elections network. The idea is that such a network would be able to quickly detect potential threats and swiftly enforce existing rules, including available financial sanctions. We have also stepped up our game against cyber—threats and to address disinformation. My colleague, Commissioner King, will tell you more about this in the concluding remarks, but I just want to stress that the Commission is not looking idly at those new developments. We have brought in a package of measures to strengthen resilience against classical cybersecurity threats, like hacking in 2017. On disinformation, the Commission proposed a package of measures in the Communication on tackling online disinformation, based around transparency, traceability and accountability. We asked major IT platforms to commit to an EU-wide Code of Practice on Disinformation, which was presented last month. But we also have to recognise the fact that many companies, including Facebook, are trying to fix the mistakes they made and support us in the effort to make elections fairer and more transparent. It goes without saying that the pressure you in this Chamber put on them brings positive results. I am counting on cross-party support for this package because it is ideologically neutral. The truth is that this is not, as such, about politicians. This is about the right of European people to make their choice as freely as possible, free from illegal manipulation, free from disinformation and free from foreign interference. Parliament’s support for this package is crucial and your resolution is a great opportunity to send a clear message to the EU governments, but also to other relevant stakeholders. The European elections take place very soon. If we want to be prepared, we have to act now and we have to act fast. I am encouraged by last week’s European Council, which welcomed the Commission proposals, in the Communication called ‘Securing free and fair European elections’, on election cooperation networks, online transparency, protection against cybersecurity incidents, unlawful data manipulation, fighting disinformation campaigns and tightening the rules on European political party funding. It also called for a rapid examination and operational follow-up by the competent authorities. I therefore hope that together we can advance rapidly and shield ourselves better against manipulation, disinformation and abuse, also in light of the upcoming elections.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, there is no doubt today that interference through social networks (we are looking at Facebook here, but also others), manipulation from a political point of view and from a more general point of view are a danger, a risk, a threat. The Cambridge Analytica case has clearly shown that it is possible to interfere in an electoral process. We are not only concerned with the electoral issue; of course, as a political chamber, that concerns us, but the use of citizens' data in matters other than just political matters is also reprehensible, is a risk and is a danger. And so, on the basis of this case that we know, based on the strong suspicions that we have in the case of the United States, based, for example, on what is happening now in Brazil, where the suspicions of fake news and manipulation of algorithms to campaign are multiplied from part to part, it is essential that we take measures, measures for the European elections because these are urgent , but measures that are medium and long-term for all electoral processes. As I say, for us, it is not just the electoral issue that is at stake, it is a matter of general citizenship for all matters. This means that it will not only be interference or legislation in this case, but by understanding how we can look at the democratic society of the future, knowing that social networks have to play a role there and that we, as well as have been able to regulate the role of the media in the past society, will be able to regulate the role of the new world of social networks in a modern democratic society. The challenge before us is a constitutional challenge far more ambitious than just this to prevent interference at the moment.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Cambridge Analytica scandal is the biggest manipulation of the democratic process so far in the digital age. This is not an isolated incident, Cambridge Analytica is the latest in a long series. A wave of massive data breaches has been rolling across Europe – there's been Yahoo, eBay, Uber and Facebook, to name just a few. In the first half of 2018 alone, 2.2 billion people were affected by data breaches. A study from Oxford University, in cooperation with Lund University has shown that in Sweden, in the Swedish election, about 30% of online communication was fake news, and that a whole lot of all that fake news was imported from foreign countries. That means, today, we are talking about trust in the election. We are talking about our free ability to vote. We are talking about political preferences being manipulated. We are talking about the selection of political leadership. We are talking about freedom and democracy. According to the NATO Secretary-General, Jens Stoltenberg, 80% of disinformation comes from Russia. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This cannot continue! Our democracy is a democracy of citizens and not of those who manipulate data or buy data. If you have ten likes from someone, then you can describe them as well as a work colleague. With 70 likes you know more than the roommate, with 150 likes more than the family member and with 300 likes as much as the respective spouse. This means that we are in danger of losing personal sovereignty, we are in danger of losing more democratic sovereignty. The people's right to self-determination at the cradle of any democratic movement is in jeopardy. And we have to say that the next European elections will determine whether we win this battle for freedom and democracy, or whether we lose it. We have started with the General Data Protection Regulation. That was the right move. But we need to go further – in legislation, in the reform of our national electoral laws, and in the protection of privacy in the area of electronic data security. I would like to thank the Commissioner for having this discussion with us. It's five minutes to twelve. And I would like to thank – an unusual step – our excellent photographers for accompanying us this morning. If I may ask you to take a picture of the Council bench this morning, that would also be a very impressive picture. Where is the Austrian Presidency in such a discussion? If you are blocking ePrivacy behind the scenes, if you are making sure that we do not make any progress on legislation and that we are not even in this Chamber this morning? What is the Council's basic position when it comes to democracy and freedom? I cannot accept that, and that is not how we can work. I believe, Mr President, that we should make a statement to the Presidency on how serious the debate is now in Europe.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Bullmann. Yes, we will respond accordingly.

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, trust is vital in the digital era. With more of our lives taking place online and increasing consumer choice, people can, and do, get up and leave when that trust is damaged. What happened with Facebook and Cambridge Analytica was an unacceptable abuse on a vast scale. Everyone can agree that this must not happen again, and I have been supportive of the ongoing investigations. The UK Information Commissioner’s Office, which currently handles 30% of all European data protection board cases, is doing a thorough job of investigating. It has already issued a fine to Facebook. Cambridge Analytica is no more. It is clear that Facebook does not walk away from this scandal unscathed. Facebook knows it will need to rebuild its reputation in the eyes of its users, and as politicians it’s not our role to dictate exactly how they do that. Nor is it our role to tell users how they should react. Most Europeans have not given up their Facebook account. Clear legal limits and strict conditions on political profiling have been imposed by the new GDPR rules. Therefore, we should allow the GDPR time to bed in before we throw the baby out with the bathwater and start to chuck more legislation at the problem. And also let’s try not to fool ourselves that Facebook manipulation was responsible for Brexit or Trump. People would have voted for them regardless of Facebook. It was already prevalent in our society. The GDPR is not perfect, but at the speed at which technology moves and innovation moves, any new laws in this area need to keep up with the modern world. We should focus on addressing this, rather than trying to point-score by taking dangerous steps to suspend the privacy shield which is proposed in the resolution we will vote on later. This would deny our citizens the protections that it offers.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, although I might not agree with everything Mr Dalton says, I agree with one thing: that we shouldn’t forget in this whole debate that the biggest threat to democracy is still offline and not online, in populist movements, governments, even in the European Union, who are trying to undermine democracy and the rule of law, and we should speak out.  On the GDPR, differently to Mr Dalton, I think that we should go faster. First of all, GDPR is the best privacy law in the world, but if it’s not being implemented properly then it’s useless. We should be looking at the means that the data protection authorities have in order to tackle the challenges on the table. For example, the Dutch Data Protection Authority has about 150 staff. They cannot fight Facebook. They don’t have the same means.  Secondly, you say that the investigations are advancing. But are they advancing fast enough? You say Facebook is trying to fix its mistakes. I don’t know, I’m not terribly convinced myself, to be honest, because they may have fixed some mistakes because they had to, but they’re making new ones in the meantime – they’re not mistakes, they’re actually deliberately trying to circumvent the law. I hear that now Whatsapp is being used increasingly to spread all sorts of nonsense online.  That also brings me to new legislation. Contrary to Mr Dalton, I do believe that we need further legislation in the form of e-privacy, which is indeed being blocked by the Council, but the right-wing parties in this House have also voted against it. I really don’t understand how you can stand here and say ‘I’m terribly worried about what’s happening to our democracy’ and at the same time try to water down e-privacy. How can you do that? It’s hypocrisy.  (Applause) I think we also need to recognise that, in our very legitimate aim to strengthen security, we have very often very rapidly passed legislation that undermines the privacy and the legal protection of our citizens, and risks undermining the rule of law and democracy as well. We should have a proper evaluation before coming up with, yet again, new instruments for massive the collection and processing of personal data.  Finally, on a fake news and disinformation. I think we need a proper legal definition of fake news. What’s fake news? I mean I may think that one of my colleagues in this House is spreading fake news, and they probably think that I am. Where do you draw the line between a political view and fake news? We need a proper legal definition before we take any measures against fake news, because otherwise it becomes arbitrary and then we are undermining our democracy for real.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I hope that Mark Zuckerberg is actually listening to the debate today so that he will understand that we are not letting him off the hook and that we are not happy with just some minor tweaks to the privacy settings of Facebook. The Facebook-Cambridge Analytica scandal is not simply a privacy scandal. It’s a political scandal. It is a threat to our democracies. Facebook is illegally allowing some people to use the data for manipulating voters with psychological profiling, with fake news and with advertising profiling that makes it totally impossible to understand who is actually seeing what – the so-called ‘dark ads’. The consequences are dramatic. This can even lead to voter manipulation, and there is a lot of evidence that shows that this is exactly what happened. Facebook is a very powerful platform with huge influence on our private lives, but also on our political life. If we want to safeguard our democracy, we need clear and strict rules for such online platforms. Transparency is good, but it is just not enough. We cannot leave it to companies like Facebook to decide who gets to see what political content just before the elections. We need to make sure that all voters have access to the same information, and we need to ban micro-targeting of political advertising. Member States need to do this very soon if we want to make sure that the European elections in May are undistorted by dubious dark ads and by political manipulation.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think that we as a Parliament have done our job so far. We have raised the case of Cambridge Analytica, we have had hearings on which Facebook has, as expected, sent PR staff. Yes, and we have also endured the autocratic behaviour of the President of the European Parliament, Mr Tajani, whose so-called hearing has made us a kind of mockery of the world. But good – we have a resolution, we have positioning, and we also have a sensible statement from the Commissioner. Now we want to have consequences, because it is about Facebook's business practices, which allow it to use data on a large scale for so-called research purposes – but actually to exploit it for political purposes, to abuse it.  Cambridge Analytica was not only a violation of data protection law, but also, in a sense, a staff-abuse operation.  All you hear from Facebook is a verbal apology with an angelic look, in a way, with no guarantee that something like this can't happen again and that something will change in the business model. I want to make one thing very clear: when data is manipulated for political advertising purposes, elections are manipulated. When elections are rigged, it throws us back into a pre-democratic era and elections become a farce, and then, frankly, we can also vote here on socialist lists of unity. That is why action must be taken. There must be regulations for election advertising, as in the offline area. We need transparency, we need disclosure of funding; what we don't need is targeted advertising. This must be prohibited, at least during election periods, and otherwise subject to strict regulations.  Apart from the fact that I am now seriously disturbed by Facebook's market power, I would like to say one more thing: if we lose the race in the Cambridge Analytica case, then we can also bury the citizens' freedoms. To the Council: Incidentally, I believe that ePrivacy must be adopted as soon as possible.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Christmas is still weeks away, nevertheless, I can bring you joyous tidings from St Nicholas, as Sir Nicholas Clegg is also known. Facebook has just appointed St Nicholas Clegg as head of global affairs. Many of us, many colleagues, have despaired at Facebook’s predatory approach and worse, its blatant exploitation of the personal data of its users for commercial purposes. But, apparently, St Nicholas is going to put an end to all of this. St Nicholas is to be paid a pot of gold, worthy of ALDE Group leader, Guy Verhofstadt, on a slow day. Facebook has lost the confidence of millions of people, but St Nicholas Clegg understands this well because he went through exactly the same when he was leader of the Liberal Democrats. Also, St Nicholas Clegg is qualified. He speaks four languages fluently and can explain hypocrisy in all of them. Nonetheless, Sir Nicholas will do well. He has written an entire book called ‘How to Stop Brexit’. He will always be beloved as a lobbyist by the EU Commission and, for sure, the Commission is going to let Facebook off the hook.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I do not have a Facebook account. Yet Facebook follows me, and with me millions of others. The European privacy law does not protect Facebook in this and me. Facebook is a monopolist. Facebook also has a political opinion. In Germany, Facebook appeared to block criticism of social democracy, but not anti-Semitism. The European Commission told me on 4 August 2017 that it had no problems with this. The European Commission protects Facebook, but not the Jewish community. Mr President, for many people, Facebook is the Internet, for social contacts, but also for the news. That news is filtered through Facebook. Only neat – left-wing I assume – opinions come through. Facebook protects its premise, not the free press.  Mr President, the European Commission has reached an agreement with Facebook with a view to the upcoming elections. According to the Commission, stories of fake news and voter influence justify the need to approve or remove opinions from the Internet. However, the European Commission has nothing to learn from Moscow about influence. The Commission protects the European Union, not the democratic process. The European Commission has a problem with criticism of the euro, criticism of the European Union, criticism of migration, criticism of Islam. This criticism is called populism and must be combated, but let that criticism be my opinion.  I believe that the European Union as such is a threat to the peace and well-being of the Member States, and that is an opinion that has no place on Facebook. My criticism also had no place in the resolution on which we are going to vote, because all my amendments were voted down. That's no wonder, either. Like Facebook and the European Commission, this European Parliament also protects its own position, not that of its citizens.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, if the European Union is actually serious about users’ data and data protection, why not target Google and every other internet search engine whose algorithms ensure that anyone’s search on absolutely anything is tracked, evaluated and fed back to the big corporates to influence and manipulate consumer opinion, choice and decision?  The concern that has been voiced in the Chamber this morning is about data-mining for political purposes and, of course, it is a key European Union issue because it knows the threat that exists in terms of anti-European Union sentiment there across Europe for next year’s elections. But just let me remind you, both Twitter and Facebook have conducted the investigations. They have conducted those with the relevant political commissions, in relevant countries, and concluded, conducted, been approved, negligible impact.  Turning to Commissioner Jourová, I’m very pleased to see you this morning, Commissioner, and you stated ‘free from foreign interference’. Well, can I ask you, will you take steps to stop billionaire George Soros from funding an anti-Brexit campaign with multimillion pound donations?  (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Molly Scott Cato)

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: "In a world of digital revolution, trust is one of the most important values. Builds healthy relationships between users, content creators and broadcasters, and communication organizers. Facebook is not only a key company, but also a communication organizer. That's why facebook's credibility is so important and symbolic. It is necessary to clarify to the end all the causes and aspects of the Facebook-Cambridge Analytica relationship and the scandalous leak of personal data. After all, there are legal tools in the form of a data protection regulation already in place since 25 May this year, there is a European-American privacy shield to ensure that privacy requirements are met, and Cambridge Analytica has been certified accordingly. What is legally required must be respected without any reduced tariff.  However, some time has passed since that event. There are new challenges: political advertising and the ambiguity of its sources of funding – important during elections, automatism of algorithms threatening to disrupt the transparency of communication, the development of disinformation in every form, up to deepfake. The dark side of the internet is stronger than the benefits, so new strategies are needed. We are working on them in the European Union and I thank the Commissioner and the Commissioner for this initiative. What not to say about Facebook, he is also working on them – whether by developing flagged materials that are forbidden, hateful or uncertain about the veracity, whether by eliminating bots and anonymous accounts for online combat, or by teaching a new approach to privacy, where our real choice and consent will be the key to conscious online behavior. By stigmatizing bad practices like today, let us also show good examples. This and cooperation will be more useful for a healthy future for the internet.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at least one colleague has already said that entire elections, Brexit or any other individual election, are not wholly affected either by the Cambridge Analytica scandal or any other Facebook issue. This is an ultimate misunderstanding of what we are dealing with. What we are dealing with is individual groups of vulnerable voters being shifted around by the lack of integrity of what is happening on Facebook. If colleagues are not aware now of what is happening on these platforms, the scale of Facebook in 109 countries, then they’re not paying attention. We must take action now to restore trust, not just in online platforms, but in the integrity of our elections. That is now happening in the Commission and it is happening here in Parliament. This is absolutely critical, and we are defining the problem, but we must take action. In the hearings we said that there must now be an internal audit of Facebook. We urge Facebook now to work with the European Data Protection Board to carry out that full and independent audit, but we have to conform not just to GDPR but we said when the Council were absent here, to think about what the protections are within e-privacy. Not because e-privacy is some totemic, iconic thing that we are bandying around, but because we have a problem with the technology. We have, colleagues, a whole issue now of further actions to protect our elections. In the United States, recent requirements have been introduced to verify the identity, location and sponsor of political ads that are a good response, and the same standards should be applied here. We have a whole range of issues that we have to fix here in the European Union: applying conventional offline electoral safeguards, such as rules and transparency and limits to spending, respect for silence periods, making it easy to recognise online political paid advertisements and banning profiling for electoral purposes. Social media platforms should label content shared by bots and speed up the process of removing fake accounts, and compulsory post-campaign audits should be conducted to ensure personal data are deleted. The Commission should look with us and updating competition rules and increasing algorithmic transparency. We are here to deal with Facebook because Facebook is not a minor issue. This is a global issue dealing with elections all over the world and it has already affected our referenda and it has affected our elections. Colleagues, if anyone in this Chamber thinks that this is not a serious issue, they are not paying attention. This resolution sets out the path we need to protect our citizens’ privacy and restore trust and confidence in our democratic systems.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, about six months ago we were all surprised, angry or in disbelief at the huge data breach at Facebook. This was the start of several investigations, including in this House, which gave a clear signal: such invasions of our privacy are unacceptable. In September, however, a new data breach at the tech giant came to light. A software problem gave hackers access to millions of user accounts, including five million European accounts. This resolution was a great opportunity to condemn this injustice and call for further action. Unfortunately, the resolution goes in all directions. For example, it calls for the suspension of the EU-US Privacy Shield without providing an alternative. Or there are calls for the national electoral laws to be adapted, which is clearly within the competence of the Member States. The key word that this resolution needs in this fight is focus. Focus on the exact problem we're dealing with. This is the only way we, as legislators, can make a difference.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Facebook scandal has been a warning for all of us about what can happen when data is misused. Now, however, we have to focus on the lessons learned.  First, we need to be extremely cautious in protecting our data online. Internet literacy and staying safe on the internet must become a standard part of our education systems. Second, platforms need to better self—regulate. The days of community codes are over and now we need strict guidelines and rules. More importantly, platforms should act.  Lastly, fake news is a direct threat to our democracy with a potentially significant impact on the election results. Important decisions, such as whether to stay part of the EU or not, should not be decided based on targeted fake news. We should bear this in mind in the run—up to the forthcoming European elections. We want to keep the internet an open and free forum of discussion, but we need to know how to spot the fake.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I am able to take this time on behalf of Romeo Franz – I think there may have been a misunderstanding. Is that possible?

name: President. –
text: Ms Scott Cato, right now Mr Romeo Franz is listed to speak, and according to the rules you may only be granted the floor during catch-the-eye procedure. There is no direct replacement, just catch-the-eye. Interjection from Ms Scott Cato: ‘I am on the screen now though, Mr President, I would just point out respectfully.’ Let us agree: ok, catch-the-eye, and you have one minute. According to the rules, if I have a list of speakers – excuse me but I do believe that the person chairing the sitting is myself, not somebody behind, so a one-minute speech. It is a list. I asked Mr Romeo Franz to take the floor. We received information that Ms Scott Cato would like to replace Mr Franz, which is not possible. My proposal was that she be granted one minute in catch-the-eye, Ms Scott Cato accepted, so let us continue according to the list of speakers which has been prepared.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal is a political scandal and has demonstrated the dangers that exist when power is concentrated in the hands of a few speculators who have the means to file and manipulate millions of people. This is the massive breach of personal data, which has been revealed, is a threat to democracy and is only the tip of the iceberg. The personal data of tens of millions of Americans and 2.7 million Europeans has been used and, a few days ago, Facebook informed that hackers had gained access to nearly 50 million accounts.  Facebook's own representatives, during the hearings in the European Parliament, admitted that they had an agreement with an app developer who gave personal data to third parties. However, they did not respond to what measures they are now taking to fully comply with the new European Regulation on the protection of personal data. We have a responsibility, in view of the European elections, to ensure that European legislation on personal data is implemented by all social networking platforms, to be checked through new legislation and to simplify procedures so that users can manage their personal data and regulate who has access to it. Those who have not been exploited must be compensated by Facebook, as the four consumer organisations in Belgium, Italy, Spain and Portugal rightly claim, in their action before the courts.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the misappropriation of data from Facebook, which was later used by the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica, raises important questions about the means we have at our disposal to combat such phenomena. We must answer these questions, as 500 million European citizens we represent here are asking us to do. We are well aware that the business model of the large multinationals of the web is based on the collection of user data, which has become the new black gold, and on the subsequent monetization of the same. Alternatives to so-called surveillance capitalism exist, but we need the political will to take new paths. We must start again from the education of citizens so that they are not mere consumers but conscious members of society. We must equip our citizens with the necessary tools to enable them to use new media and new technologies, warning them what it means to live in a world where we are constantly connected. We must make the new generations aware of how important the right to privacy and the protection of personal data are and what its concrete applications are. There is still time to turn the page and prevent a repeat of scandals such as this.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last month a security breach allowed the personal data of some 50 million Facebook users to filter out, proving that despite the contrite excuses, expressed in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, there is definitely something rotten in Mark Zuckerberg's kingdom. What is the true nature of Facebook? It is the much more raw one of the breakdowns in a confidential memorandum from one of the vice-presidents.  We connect people, period. Maybe it will cost a life exposing someone to stalkers, maybe someone will die in a coordinated terrorist attack via our tools. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, that is exactly their own definition. Still Facebook is not neutral. Supported by his legions of moderators, his censorship is zealously exercised against a myriad of conservative accounts while on the other side of the Mediterranean, in Libya, armed militias communicate with impunity. By its control over the information and communications of millions of individuals, Facebook has thus made itself the armed arm of a totalitarian censorship with variable geometry. For compromising, our democracies will be forever disrupted and the next election will be truncated by lawless people.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, it is quite extraordinary that this Parliament should be indignant about Cambridge Analytica’s cack-handed attempt to impact democratic votes. After all, right now, just a few hundred yards from the Brussels Parliament, Herman Van Rompuy, the former President of the European Union, leads a think tank whose sole aim is undermining the UK’s democratic referendum to leave the European Union. Scandalously, he published a paper whose aim – and I quote – was to change the political dynamics in the UK by getting the Prime Minister to agree to an extension of the transition period.  This is foreign intervention in domestic politics. This is manipulation of voters from the outside. This is worse than Cambridge Analytica. This is the anti—democratic interference which is the very essence, the soul, of the European Union, and it has worked as Theresa May is now offering such an extension. Scandalous, scandalous, scandalous!  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)) (Interjection from Mr Woolfe: ‘It is a pure joy to accept such blue cards from Mrs Scott Cato. Go ahead.’)

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Dr Cato – but I appreciate Mr Woolfe taking the blue card and having the courage to do so.  Steven Woolfe sounds extremely indignant about this debate, so I wonder if he’s critical about the theft of our citizens’ data? I wonder if he minds about the use of illegal ads? Does he believe that the EU wants to steal our cuppa or cause polar bears to starve? And does he approve of the micro-targeting of ads at a vulnerable group of people, as Mr Moraes said, which undermines the public debate?

name: Steven Woolfe (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – What I’m indignant about is the hypocrisy of this House. The hypocrisy that, on the one hand, says we do not like Cambridge Analytica yet we’re quite willing to accept the money of Soros as he funds organisations in the UK that have tried to attempt to have a third referendum in the United Kingdom. Those who attempt to suggest that outside interference in the EU is perfectly acceptable: if you want democracy, treat it fairly on both sides, but don’t accept the money from those who are trying to undermine our own Parliament.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, there are still further blue card applications, but let us adopt the principle: one speaker, one blue card. The point is that we have to finish at 10.30.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the What does Facebook do, and what do parliamentary questionings bring? Let us not deceive ourselves. Facebook has not taken Parliament's investigation seriously. Facebook has lost trust and broken EU law. On the other hand, fine words or voluntary commitments do not help. Strict rules, effective controls and, if necessary, sanctions are needed.  What does that mean? Firstly, thanks to the General Data Protection Regulation, we can penalise infringements, as in the case of Cambridge Analytica, with up to 4% of global turnover. Let us give our data protection authorities the necessary means of effective control! Secondly, we need more transparency, particularly in the case of political advertising. Who is actually the client of an embassy and who pays?  Thirdly, we need the ePrivacy regulation to protect against targeting, for example. ePrivacy should have been working together with the Data Protection Regulation for a long time. The fact that ePrivacy has been blocked by the Member States for 1.5 years is unacceptable! Bottom line: we are not helpless at the mercy of the practices of the big digital companies, but we must now act decisively and together to protect our citizens, in order to protect our democracy.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking about two problems, related, but different – the use of personal data for commercial purposes and their use for political purposes. While the former has been known to us for at least a few years, the gravity of the latter problem is only just reaching our consciousness.  It is right to demand that online platforms distinguish between the political uses of their online advertising products and their commercial uses and that the processing of personal data for political advertising purposes should have a different legal basis from that applicable to commercial advertising. It is only that, as far as I know, such an appropriate legal basis has not yet been established and it is a great task for the future to develop it. The motion for a resolution also states that Member States should urgently investigate alleged misuse of the internet political space by foreign powers. But, after all, abuses of the online political space also happen within the Union, between different Member States. And that also needs to be analyzed.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, at the beginning of this year we saw the Facebook Cambridge Analytic scandal unfolding, an event of major proportions. We saw how our private data was harvested without our consent and subsequently used for political purposes – not a small one, but the biggest and most important one. The reaction was justifiably harsh. A common voice from all over this Parliament protested about the illegal use of private data. Mr Zuckerberg himself stood here and spoke about the change. He promised better security and assured us that something like this would never happen again. And why is it that, just a month ago, we saw another Facebook security breach aimed at our private data? How many more ‘sorrys’ are we going to have from Mr Zuckerberg? I don’t think there is any meaning in asking him anything anymore. I therefore urge the Commission and this Parliament to respond appropriately and prevent this from happening again. We need stronger privacy rules and we need better enforcement of existing laws in order to have our personal data information secured.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, it should no longer be possible for personal data to be used without the knowledge of users. The Cambridge Analytica scandal has shown the immense power that we have allowed to accumulate in the hands of companies that have our personal data as they see fit. It's time to take back control of our data to keep control of our lives. Let's open our eyes. To accept that our data should be used for profiling and political targeting would not only be an individual defeat, but a collective abdication. Leaving Facebook and its algorithms to determine the political messages we receive is to accept a form of voluntary servitude. At a time when the truth itself is threatened by the proliferation of infox, our freedom of opinion is linked to the clear knowledge we have of who is addressing us and for what purpose. Do we want homo numericus to remain a free citizen? So any political content must be able to be identified as such and we need to know who is behind it. It's really the minimum and it's urgent.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, in 2013, Snowden revealed to us how US agencies had put the largest companies in the Internet sector to keep an eye on users. The world then realized how fragile your privacy and the protection of your data was. Five years passed and the Cambridge Analytica scandal came to show us how on the edge of the precipice what it was decided to do was take a step forward. Privacy and our personal data have become one of capitalism's most valuable assets and today we know that personal data has been used as weapons of political combat. If we add to this the growth of fake news, lies and hate speech, we have the perfect recipe for mass manipulation of elections. Platforms such as Facebook and WhatsApp do not have the capacity or transparency to deal with the information they propose and even less to protect it, as we see in Brazil. So I ask what more needs to happen to continue to defend our democracies and to defend democratic elections.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the My party is a conservative party, moderate, right-of-centre. In my country, however, many journalists are predominantly left-of-centre, many of them very far to the left. Some surveys conclude that more than 40% of journalists vote green. Objective reporting is not a matter of course, certainly not in these times. So I'm very grateful that Facebook exists. With Facebook, we have a channel to our voters that green-left indoctrinating journalists can't wall us up. We are watching very closely how the left-wing majority in this House and in our home wants to take this access away from us. We see them putting pressure on Facebook, how they want to throttle and even censor conservative-liberal expression in reach. This is the case with the left: first they demand non-dominant discourse, and once they are in power, then they are only interested in discourse-free domination. Ladies and gentlemen, anyone who does not want to discuss this proves only one thing: that he has no arguments. And those who, like you, have no arguments, have already lost the debate. You will notice that.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, in the face of the illusion of freedom on the Internet there is a harsh reality. And here, as when the screen closes, do the business groups that own the property. For others, work, information, fun means, unintentionally or unknowingly, self-inventory. Their personal data, political attitude and interests are recorded, collected, processed, become a commodity, the subject of fierce competition over which group, secret service and civil state will control them by treasures, displacing its competitors.  The European Union and its governments play the sensitive part of personal data, set up GDPR mechanisms and impose sanctions, serving European groups in their competition with their US counterparts for market control. Beautiful world, angelically created capitalism, the questioning of this system, which today is censored and filtered, will find its way and, with its overthrow, their science, technology and applications will be put at the service of popular needs.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, our message here six months ago was clear: the misuse of the data of millions of European citizens is scandalous, Facebook must change and Mark Zuckerberg must come here and answer. Well, that accountability session came, but it was – partly because of the demands of Zuckerberg himself – a mockery. Even in the three good hearings we have organised in this House, Facebook has in no way appeared to take this problem seriously. Instead of people with knowledge of business or people who actually have something to say in the company, the public policy team was sent, the lobbyists from Facebook, the same lobbyists who were previously used here to lobby hard against our new privacy rules. So while we're right to note that Facebook has made improvements, it's anything but reassuring. One and a half billion users were quickly put out of the reach of European rules. Another sign that Facebook still doesn't believe in the importance of data protection or the way we deal with it in Europe. So it's our job to give them that faith. Good or bad. There needs to be a full audit of the Facebook company and regulators across Europe need to get to work to really verify that current practices at the company are complying with our rules. Facebook posted full-page ads in April to welcome the new European rules. So we're probably doing Facebook a great favor to enforce those rules from day one, first of all at Facebook itself.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am not going back on our resolution, which I support; I hope that the Commission will at this time work to protect the European elections from interference which, as a result of these hearings, appears not only possible but absolutely predictable. I wanted to raise an issue which concerns the whole fact that we are waking up from a world where everything seemed free and we are discovering that, in reality, the price we pay this world of the Internet all free of charge is the use of our data for economic and electoral purposes. I therefore believe that the problem is more complex and needs to be addressed: as in a future that will increasingly use platforms of this type, a correct relationship is reconstructed where you pay for what you use but you are protected in your identity and in the use of your data. I believe that there is also a problem with public platforms because, as always, when large monopolies are created, the public can intervene both to regulate monopolies and also through different public instruments.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in my own country the relevant committee in my parliament is crying out for action to be taken. My colleague Damian Collins is not satisfied with the result, and the committee in question has carried out an inquiry and has directly said that there is manipulation and Russian interference in our election processes. That is at a nation-state level and look here today: the Council chairs are empty, that is the response that we are giving. Governments are stalling, Facebook knows its power. But this weekend hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of London and among their demands is a demand that we must protect our much-cherished democratic processes. Cambridge Analytica and Facebook were instrumental in swaying the EU referendum in the United Kingdom; swaying it using techniques beyond the expectations of an unsuspecting electorate and out-of-date election regulations. Nick Clegg may hold the most senior public policy role in Facebook today ; let’s hope he guides them well. But Cambridge Analytica has not gone, it lives on in other guises and will continue to show itself again.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE).
text: – Colleagues, this is really a scandal, a crisis of confidence, and I am glad that the European Commission will not miss this crisis and will not leave it unused. However, I want to look at the problem from another angle.  We create our own digital personality. In the beginning, her life really depends on our will, and we really control things. However, no one tells us, and probably no one could tell us from what point onwards the data of our digital self is used by other people and organizations for their own purposes.  We do not realize that our digital self contains information that, combined with hundreds of thousands, millions of other such digital personalities, in practice represents value, can be bought and sold and used in so-called "big data analyses" and the preparation of infographics, with which we can be individually manipulated and targeted as consumers and voters. Of course, we will do our best to create appropriate regulation, but I always have doubts that our legislative activities will be behind us as soon as they are created. We will always fall behind on new technologies. Therefore, I would like to turn to the other, the real protection – common sense, restraint, digital competence. This is what we need to educate especially in our young people, because the digital space does not promote these qualities. Of course, there is no more reliable barrier to manipulation than the responsible democratic person, armed with the appropriate regulations, the making of which is our duty.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the phrase ‘if you are not paying for the product, you are the product’ predates the internet era. Still, both regulators and internet users seem unprepared for the new reality in which data is the new oil. Unaware to whom they give away their data or how they can stop sharing it, most people until recently found being offered ads to buy things as something uncontroversial. However, the Cambridge Analytica scandal revealed something more worrying: people’s data can be improperly collected and shared, and they can be microtargeted by various entities who want to influence and manipulate their political view or voting behaviour. This threatens the very idea of democracy, according to which voters can decide for themselves and are not mere subjects of propaganda machines. Users and, most importantly, regulators need to catch up with this new reality. We took the first step with the adoption of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR); now we should apply it and make sure third countries using our citizens’ data apply it too.

name: Romeo Franz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Do we really owe Brexit and President Trump to this data-based individual manipulation? This question is extremely difficult to answer, but it is the core democratic question of this scandal.  There are insights into the political impact of Facebook. A team from the University of Warwick has looked at the far-right attacks in Germany in recent years and searched for possible causes. Depending on the locality, they have looked at whether there is a connection with the number of foreigners living there, with unemployment, the level of education and income and, and, and, and. The only variable where they could determine a significant statistical correlation with the number of assaults was the extent of Facebook's use in the local population. Facebook is a problem for our democracy – even without Cambridge Analytica. It is therefore good that the resolution calls for a ban on targeted political advertising based on profiles with personal data. Unfortunately, the code of conduct that the Commission has drawn up with the platform only aims at transparency and self-regulation. However, we need clear rules when our democracy is important to us.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as rapporteur on the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), I was very pleased with the overall outcome, and I think it will work well into the future. But, as Ms Sophia in 't Veld said, all the rules and laws in the world are no good unless theyʼre applied, and I think it’s quite obvious that there are problems in Facebook – we have seen that for some time. The first one, I think, is the question that Manfred Weber, Leader of the European People’s Party, put to Mark Zuckerberg when he came to Parliament. He said: ‘Is Facebook just too big?’ We had the phrase during the recession from his book about banks being too big to fail, but is Facebook just too big to operate? That’s one question that has to be looked at. I know Facebook does an awful lot of good work in terms of facilitating people to communicate, but the dark side has to be addressed, especially countries like Russia interfering in elections. That’s undermining all of society and it needs to be monitored and monitored independently, as opposed to what’s happening now.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the attack on Facebook on 28 September put the personal data of millions of people at risk: from the simplest information to the bank details linked to Facebook profiles, everything was the subject of the attack. After Cambridge Analytica, this new scandal shows that Facebook is not yet in a position to ensure full compliance with EU data protection legislation, in particular the General Data Protection Regulation and the e-privacy directive. After the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Facebook promised a full internal audit: if that happened, the European Parliament has not yet been informed. Facebook must allow ENISA and the European Data Protection Board to carry out an independent audit on its platform. Facebook needs to make substantial changes to its platform, not only to ensure compliance with EU data protection law, but also to improve its transparency, to stem the risk of further political manipulation of Facebook profiles and to prevent fake news from affecting the next election.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. Chairman, the development of information technologies and numerous digital services has made people more networked than ever before. Doing business without the internet is hard to imagine today, and online we have moved a good part of our private life – from texting and storing family photos to buying clothes and ordering food. Products and services are easily accessible, new communication channels have made us more productive, but all this comes at a cost of violated privacy and security. The Cambridge Analytica case only confirmed the importance of protecting citizens' data online. But it is very important to avoid unnecessary hysteria and inform citizens what poses a danger to their privacy and what is benign. A panicked withholding of all data would significantly slow down the development of digital services, make it harder for many companies to operate and put jobs at risk. That, I believe, is nobody's goal.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, those of us involved in politics have been horrified by the way Facebook has been used to share disinformation that distorts democracy and divides societies. From the UK Brexit campaign to the Trump election and now the presidential election in Brazil, Facebook has shown itself to be an anti-social network that threatens democracy. The disinfectant of publicity has not ended this problem. Cambridge Analytica is morphing into a new form under the auspices of Emerdata that reunites the money of the Mercer family with the manipulative skills of Alexander Nix, and itʼs disappointing to hear that Nick Clegg will be joining Facebook as global ambassador and spin master. The resolution notes that we need less PR and more detailed answers from technical experts and changes to Facebook governance. I’m pleased that the resolution notes the excellent work done by the UK’s information commissioner, Elizabeth Denham, and that it seeks to prohibit political targeted advertising that undermines the public debate through microtargeting. We are witnessing democracy disrupted across the world. Protecting democracy against the psychological operations of the wealthy should be a priority for us all.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the Cambridge Analytica scandal has shown that the personal data of some 50 million users he had managed to secure was allegedly used to bolster President Trump's campaign. Of course, this practice is not unknown in the United States. According to Bloomberg, president Obama did something similar in 2012. But the deeper issue that emerges from this scandal is the security of personal data.  Every person, unfortunately without taking into account the issue of confidentiality, gives up his personal data on social media, hoping that these will not be analysed. Unfortunately, however, this is not the case, because with the algorithms that have created these instruments, they analyse personal data in order to assess, above all, commercial preferences but also policies and to be able to influence them. That is why the Member States must take measures to stop this happening, but without violating the right to free expression of the user.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the use of personal data voluntarily or unintentionally transferred by the social network Facebook, or by other networks and platforms, to manipulate political choices and choices and behaviours of mass, raises a civilisational question. At issue are values such as privacy, transparency, trust and, ultimately, citizens' freedom of choice. As we prepare to make the huge investment in Europe's digital programme, we must set an ethical and legal standard for all companies operating in our territory, or interacting with it, and develop robust verification and sanctioning tools for those who do not. At the same time, it is important to progressively develop a social media management model that is closer to the Internet model, more multi-stakeholder and less based on large hegemonic business potentates. You have to give back to society what's hers. It is necessary to put technological development at the service of individuals and not those who want to manipulate and distort their freedom of choice.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner for Justice, when the scandal broke out, Mark Zuckerberg was called to appear before the United States Senate and it was the first time he put on a tie. His physical position was subordination to the United States Senate. When he appeared here in the European Parliament, he was not even remotely subjected to a harshly even interrogation to which he was subjected by the United States Senate.  We are before the giants of the network, who consider themselves completely disassociated from any law and any jurisdiction and yet before no giant can the European Union abdicate its duty to protect and secure the fundamental rights of Europeans; therefore, there is much to be done.  To begin with, we must require that the Data Protection Regulation be complied with, as well as the network giants, and, where appropriate, the directive linking the police, judiciary and prosecution to investigate crimes related to fundamental rights violations on the network should be implemented. But we also need to invest in privacy education, cybersecurity and new technologies, because our investment in new technologies has nothing to do with that of the United States, and until we have a better investment in security and technologies, we have nothing to do with network giants.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating something that is about the future of Europe, after all, the life of citizens and democracy. But, behold, the Council is not present, the Commission seems to be pleased with the steps it has taken, we, Parliament, have done our job as has been said and we are in the same situation, Commissioners, because, lo and behold, every week we can see that false accounts appear, that our data is taken. What are we actually doing? The Commissioner says we have a very powerful instrument, but how do we use it? What are the results? Let's face it, I believe that the Commission must find common ground because Facebook has ignored us. I was in a delegation in July there. He found nothing new after saying that when he designed Facebook, he didn't think about data protection. I believe that we have nothing so far and in a few months we are entering the European elections. We can't let citizens, companies defend themselves with mastodons, fight mastodons. This is the duty of the Commission and the Council.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate on what is a key resolution. As my colleague, Commissioner Jourová, underlined, the Cambridge Analytica case has thrust into the spotlight an array of threats to our elections: hacks, leaks, fake news, as well as the misuse of personal data, classical cyber—attacks that target our voting systems and cyber—enabled manipulation of voting behaviour. To tackle the classic cybersecurity threats, the Commission brought forward a package of measures in September last year to build greater cyber-resilience, to protect systems and data and to strengthen deterrence against those who would seek to attack us. To tackle the challenge of cyber-manipulation, in April this year, the Commission proposed a package of measures in our communication on tackling online disinformation, based around transparency, traceability and accountability. This set out our clear definition of disinformation. It sent a clear and strong message to all of the internet platforms – Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and others – who we strongly believe have a real responsibility to take action. We asked them to commit to an EU-wide Code of Practice on Disinformation, presented in fact last month. We set out clear objectives for this code and called for measurable results in a number of areas, not asking the platforms, or indeed public authorities, to judge whether something is true or false, right or wrong, but to shine a light on the provenance of the information that we are seeing. I am encouraged that your resolution, as Claude Moraes underlined, identifies the need for urgent action in a number of these areas. We ask the platforms to restrict targeting options for political advertising, to ensure greater transparency around sponsored content, to step up their efforts to identify and delete fake accounts, and to establish clear rules around bots. There should also be greater clarity around algorithms and information on how they prioritise the content that is on display. This should be combined with tools enabling users more easily to discover content and access new sources representing alternative points of view, as well as to be able to report disinformation. We want to see the code implemented effectively. We’ve said we’ll analyse first results by the end of this year. We hope we can see sufficient progress by working on a voluntary basis, but we’ve been clear: we reserve the right to consider our options again if we do not make the progress that we need to see. As mentioned by Commissioner Jourová earlier, last month President Juncker presented a set of measures specifically on election security, asking Member States to set up a national election cooperation network of all of the relevant authorities and to appoint a contact point to participate in a European-level election cooperation network. As part of this, the Commission will work closely with, and support, data protection authorities to make sure that all data breaches are effectively investigated. Last week, we convened a high-level meeting which brought together, for the first time, public and private actors from the Member States in order to take stock of progress and to identify and share best practices for countering the threats to our democratic processes and our democratic values. This event highlighted again the key importance of engagement, both by the public authorities, but also by the key private-sector actors. With the European elections and numerous national elections on the horizon, it is imperative that we see sufficient commitment from the big online platforms. The Commission very much welcomes your strong engagement on this urgent range of issues. Awareness is the first line of defence, but, as you set out in your resolution, we need to go further. We have a strong shared interest in protecting our democratic institutions, our democratic processes and our elections. The Commission is committed to working with you, with Member States and with the private sector to secure the foundations of our democracy.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: You will allow such a small personal observation. It was good that I was able to preside over this point of our debate, because in the European Parliament I am responsible for security, including the one we have discussed here. I have received one motion for a resolution closing the debate. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 25 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ева Майдел (PPE)
text: in writing. – The abuse of truth, facts and trust of people and voters is not a patent on digital platforms. It unfortunately existed and will continue to exist in the analogue, digital and paper worlds. The only thing that has changed with the new platforms is easier access to them. What we need to do is set clear rules so that platforms take their responsibility by controlling the communication environment they have created and better monitoring harmful content and misuse of personal data. However, we have one more task and it is to impose rules and sanctions on those who want to take advantage of the lack of clear rules in digital platforms. And this in the first place are political parties and candidates and their partner organizations. Neither Facebook nor Google or any of the other platforms can escape their responsibility, but we must not forget that the main interest in this abuse is precisely in political organizations and candidates. And they need to get the greatest rigour we can for wanting to manipulate citizens' choices by substing the fair political race for their credibility with a race of lies and manipulation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Socialist Group in the European Parliament was the first to recognise that the most important and urgent task of the EP and the union as a whole is to be at the forefront of the defence against insreplicable practices that threaten our citizens, our entire democratic political order, such as the 'busting' of Cambridge Analytica – the misuse of the personal data of tens of millions of Facebook users.  However, with this decision, we are only in the process of detecting – even more importantly – and taking the first defensive step, knowing that the cambridge analytica case is just the tip of the iceberg, as there are many other businesses in the world that use personal data management algorithms to manipulate and sell information.  I consider the dissemination of 'fake news' organised by individual political forces and even states, political incitement campaigns and manipulation to influence the election results to be particularly dangerous for the democratic functioning of the EU and its Member States. In view of the forthcoming important elections in several countries of Europe, in particular the EP elections in May, I think it is important that our current resolution has a concrete afterlife, and that the Governments of the Member States, too, take decisive measures and targeted legislation to stop this modern attack. I would particularly expect this from political leadership in the Member States, such as my own country, where, unfortunately, the Orban government itself uses such tools of fake news and fear-mongering for its political purposes.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the context of the scandal surrounding Facebook companies - Cambridge Analytica, in which the data of millions of Facebook users was illegally accessed by a British consulting company for electoral purposes, we are witnessing today a series of extensive discussions on the protection of personal data that every internet user makes available to social media giants. I believe that the phenomenon is all the more important as it can lead to the manipulation of citizens, especially during the electoral process, or it can influence consumers in such a way as to lead to distortion of the market and fair competition. The Facebook-Cambridge Analytica scandal has made it very clear that we must make significant efforts to restore the confidence of our citizens in the democratic process and ensure an adequate level of transparency. In 2019, in Romania we will have two rounds of elections. In this context, the illegal collection of users' personal data is one of the biggest challenges we face in the age of digital technology worldwide. It is therefore important that Member States implement the General Data Protection Regulation as effectively as possible and that the Commission takes the necessary measures to monitor the implementation and enforcement of legislation in order to ensure the protection of all European citizens.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D)
text: in writing. – Facebook is a global social media platform that hosts, among other things, the accounts of more than 370 million European citizens of all ages, citizens whom we have an obligation to defend in the face of abuse of any kind. In this context, any breach of the European Regulation for the protection of personal data by the representatives of this platform or by third parties having access to its exploitation is in fact a breach of the privacy of 370 million European citizens. It is clear to anyone that the possession of the data of hundreds of millions of people - here including not only personal identification data, but also data on political preferences, preferences for certain products and services or other sensitive data, but also access to private discussions - represents a huge opportunity for the big companies that operate these social media platforms. This is also the case with Whatsapp or other apps. That is why, as great as the opportunity is, so must the responsibility of these operators, and I support the imposition of drastic sanctions by European or national authorities whenever the European regulation on GDPR is infringed. Otherwise, democracy itself is affected.

name: Presidente. –
text: I welcome, on behalf of Parliament, the President of the Republic of Romania, Klaus Iohannis, who will be the protagonist of today's debate on the future of Europe (2018/2732(RSP)).  I thank him for accepting our invitation to discuss with us, in a real debate, what Romania's proposals are for the future of Europe, in order to prepare together – the European Parliament, the Commission and the Member States – a strategy to relaunch the European dream, which, despite the difficulties it encounters, remains the only possibility for our fellow citizens. That is why I am very pleased to have the President of Romania with us today, on the eve of the six-month Presidency of the European Union, and elections will also take place during the Romanian Presidency. So today we will have the opportunity to confront him after listening to him. Before giving the floor to President Iohannis, I would remind you that it is possible to request catch the eye using the electronic voting device.

name: Klaus Iohannis
text: President of Romania. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour and a privilege to be in the European Parliament today. Thank you for inviting me to participate in the debate on the future of the European Union. The Union has been marked over time, but especially in the last decade, by multiple challenges that have tested our cohesion and unity, from the financial and economic crisis, the migration crisis, terrorist attacks, to the rise of populist movements. It was a decade in which the Union had to "learn to adapt on the go". Against the background of these challenges, the Union was marked by the search for a common vision, defined by the need for a 'wise' balance between the specific realities of each Member State and the desire to strengthen together a genuine Union, a future-oriented Union. The main positive finding of this period is that there is one element that unites us: European identity based on common principles, values and interests. And these common values must always be rediscovered, revalued and valued, because the universality of values lies precisely in their regenerative character. We are going through a new chapter in the development and consolidation of the European project, in which we need to develop a new vision for the future of the Union. From this perspective, I strongly advocate unity, cohesion, solidarity and the common European path in efforts to strengthen the European project. The central key to our efforts must remain "unity." For Romania, this principle is the very essence of the European project, which has given it the ability to face the multiple challenges that the Union has faced to date. The European Union is an evolutionary project. The new realities, both at Member State and global level, call for the development and consolidation of the European project and, in no way, a question of the fundamental principles on which the European project was built. A strong Union must not be achieved at the expense of unity. We need an inclusive Union, which leaves no state or european citizen behind. From this point of view, ideas such as a multi-speed Europe or a Union of concentric circles cannot be a solution, in so far as we want to maintain the unitary and indivisible character of the European Union, which gives it value and credibility in its relationship with the rest of the world. President Juncker said last year that Europe must find its breath, breathe with both lungs, the western and the eastern. I hope that our future together will also show us that Europe has only one heart. A heart that beats through all of us, that unites us, from east to west and from north to south, that makes our citizens naturally identify and define themselves as Europeans. We must assume this common ideal and, if necessary, adapt and recalibrate the tools by which we can achieve it. I am confident that the new stage in which the European Union will enter from 2019 and which Romania, as the rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union, will prepare together with the other Member States and the European institutions, will be a fruitful one. I am confident that the Sibiu Summit of 9 May 2019 will be a milestone in the projection for the future of a stronger, more united, more cohesive and more democratic Union. It is up to our power, wisdom and will - Member States, European institutions and European citizens - for this objective to become a reality. Ladies and gentlemen, the Sibiu Summit is an important moment to strengthen the foundation of this future. A common future, a democratic future, an optimistic future. The future of the European Union can only be edifyed with the direct and active participation and involvement of European citizens. I want Sibiu to be a time of awareness for European citizens. Citizens want concrete measures and tangible results. They want positive news about peace, security and prosperity. Citizens must also see that we are working to protect and strengthen the union's major symbols: the euro, the internal market, the Schengen area and freedom of movement. At the same time, our citizens need more cohesion. And cohesion is not only the ambition of the new Member States, which have a lower level of economic convergence, but it is a necessity for older members of the Union. Cohesion is unity, it is the expression of joint, concerted and coordinated action at Union level. We must return to the essence of the principle of cohesion, as reflected in the Union Treaties - the centripetal force of a community of vision and action, generating added value for the whole Union. The European Union is today in a moment of economic recovery. This would not have been possible in the absence of a common vision and action in the creation and consolidation of an economic and monetary union. Economic security is as important as border security, and the union's prosperity depends on our ability to ensure a strong economic and monetary union capable of meeting citizens' expectations, but also of meeting new challenges. In order to achieve this objective, we need comprehensive measures and decisions to ensure the participation of all Member States in joint efforts to achieve a stronger, more stable and more competitive euro area. For Romania, joining the euro area as soon as possible, when all the conditions are met, is a fundamental national objective. This year we are celebrating 25 years of the internal market. We have come a long way in terms of the freedoms and opportunities to travel, study and work within the European Union for our citizens. We cannot imagine the European Union without the single market and its four fundamental freedoms, the free movement of goods, people, services and capital. We need a functioning, competitive and inclusive internal market. An internal market in which citizens feel its benefits in their daily lives. At the same time, Europe is and must remain an international leader in multiple areas, particularly in terms of the technological and digital revolution. Europe has the ability and strength to transform itself and be a leader in connectivity. Growth and stability, competitiveness, security and improving the quality of life of all Europeans depend on how ambitious and determined Europe is in terms of digitalisation and research and innovation. At the same time, we must ensure that our workforce is better adapted to the needs, requirements and developments of the internal market, in order to ensure that social progress and competitiveness go hand in hand. We must also be aware that the digital transformation of society cannot be achieved without a massive investment in education and the new skills needed. All citizens - from any region and any social group - must be engaged in these developments.
