This must be our commitment, to those who lead Europe, and in this diversity and scope will lie the strength of our continent in the global competition to come. We are also talking about a future in which the Union will regain its own citizens by strengthening their sense of security here at home inside the Union. The challenges of migration and security are issues of maximum interest to all of us. We must act so that the European project rebuilds the safety of citizens, we must pay greater attention to the fight against terrorism and radicalisation. We need to act in such a way as to become more proactive and increase the Union's capacity to prevent. Responding to crises with contextual measures is not an effective way and, in this key, we need sustainable solutions. The European Union must remain an area of free movement, where all our citizens can move freely and work anywhere in the Community area, where young people can travel, study, thus fully benefiting from one of the most visible and ambitious projects of European construction - the Schengen area. For Romania, accession to the Schengen area is an important objective. This will make a significant contribution to strengthening security for the entire free movement area of the Union. The corollary of a safe and strong Union should be a enlarged Union, because size confers power - a very true and relevant notion in a highly competitive global context. And the Union's enlargement policy has clearly demonstrated its value through successive waves of welcoming new members, contributing, in an undeniable manner, to the prosperity and security of the continent. The enlargement of the Union must not only remain a wish for future generations, but continue sit a real necessity, in which candidate states and potential candidates must anchor their efforts to continue reforms and to take genuine and consistent ownership of European values and principles. Honourable MEPs, we cannot really be globally relevant if we fail to significantly influence the environment in our neighbourhood. Keeping the states in the Southern and Eastern Neighbourhood firmly anchored in European values and maintaining their commitment to irreversible structural reforms also depend on our ability to fulfil our commitments in relation to them. Last but not least, we are also talking about a future in which the Union will have a leading role on the international stage, a future in which Member States will support, on the basis of shared interests and mutual solidarity, the union's affirmation as a global actor, with a decisive contribution to the promotion of the rules-based multilateral system. The implementation of the European Union's Global Strategy has already facilitated important developments both in the area of security and defence and in strengthening links between the Union's internal and external policies. It is our responsibility to ensure that, in the years to come, the Union will have the tools to respond to new challenges. Continuing joint security and defence initiatives under conditions that ensure close cooperation and avoidance of parallelisms with NATO, strengthening the resilience of the Union and its partners, improving strategic communication are objectives that require increased attention and constant action. The consistency of the Union's policy in its neighbourhood, the maintenance of the strong transatlantic partnership, the honouring of commitments - from the continuation of enlargement policy within the agreed parameters, to the strengthening of the institutional relationship with the UN and the firm support of its multilateralism and virtues - are all areas where the Union will be called upon to demonstrate that it can act effectively. Distinguished Members of the European Parliament 11 years ago, when Romania joined the great European family, I felt particularly proud, as a Romanian, that I was living this important moment for my country. Next year, when Romania takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union for the first time, the Sibiu Summit will be a turning point for our European family. It is our duty, it is our responsibility to shape the future of Europe. Together with all Romanians, I feel proud as a Romanian citizen and also as a European citizen. Because national pride or European pride are not eroded concepts or parallel realities. It is an assumed state that sustains and gives strength and content to this identity. Because Europe is part of our fiber. A Europe that sums up our diversity. A Europe built on the concept of unity in diversity. That's why Europe is Romania and Romania is Europe. 2018 is the year of the Centenary of Modern Romania, which means for us not so much retrospective-historical analyses, but, above all, projections of the future. In these 100 years, I have learned some important lessons, going through unfortunate experiences and periods. And the lesson of democracy is one of the most important. That is why we appreciate all the more the values of the European family.  For this reason, Romania is a country deeply attached to the European project. We have a vibrant and dynamic, ever-evolving society. We are a young democracy, which has the resources to improve itself. Romanians are actively connected to civic values. They proved it as clearly as possible and made their voices heard when it was necessary to defend the rule of law and democracy. (Strong applause) The Romanians have the will and the strength to go on the European path they have taken. It is the ambition to overcome any obstacle in order to remain strongly anchored in the great European family of which we are fundamentally a part. The younger generation believes in Europe and engages in debates about our future in a positive and, above all, optimistic manner. Our optimism about the future of Europe is also feeding from the enthusiasm of these remarkable young people. At the same time, their enthusiasm makes us particularly responsible. The advantage of this wave of enthusiasm coming from Romania comes primarily from its strength to inspire and reawaken the reflex of the defence of democracy, which is not a given, but implies a continuous responsibility to care for, defend and promote it. Romania is now a dynamic and forward-looking country that has quickly embraced and capitalized on new technological trends and digital services. One of the Romanian companies has been a world leader in defence and cybersecurity solutions for several years. On the other hand, a company initiated by two young engineers became, this spring, the first Romanian "unicorn". In just six months, the company tripled its value to a valuation of 3 billion euros, becoming one of the world leaders in software, automation and artificial intelligence robots. All over Romania, from Iaşi to Timişoara, from Cluj to Bucharest, from Craiova and Constanta, thousands of talented Romanian engineers - women and men - are working to advance digital technologies, be they connected machines and intelligent transport systems, 5G telecommunications and the Internet of Things, research and innovation in blockchain, space technologies or digital agriculture. The data economy is the future, and the Romanian IT&C and creative sectors have one of the highest shares of national GDP across the Union. It must therefore not be grudged by anyone that Romania wants and has the capacity to contribute to strengthening the Union's global role in this area. Romania actively supports a Union that invests in the safety of its citizens. European unity is essential when we talk about strengthening the internal security of the Union. For Romania, as a Member State managing one of the European Union's largest external borders, security is a priority area, where we have already demonstrated that we are performing in all respects. We are able, today, to be a security provider, to the highest standards, for the whole Union, as we already do within NATO. As a Member State of the Union, we will attach particular importance to the continuation of measures aimed at reducing the fragmentation of the European Security Area. We have a duty to protect all citizens, whether they are in the Schengen states or not. This is only possible through the full application of state-of-the-art security instruments by all Member States at the Union's external border. Distinguished members of the European Parliament, the European Union has built itself on a desire that is as humane and profound as possible, that of peace on the European continent. This internal peace - with all its ingredients: cooperation between Member States, the principle of the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms, diversity, prosperity, social standards, work - has become an extremely valuable export asset. The time has come to return with this model inward and show our citizens what we have managed to create together. Let us see how we protect peace together and how the need for peace translates today to the citizen's interests. I always have in mind the extremely current words of Jean Monnet. Quote: "... il n'y a pas pour les powders d'Europe d'aumen que dans l'union» I urge you to keep unity as a watchword of the future. But a unity that will not come by itself. A unity that we must constantly protect and strengthen, while caring for the diversity so characteristic of European culture. Thank. (The assembly, standing, applauded the speaker)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President of the Republic, dear Klaus, Mr President of the European Parliament, it is a great honour for Mrs Creu, and for myself, to have been able to listen to you, who know you and love you. This is a great moment for the European Parliament, because it is the first time, I believe, that a Romanian President-in-Office has spoken, on the eve of the presidency of his country - the first Romanian Presidency - before the representatives of the European people.  Dragi români, I'm not fluent in Romanian but I did understand. My imperfect Romanian means "my dear Romanians" because they are watching us and looking at us. It is also a moment of great emotion for me, since I have a long history with Romania and with its President exercise. It is first of all personal, between the two of us, since we have known each other for centuries. The Romanian President was mayor of Sibiu Hermannstadt, and there is an old story between Hermannstadt and Luxembourg. Because contrary to what German historians claim, those who populated Transylvania were not the Saxons but the Luxembourgers. This makes it so that we can talk to each other in an approximate Luxembourgish; Finally, there is a union between us that makes ancient history last in our times and for decades and centuries before us. There are too few Romanians in this room. In December 1997, I chaired the European Council in Luxembourg under the Luxembourg Presidency, and it was then that we opened the doors widely for the countries that were then called 'candidate countries', including Romania. And, under another Luxembourg Presidency, in April 2005, I was able to sign on behalf of the European Union the Treaty on Romania's accession to the European Union. These were unforgettable moments for me, because on that day the reconciliation between European history and geography was definitely achieved and for me Romania is therefore not a neutral country, but a country to which I had my deepest feelings, the few qualities of heart that I can have, and therefore yes, welcome to Parliament and welcome back to Europe Mr President. I think of the Romanian people, whom I like because, through their authorities, they have covered me with distinctions and honours to which I have been sensitive, whereas as a rule, they say that we are not sensitive to these kinds of decorations and honours. I am thinking of the Romanian people who, from the beginning, have been able to integrate into the sphere of European solidarity and complicity as if Romania had been a founding Member State. And so, yes, Romania today and for a long time - even before its accession to the European Union - has been and has become a provider of stability and not a consumer of stability in a region tormented, difficult, dramatically tested, through its history, down to the blood, and so yes, without Romania, the European Union would not be complete. (Applause) Romania, from the first day of its accession, has been at the head of European integration. I know that the President does not like the Europe of concentric circles, an avant-garde Europe and a Europe that would be lagging behind. He doesn't like it at all, just like I don't like these concepts. But Romania has proved in fact that it has nothing to fear from such a scenario which, moreover, is not mine, because it has always ranked at the head of the movement. I take as an example Romania's agreement on the establishment of a European public prosecutor's office. Others, even founding Member States, do not have the courage to do this. Romania was among the first to say yes to the introduction of a European patent, while others did not have this avant-garde will. Romania will celebrate its centenary on 1 December of the current year, the centenary of the great union, as our Romanian friends say. I wanted to say to the President that it is of course a Roman holiday, but it is also a European holiday, because everything about Romania is about Europe. Everything unique to Romania is no stranger to the European Union and therefore on this day we will celebrate together a great moment in Romanian history and a great moment in European history. As early as 2014, when I appeared before this Parliament on 15 July - a date you did not accept but I did - I said that Romania, under the mandate of the Commission which is my own, should be part of the Schengen area. Seit Juli 2014 plediere ich dafar, dass Rumenian Teil der Schengen-Zone wird, und ich hette gerne, dass wir dies bewerkstelligen, bevor das Mandat dieser Kommission endet. (Applaus) Ich sage das aus allgemeinen Grunden, ich sage das aber auch aus Rumenen-spezifischen Grunden. Allerdings mechte ich darauf aufmerksam machen - und das ist eine Bemerkung, die ich nicht so sehr an die Address des Pràsidenten richte, sondern eher an die Address der rumonischen Regierung und des rum-nischen Parlaments: Man darf das nicht dadurch in Gefahr bringen, dass man von rechtsstaatlichen Prinzipien Abstand nimmt. (Applaus) Mein Herzenswunsch wre es, dass man in Rumenen vor Eintritt in die Presidentschaft der European Union einen nationalen Konsensus hinkriegt, was Rechtsstaatlichkeit und Kampf gegen die Korruption anbelangt. Dies ist absolut notwendig.  (Applaus) Ansonsten wird es der Kommission schwerfallen, die zielgerichtete Empfehlung, was den Schengen-Raum anbelangt, einvernehmlich vorschlagen zu kunnen.  And then we have the problem of the budget. I have had more than three talks with my friend the president, insisting on the need to put into place the negotiation boxes after the Austrian Presidency, which will achieve it. Concluding this chapter would be a major performance and much-needed achievement under the Romanian Presidency, in the light of the perspective of the summit in Sibiu. This chapter on the financial perspective has to be concluded before the European elections because we would lose more than the momentum, we would lose several dimensions. It would be a major win for us if we were able to put the financial outlook in place. I know that the Romanian president, my dear friend Klaus, is very committed to achieving this, together with his government. It will be no ordinary summit in Sibiu (Hermannstadt). It will be the moment when and where we have to deliver European perspectives, talking to those who called for the European elections in May 2019. Ich bin sehr davon 'berzeugt, dass der Herr President und die rum-nische Regierung, das rum-nische Parlament, alles in ihren Kr-ften Stehende tun werden, um Sibiu zu einem groeen Moment europeischer Zukunftsgestaltung zu machen. Ich hatte letztes Jahr vorgeschlagen, dass wir diesen Gipfel in Hermannstadt/Sibiu haben sollten, weil ich der Auffassung bin, wenn es ein Land, das erst 2007 mit groeer Versp-tung im europeischen Geschichtsverlauf der Europ-ischen Union beigetreten ist, schaffen wurde, die nechsten sieben Jahre rumenisch - sprich europeisch - europeisch - sprich rum-nisch - zu gestalten, trege dies eine Symbolkraft in sich, die man nicht. (Beifall)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the President of Romania. Mr President, it is good to have you here within the format of the Future of Europe discussions in the European Union.  The first lesson, I would say, that we can learn when we listen to you, as a representative of this great country, is optimism: Europe works, Europe delivers. I only want to mention one figure out of the last 20 years: the economic development of Romania, so the growth rate, increased by more than 490% on the GDP base, four times higher than Moldova, for example. So to be part of this Europe, to be part of the European Union, works – on the question of the economy, but also on the question of developing towards a modern society in Romania. Congratulations on this.  But, I must say that Europe is not yet really unified. We cannot talk today about an already really united European Union. Romania is a Member of the European Union but the living conditions inside of our Union differ a lot. The European People’s Party (the PPE) does not want to accept this. We want to change this. We want to really have, in the future, a united Europe where people have an equal standard of living.  There is no Europe of east and west. There is no Europe of north and south. No Europe of poor and rich. There are only Europeans. And that is why, as the PPE, we want to continue our efforts under cohesion policy – you mentioned this – and we have to invest again in infrastructure, but I think new priorities are also needed. In research, for example. Let’s build, for example, the next supercomputer of the European Union in some of the countries in the central and eastern European Member States, and not always in the traditional Western countries, and let’s dream the dream that in the future an Austrian or a French student goes to Krakow or Bucharest to study and not to Oxford or Munich anymore. That is probably one of the dreams we should really dream.  Another element is that Romania is a Member of the European Union but also in terms of the conditions, not yet fully. That is why we welcome the engagement to join the euro, which is for us a crucial element for surviving as Europeans in a globalised world, and we fully support the enlargement process on the Schengen Area. Let’s be engaged. We also fully support what President Jean-Claude Juncker said today, that we should get started; probably the first step is opening the airports already before the European elections in 2019. We have to move on these questions.  I want to show respect also towards the citizens of Romania, because I think it is clear that there is still a need of modernisation, of modernising the country in the direction of a country which fights strongly for fundamental principles and fights against corruption. I want to clarify that this is not only a Romanian problem, but it is also a Romanian problem, and people care about this, people care about the situation in the country. The government has to change the direction.  We discussed this a few weeks ago here in Strasbourg as well. For my political family, I have to underline that today’s government already crossed some of the red lines which are defined in our common understanding about values and I want to thank you, as President, because you gave the people in Romania who demonstrated opposition, who demonstrated too their readiness to go forward for a modern Romania, a voice. You defended modernisation. You are the President of a modern Romania and that is good.  Herr Präsident, Sie werden in ein paar Monaten die Präsidentschaft übernehmen. Da gibt es noch ein paar Punkte, die uns wichtig sind. Das erste ist, dass wir bis dahin versuchen müssen, Antworten zu geben. In der Migrationsfrage, in der Fragestellung des Budgets für die Europäische Union müssen wir liefern, und wir müssen auch über die Erfolge, die wir haben, reden, den Menschen auch vermitteln, dass Europa in ihrem Alltag wirkmächtig und positiv ist. Das Zweite, was aber auch wichtig ist, ist, dass in Ihrer Ratspräsidentschaft die Europawahlen stattfinden werden. Wir alle vertreten ein demokratisches Europa. Wir sind die Kammer der Bürger der Europäischen Union. Für ein demokratisches Europa braucht man Kandidaten und man braucht ein Programm, man braucht Inhalte, man braucht Ideen. Das werden wir praktizieren als Abgeordnete, als Parteien auf diesem Kontinent in den nächsten Jahren. 2014, bei der letzten Wahl, hatten wir beispielsweise zum ersten Mal Spitzenkandidaten nominiert, wie Jean-Claude Juncker, auch Guy Verhofstadt hat kandidiert, Ska Keller hat kandidiert, wir hatten verschiedene Kandidaten. Und wir wollen beim nächsten Mal noch mehr die Programmvielfalt deutlich machen – dass ich für Ceta gestimmt habe und Ska Keller gegen Ceta gestimmt hat beispielsweise –, die Unterschiede deutlich machen. Worum ich Sie bitte, ist, dass Sie im Anschluss Ihren Beitrag dazu leisten, dass dieses demokratische Europa, die Willensbildung der Bürger Europas dann auch nach den Europawahlen Ausdruck findet in einem gemeinsamen Programm für die Zukunft dieses Kontinents und in den Entscheidungen, die dann zu fällen sind. Ich habe mit dem Verweis auf den Optimismus begonnen, den Sie praktizieren, und ich möchte damit auch schließen. Vor 28 Jahren, am Beginn der Neunziger, hat ein junger Mann in Sibiu vor der Entscheidung gestanden, sein Land entweder zu verlassen und in der Ferne seine Zukunft zu suchen, oder dazubleiben und aufzubauen. Er hat sich für das Letztere entschieden, fürs Anpacken. Er hat zunächst seine Stadt in die Zukunft geführt, die Arbeitslosigkeit reduziert und den Menschen einen guten Platz zum Leben geschaffen. Heute steht der gleiche Mann vor uns, nämlich der heutige Präsident Rumäniens, Klaus Iohannis. Und deswegen ist die Botschaft, die Sie mitbringen, Optimismus. Mit viel Arbeit, mit Seriosität, mit Willen und Ideen kann man sein Land und Europa in eine gute Zukunft führen. Danke für diese Botschaft! (Beifall)

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Welcome to the European Parliament, Mr President. It is important that you face up to the debate on the future of Europe today. Not only because your country will take over the Presidency of the Council from Austria in a few weeks' time, but also because of developments in Central and Eastern Europe. The euphoria that spread more than ten years ago has faded away. Ditches that are believed to have been overcome open up and new ones are added. This is also linked to non-compliance, such as your country's repeatedly postponed accession to Schengen. Generally speaking, there are imbalances, especially in the economic field, which apply to the entire East. The demographic situation is also a challenge. Most Eastern European countries face a huge brain drain. We should address these developments much more openly, more directly, self-critically. Also to prevent the latent resentment of demagogues from being exploited in order to undermine the European community of values. Often – and you too have done so today – an image is quoted in the context of Eastern and Western Europe, according to which Europe would have to breathe with two lungs. The rule of law, democracy and human rights are the air we need to breathe, and that unites us.  Mr President, it is good to hear that you, too, do not want to call into question European values and that you want to base your actions accordingly. Romania is an important Member State of the Union, a very important one, with great potential. Economic growth is well above the EU average, mainly thanks to a strong commitment to the IT sector. The Romanian diaspora also contributes significantly to the economic development of other Member States. Romania has come a long way. The initial situation was more difficult than in the other former communist countries. The progress made was particularly possible because the country is cooperating with the European Commission in the cooperation and control mechanism. The fight against corruption and the independence of the judiciary are priorities. Only if this succeeds can the positive economic development of the country be secured in the long term. Only when corruption is eliminated will economic success also appeal to ordinary people. Much still needs to be done in this respect. The S&D Group will be a critical supporter here. For us, democracy and the rule of law are at the heart of it. These principles are universal and apply to all Member States, whether in the East or the West.  If you had a little more discipline, you would let me speak out. That is why we are counting on you to support the European Parliament in finally implementing the rule of law and fundamental rights mechanism that we are proposing, which we will be discussing this afternoon. Mr President, we are watching with concern the internal political situation in your country, which is constantly getting worse. It is not for us to interfere in domestic political processes, but it is not good for a society to become increasingly fragmented and to become incompatible. We hope that, by virtue of your office and your personality, you will contribute to overcoming them and to more commonality. That is why we are also asking you to reconsider the role of the secret services, the last remnant of the Ceauescu years. Secret protocols should not play a role in ordinary court proceedings. This would be an important step towards a modern, liberal and European Romania.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Welcome, President Iohannis! 11 years after accession, Romanians want to Europe - 65% of us want Romania to remain in the Union and more than 60% of the citizens of the Member States also want in the Union - a record level in the last 25 years. European political leaders must not lose this people's trust, but must strengthen it. Romanians put their trust in the Union especially now, when they have been living for months the nightmare of a non-transparent government, which constantly attacks independent justice and weakens the fight against corruption. However, Romanians are a living people and do not hesitate to take to the streets to defend justice, justice and democracy. During this time, the European Parliament has adopted new directives to combat money laundering, for the extensive confiscation of assets, but they are not transposed into Romania, either on time or correctly, but on the contrary, often the other way around than the directives provide. That, by this PSD-ALDE government. In order to preserve its values, Europe must sanction slippages from democracy. President Iohannis publicly criticized and sanctioned the slippages of the PSD-ALDE government, the assault on justice and the amendment of criminal law. But the PSD-ALDE speech, like the speeches of other populist politicians, tries to manipulate public opinion by insisting that Romania or other Member States are losing their identity. However, I say nothing about the advantages of membership of the Union. Extremist discourse divides societies, while extremist politicians go about their business with public money, following the Kremlin's example. We must overcome extremism and populism. Before taking over the Presidency, the government must comply with all the recommendations of the Venice Commission and the warnings of the European Commission regarding the amendment of the codes and laws of justice. It would be a sign of respect for Romanians, foreign partners and democracy. In 2019 it will be the first time since accession that Romania has taken over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. The first Union summit, without the UK, will take place in Sibiu in May 2019. In order to preserve its values and Europe must sanction the slippages from democracy, as I said. Romania has the opportunity, taking over the Presidency of the European Council, to be on the world's radar in the first half of 2019. I want Romania to fulfil this role responsibly and professionally.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the first time that I went to your country, President Iohannis, to Bucharest, was in December 1989 in one of those old Tarom airplanes. I have to tell you, it was torture. With no leg-room, it was a little bit like flying with Ryanair today. For me it was the first time that I went to a Communist country, because before the fall of the Berlin Wall, we liberals were not allowed to go. In Bucharest – I remember it very well – I met the historical leader of the Romanian liberals, Radu-Anton Câmpeanu, in an empty building, in an empty office with one table and one chair. He had just returned from exile in Paris in December 1989. When I came back here, what I did was immediately to send a truck full of office furniture and computers. A few months later these capitalist gifts were destroyed by a furious mob of miners, the henchmen of Iliescu. So I had to send a second truck to Romania to help Mr Câmpeanu build up his liberal and democratic movement. Not only did I send office furniture and computers, I also sent material for a radio station that became one of the first private radio stations in your country – Radio Contact – with the same name as a station in Belgium. The reason why I’m telling you this story is very simple, because today, so many years later – nearly 30 years later – I am again worried about what is happening in Romania. First of all, these dubious reforms were undermining the judiciary – I said that to your Prime Minister here a few weeks ago. The same applies to the weakening of the Criminal Code, undermining the fight against corruption. Then there was the discovery of secret protocols, which I have never heard about in any other country, between the secret service on the one hand and some parts of the judiciary on the other. My plea to the Prime Minister, but also to you – because you have to work together in this respect – is certainly not to follow that path in the near future and certainly not to follow the examples of countries like Poland and Hungary, which have embarked on illiberal paths, I should say, towards autocracy. I think that only good cooperation between you, as the President of the Romanian Republic, and the Prime Minister, the Government and the majority can avoid this. And I think there is huge support in this House to support you in this endeavour. So what we need, I think, exactly 30 years after the Romanian revolution, at European level is exactly what is also at stake in Romania. There will be, in 2019, a fight between liberal democracy and the tendency in a number of countries – unfortunately mainly eastern European countries – to go the way of illiberal autocracy. It will be a fight between tolerance and racism, a fight of openness against protectionism, and a fight by all the – I should say – true Europeans against all the kinds of narrow-minded nationalists and populists that we have seen in the four corners of Europe. And I think that, just as it did in 1989, Romania will have an important role to play in winning the fight in 2019. This also gives me the opportunity to come back to the debate on the future of the Union. If there is one real reform to be made for the future of the European Union, Mr President, then it is to get rid of the unanimity rule in the European Union. Look again at the Khashoggi case that we have today. On Saturday all the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, together with Mogherini, produced what? A weak condemnation, a soft declaration instead of common action, which is impossible because of the unanimity rule in foreign affairs. What is needed is not a soft declaration or a weak condemnation; what is needed is a ban – a European ban – on exports of weapons to Saudi Arabia. That is what is needed and it can be achieved only... (Applause) ... and this is what I want to hear in this debate about the future of Europe – if we get rid of the unanimity rule, if we can get rid – and Romania is ready to do so – of this veto power, this veto right that all Member States still cherish, but which is in fact the real obstacle to a re-foundation of the European Union. And I’m pleased that Romania and the President will be on our side in this fight for that reform.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank President Juncker very much for joining this debate on the future of Europe. With the European elections getting close, it is even more important to discuss how that future should look – our common future. That is the question that we need to ask ourselves, but not just those of us in this room. Every citizen of Europe needs to ask themselves what kind of Europe they want to live in. Do we want a Europe where we fight for our common values, where we defend democracy, civil liberties and freedom, or do we let Europe go down a slippery slope of nationalism and governments that hollow out the key foundations of our Union and of democracy? Unfortunately, some governments seem to be going exactly in that way. How the situation looks in a Member State also defines what the European Union as such, and as a whole, looks like. Right now, when our common values are being trampled upon in many Member States, every voice that defends civil liberties and every voice that defends freedom and the rule of law counts, regardless of political affiliation. Therefore, President Juncker, we count on you! The Romanian people count on you! The Romanian people showed in a referendum two weeks ago that they do not want an authoritarian state that discriminates and that tries to play people off against one another. They also protested in their thousands against corruption. They protested against a government that de facto legalises corruption and does not even shy away from weakening a judiciary system to make it easier for some politicians to put public money – the money of all Romanians - into their own pockets. But, instead of listening, the Romanian Government sent tear gas against those people protesting. And now the Government even wants to replace a strong anti-corruption chief prosecutor with somebody who has, let us say, not such a strong record of working against corruption. This is a slap in the face for Romanian citizens. Mr President, it now depends on you to stop that. Mr President, we need you as a strong voice for democracy and the rule of law in Romania and throughout the European Union. Two weeks ago, the Constitutional Court of Romania declared over 60 articles of the new criminal procedure code unconstitutional. On Friday, the Venice Commission warned that the reform would jeopardise the fight against corruption and also against organised crime. Mr President, why don’t you take the lead and call on all political parties to put the recommendations of the Venice Commission into practice? Romania needs to start a broad reassessment of the law reform with all stakeholders involved. Since Romania will take over the presidency in a couple of months, it would be even more important to have a role model at the head of the Presidency for good governance to show how it can be done. Let us be courageous together and stand up for democracy and the rule of law, and let us not be intimidated by all of those who flagrantly undermine that very rule of law and our freedom.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, thank you, Mr Iohannis, for being here to exchange views with the European Parliament. Romania joined the European Union in 2007, and at that time a period of high hope and close ties between the Romanian people and the other countries of the European Union began. However, recent developments seem to show that the dignity of the Romanian people is putting the Government in check. We're talking about the future of Europe. I'd like to look back and remember that 2014 presidential campaign. At the time, Mr Iohannis, your party focused on fighting corruption and improving the judicial system. Anyone looking through a rearview mirror would be astonished at the decisions the government of their country is making in recent times. You have the prerogative to address your Parliament on matters of national interest, as well as to safeguard compliance with the Constitution and fundamental rights. And in this sense, he must be firm and clear in defending democracy and freedoms and not become complicit in the drift of his Government, which seems to be following in the style of others, such as Polish or Hungarian. We witness with surprise some democratic involutions typical of other times. Specifically, I'm going to mention three well-known cases. First, the referendum against same-sex marriages, convened by the far right and the Orthodox church, a referendum supported by the Romanian Government participating in a campaign of hatred and homophobia that has shown the most retrograde side of a social democratic government, which should embarrass the S&D Group here, Fortunately the citizens of Romania showed their dignity outright with such a high abstention that it even prevented them from succeeding. Second, in August thousands of his compatriots took to the streets against the government's current endemic corruption. Romanian citizenship resists attempts by today's rulers to control the judiciary to dilute the relative success of the fight against corruption. And thirdly, the reforms of the law regulating NGOs. The Council of Europe Conference of International NGOs noted that there are clear deficiencies with regard to compliance with international standards and good practices. From the GUE/NGL Group we would also like to ask the S&D Group about these three elements and their opinion, and we would like to encourage you, Mr Iohannis, to be firm; to stand firm in defending democracy and freedoms and in the fight against corruption; to listen to the voice of his people before other voices and not to continue this confrontation with the common sense that his government is carrying out. Luckily, the events of recent months realize that Romanian citizens know how to make themselves heard. From here we celebrate. We show our support for defending the rights and freedoms conquered with such suffering.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Iohannis, when I think of Romania, I am thinking of the many Romanians living in Italy, the many that I know and have met. In their stories there is the image of a great country, rich in beauties and traditions, but also of a country that has to deal with long-held problems, starting with that of corruption. We saw this this summer with the protests that flooded the streets of Bucharest. Do not be alarmed, Mr President, no one here wants to be a master, we all know that corruption is a phenomenon that affects the whole of Europe, no country excluded. It is estimated that its cost for the union as a whole is EUR 120 billion per year. It is clear to everyone that corruption destroys the economy and social justice, affecting citizens and businesses that operate honestly, punishing those who deserve and rewarding those who are friends of power. Corruption is the most serious theft that can be committed in a state because it steals the future. I understand them well, Mr President, because I too come from a land of emigration and corruption. For decades I have been told that there is little to be done against this, that it must be accepted because all politicians are equal, because that is politics, and public administration and the state will never change. But that's not the case! Politics, the good one, can and must combat corruption. What? With laws, such as the one we have just passed in Italy, increasing the penalties for corrupt and corrupting, protecting those who denounce and introducing a clear principle: those convicted of corruption can have nothing to do with the public administration, let alone receive public funds. These are measures and principles that should be applied at European level, such as whistler blower measures, which Parliament called for a year ago but which are a dead letter. And with regard to dead letters, since the subject is the future of Europe, it would be good if the European Union were to start thinking about guaranteeing a future for its citizens, instead of perched on the defence of failed rules. I am referring to what is happening in the last few hours with the decomposed attacks on the economic manoeuvre proposed by the Italian Government: we have seen European Commissioners who rejected the text before they even read it, calling for atrocious punishments on the part of the markets. There was even a Commissioner who, just after the elections, had already announced that high finance would change italians' minds about who to vote for. The truth is that austerity and its rules have failed. We were told that in order to reduce public debt, social spending and investment had to be cut. In Italy it has been done, but the public debt has remained almost unchanged. We have been told that with the accounts in order growth and employment would be shared, but the reality is that the economy has been stagnant for years, families are corroding their savings, businesses are failing and young people are emigrating. The government that my movement is part of, the 5 Star Movement, said enough. Austerity is killing the Eu ropean Union and the eurozone, if it wants to survive, needs new budgetary rules, but while waiting to change it, a state cannot hang itself and its citizens in compliance with the wrong constraints. Think of an institute, the German Institute for Economic Research, confirms the goodness of the Italian Government's manoeuvre. The institute's director says Italy's problem is not this year's deficit but its economic depression. Europe should admit that more public spending and more deficits are useful if you focus on growth and employment as absolute priorities. Are these also words of a dangerous populist? To those who claim that European standards are being violated, I would remind you that the change in parameters is perfectly compatible with European rules, because Italy is still in an exceptional situation to take into account: 17.5 million people at risk of poverty and social exclusion, 5 million absolute poor people are or are not a situation of real emergency? Economists think so. Strong support is therefore needed for the poorest workings for social stability and for reviving consumption. This is what we did with citizenship income, a measure that this Parliament supported only a year ago by a large majority vote on our resolution. The last six months, Mr President, of this parliamentary term will be the Romanian Presidency: be brave too! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, change is therefore possible. In Italy there is a government that is promoting it, they have understood it in Germany too, they understand it in Brussels, once and for all!

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by its operation, or rather its dysfunctions, but also and above all by its political orientations, the European Union not only does not secure the future of The European nations - this is the debate we are dealing with today - but it is in fact becoming, increasingly, an anti-Europe. Although they defend themselves, some are probably not dissatisfied with this development, since they have never sought to ensure continental independence and power. In reality, they see European integration as a simple step towards a global village and global governance. But for my part, I am convinced that there is still time to save Europe from the current excesses of the European Union. With our allies and the national forces that are advancing all over our continent, we want to build a Europe that lives up to the genius of our civilization and that once again allows our nations to shine throughout the world, to be strong and respected on the international stage, either individually or collectively. This Europe does not go through a European Commission that decides everything and nothing, both all-powerful and at the same time impotent. Unable, for example, to protect our companies from both Chinese dumping and the extra-territoriality of American law. I would also like to take this opportunity to point out that the European Union is always in a hurry to give rule of law lessons to Poland, Hungary or, tomorrow, to Romania, to give human rights lessons to Russia, but it is deafeningly silent about the barbaric murder of journalist Khashoggi on the orders of Riyadh in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. So yes, we must put an end to this above-ground bureaucracy without democratic legitimacy. The Commission claims to be transparent and independent in the decisions it takes on a daily basis, which affects more than 500 million Europeans. But it is in total opacity that it concludes all-round free trade treaties. These treaties organize unfair competition, causing the deindustrialization of our countries and the ruin of our agriculture, whether it is CETA, which is already in force but has not been ratified by national parliaments, the projects currently under discussion with Mercosur or with the countries of Oceania, or the agreement signed this summer by Jean-Claude Juncker in secret with Japan and , as recently as last Friday, with Singapore. Subject to the market, the Commission's Europe, is also the Europe of resignation because its leaders do not assume the functions and obey less the peoples than the unelected officials around them, as well as the judges of the European Court of Human Rights and the Court of Justice of the Union. We are regularly told about European protectionism, but in 1997 the Treaty of Amsterdam repealed Article 44, paragraph 2, of the Treaty of Rome, which provided for the development of a natural preference between the Member States. And the European Court of Justice rejected some of the few anti-dumping measures taken by the Commission at the time. This is what the French essayist Éric Zemmour called "the coup d'etat of the judges". Indeed, since the 1970s, political power has gradually been stripped of its prerogatives by the judiciary, first at the national level and now at the European level. Thus, beyond our sovereignty, it is democracy and its foundations that are at risk. Nor can we claim European solidarity with a punitive Commission which seeks to sanction Member States that do not submit to its ideology, in particular on migration, which we would now like to make a new human right. We need real cooperation on major challenges such as the protection of external borders or energy and environmental issues. Of course not! we cannot pretend to want to preserve our ecosystem, while constantly encouraging unbridled transcontinental free trade, which is by nature profoundly anti-ecological. That is why it is time to re-found the European construction and reorient it, far from utopias and dogmas.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (NI).
text: – Mr President, in such a complicated context for Romania, internally and externally, but equally complicated for the European Union, your message today is an optimistic message, a message of stability, a breath of oxygen, if you will, for the European debate these days. I agree that a recalibration of the European project is needed. After more than ten years of tensions, failures, crises one after another, we need to show European citizens that we have learned from these mistakes, that we have learned our lessons and that we can enter a new European chapter that is much more determined, much better prepared, much more adapted to the realities of each member country. I want to thank you for reminding you of the more than a hundred thousand exceptional young people in Romania who work in the IT industry, who are developing blockchain projects, using modern technologies. Not coincidentally, these days the first political project on blockchain, the first blockchain party in Europe, was launched in Romania. I have high hopes for a digitalised Europe, because through digitalisation we can fight corruption and poverty. Finally, I want to thank you for reminding you not only of the unity of the European Union, not only of the importance of this unity, but moreover of 'unity in diversity'. The fact that you have returned to the primordial belief of the European Union, that we are united stronger, but united in our diversity, preserving national specificity, preserving our national values.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would remind all my fellow Members that today's debate is on the future of Europe, it is not a debate on the situation in Romania, since we had it at the last part-session.

name: Klaus Iohannis
text: President of Romania. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, first of all, let me thank all the speakers, from the President of the Commission to those who have spoken on behalf of the political groups. You have touched on several topics, of which the one who is dearest to me - my country, Romania. In December 1989, we Romanians decided that we could no longer bear the communist dictatorship and removed it. Since then, we have been building a democracy that we Romanians want based on what is called the values of European democracy, the values of the European Union. In these nearly 30 years Romania has changed. Romania has changed profoundly. We are an Eastern European country that still believes in European-type democracy. Romania is a country with a growing economy. Romania is a country that represents a pole of stability in the geographical region where we find ourselves. Romania is a country that aspires to leadership in areas such as those I mentioned in the first part of my speech. Romania is a country appreciated and respected for the security it delivers to the region and NATO and elsewhere. We Romanians have long understood that we cannot remain aid and security receivers, but we must take a much harder role, but in which we believe - that of a security provider - and that is what we do. Romania is a rule of law. Romania is a democratic state. In Romania there is a political debate and in Romania there is what we have called "a very living democracy". I do not want to go into the details of the internal debate in Romania, but I can assure you that I am determined to remain involved in order to guarantee Romanians the preservation of democratic values, the preservation of the rules and principles of a rule of law and the continuation of a very tough, but just fight against corruption. (Strong applause) I think we have more problems in Europe. One of them is the connection between citizen and politician. Often this connection is a weak one, citizens do not understand what politicians are doing and unfortunately some politicians do not understand what citizens want. In Romania the citizens have made it clear what they want, and I - who have been chosen by a significant number of Romanians - have understood that they want to continue this message with which I have begun, for a democratic Romania, for a European Romania, a Romania deeply integrated into the European Union, a Romania that keeps the rule of law intact and that fights - and I must say , with notable results - against corruption. That there is controversy is true, but tell me what parliamentary democracy would that be without controversy? And I am determined that from this fight will win European Romania, democratic Romania and I will get involved in this. We talked in the first part of our meeting about how I see the future of the European Union. Several positions were more about the near future of the European Union, and then let me also say a few words about how we see it in Romania, how I see the european Union's near future, and I am referring to the first part of 2019, when Romania will hold the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. We have an extremely difficult time ahead of us. We have extremely difficult dossiers, which we want to deal with in a fair way, but also with great determination, towards a positive or optimistic result. It won't always be possible. One of the dossiers is called Brexit and here, certainly, things are still in a phase that depends very much on the negotiation that is being conducted, but we want to reach an agreement with the UK and we want to have this deal very quickly. Romania will be involved as much as the Presidency of the Council can be involved in this. And let me say that here we have, in terms of negotiating Brexit, a first tangible, clear and transparent evidence of the effectiveness of collaboration. The fact that the 27 worked strictly together, accepted only one negotiating team, brought notable results. Here is that unity is not a concept of the day," but for unity, but for unity. We have a dossier that I know you discussed in Parliament and which is dear to you and dear to us, it is the multiannual financial framework. We need to make progress on this file. The fact that you, in Parliament, are encouraging us in the Council to move towards an increase in the budget is, in Romania's view, a good thing, but the negotiation will have to continue practically - and here Romania will get involved and we hope to have, if not the completion of the negotiations, at least significant progress in sensitive areas on this budget. A dossier that has also been mentioned by me and some speakers: migration. We need to get to a common approach as quickly as possible. If we fail to define a European policy in this area, then we will have a major problem. And Romania will be involved in making progress in negotiations. At the moment, you know very well, as far as the Dublin reform is concerned, we have 28 views from 28, very different countries. I believe that we can bring these opinions closer together and reach the first common conclusions which, then, allow us to treat this phenomenon on several levels, a treatment that will fundamentally differ from the way we have acted so far. So far we have acted in the wake of a crisis; we must act before a crisis - that is what I meant when I said that the European Union must act preventively. We know how the world works, but we also have to prepare, to cope with the effects of this function. And finally, during the Romanian Presidency, the European elections will take place and during the campaign for the European elections we will have the Summit in Sibiu. This summit is extremely important for Romania and for the European Union and not necessarily because it is my hometown, but because that summit has the unique and clear theme - the future of the European Union. We will discuss and draw up a clear, clear, understandable thinking about the European Union for the European citizen, not just the European politician. And next year's elections to the European Parliament will give us an X-ray, show us whether we have all been credible, whether we have known how to generate credible projects, whether we know how to draw a future for the European Union, or whether we still have a bit of work to do. Thank. (Applause)

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, President, we welcome you in the European Parliament. As you all know, Romania will hold the Presidency of the Council of the European Union for the first time in the first half of next year. The agenda is really tight. A tight agenda awaits, because the official european parliamentary election campaign will begin at the end of April. It is therefore particularly important to make decisions to reach agreements before its inception, on which the future of the European Union as a whole will depend. I mean the new financial perspective. The European Parliament is very visible about what is happening in Romania. We have seen hundreds of thousands of your citizens taking to the streets with a very clear message of stopping corruption. Our support is for all those who are fighting for the rule of law and who are opposed to the legalisation of corruption. It is not only the future of your country that will win this fight, but we are all connected in the European Union. Your position is therefore particularly important. I wish you courage and stamina on this difficult road. Thanks.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I thank the President of Romania here today with us and I would like to make two statements of interest: the first that only out of mere intellectual dishonesty can anyone compare the situation of Romania with Hungary or Poland and the second is that I have a nephew studying in Romania. Romania does indeed have a complex semi-presidential system, a complex constitution too, and I have two very specific questions to ask it, Mr President.  Firstly, what role has the President played in improving the democratic system and the separation of powers and how this will be visible during the Romanian Presidency, that is, respect for the rule of law and the fight against corruption, which are not only a plan of his country, but of the whole European Union. The second question concerns what I have already said about the Multiannual Financial Framework and, because we also have the Commissioner for Regional Development here, I would like to ask you whether Romania is prepared to actually, in the first half of 2019, have an agreement on the regulation of cohesion policy, that is, what political strategy it has, is drawn or whether it is already designed and whether we can know what it is about.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, I would like to pay great tribute to Romania as a country that is crucial to our security in a region as sensitive as the Black Sea basin. We are working with many colleagues, here in this House or in committees, who make a very real contribution to our common position and to the concern that we strengthen each other's independence. You have said very valuable words about the fact that we should not duplicate Europe's security structures. Three quarters of our countries are allied in the Atlantic alliance and the common security policy should consist primarily of solidarity within NATO, in presenting a common position. It is a pity that Mr Verhofstadt came out again. He said here that we must move away from the European Treaties, abolish the unanimity principle. If he loves the majority so much, let his country join the diplomatic response to the Skripala case. Because Romania has demonstrated solidarity; Mr Verhofstadt's homeland – unfortunately not.

name: Renate Weber (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, you have spoken very highly of the European Union, and I am glad, because I am a great supporter of the European project. But speaking of accountability, you failed to mention the abuses committed during your term of office in the name of a fair cause that must continue - the fight against corruption - but which, unfortunately, has often been used for power games. During your term of office, a new secret protocol was signed between the Romanian Intelligence Service and the Prosecutor General's Office, whereby prosecutors became the subject of the Intelligence Service, being obliged to report developments in their investigations. A consequence of these secret protocols was the situation of dozens of prosecutors and judges, including from the Constitutional Court, accused of non-existent acts, harassed for years, and finally acquitted. This affected the independence of the magistrates. Take this responsibility, Mr President, to make sure that the abuses do not happen again.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, President Iohannis,  you have said that all citizens should feel heard and welcome in the European Union and that they should enjoy freedom of movement, and I am sure that this also means that minorities should feel heard and at home inside the European Union. You also said that we should not have a Europe of several paces and that there should not be too big a difference between Member States. Romania is one of the few countries in the European Union where  we still don’t have any legislation on civil partnership or same-sex legislation. A couple of weeks ago there was even a referendum which sometimes consisted of homophobic rhetoric. My question now to you is: what can you do in order to push Romania to adopt legislation in this field, and what will the Romanian Presidency do in order to make sure that LGBTIs will also feel at home and heard inside the European Union?

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the Romanian Government, about a year ago, decided to abolish employer contributions and to transfer the cost of contributions only to workers. In return, he called on companies to proceed with wage increases. Mr President of Romania, I would ask you to tell us whether this unprecedented insurance reform has had the slightest benefit for workers, whether companies have finally made similar increases or whether workers have gone even further. I would ask you to reply to me, so that we know or whether you will work for a Europe of social protection and fair distribution of insurance burdens.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Greetings, President Iohannis, it is good that you are here today.  It is a pity that so few Colleagues are present. It would have been important to pay attention through their presence and interest, especially in the difficult democratic political situation. In many areas, Mr President, I have been able to follow what you have said, to understand them, although you have remained a bit general. You have tried to achieve EU standards: consolidation, cohesion, the famous European values. However, I think it is important to go into a little bit of detail, and I do not see your clear statements on the rule of law, independent courts and, above all, corruption-free politics and administration, as Mr Juncker has also mentioned. Personally, as an old Austrian, I wish you all the best for the future and, of course, the Member State of Romania for the challenge of the first Presidency of the Council of political consolidation.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have a clear question for you. I missed in your speech that you were commenting on what happened on your soil when American secret aircraft landed in Bucharest, Romania. There have been tortures, interrogations, murders and abductions. You are talking about a continuation of the transatlantic alliance. Is it what you mean by the transatlantic alliance that you continue to approve that an unspaced power like the United States of America is operating torturers and torture prisons on European soil? I also have a question: how do you intend to deal with the infringement proceedings already initiated against Poland and Hungary? And similar debate is also being held against Romania. When we talk about the future of Europe, we must of course also talk about the diversity of the peoples of Europe; that is what you have done today. But we are not talking about the diversity of a multicultural, multiracial society, but we are promoting the struggle, the competition between peoples, and we do not want to bring millions of foreigners to Europe. How do you feel about this?

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean (PPE).
text: – Mr President, President Iohannis, I appreciate the way Romania, through you, looks at the future of Europe. The pro-European voice of the East, which you represent, is extremely important at this time when confidence in the European project needs to be rebuilt. I believe, like you, that the two-speed Europe is extremely dangerous and can create faultlines within the Union that will be difficult to repair. I also believe that the success of the European Union depends on the success of each of the Member States, and Romania must do more and better to contribute to the strengthening and future of the European project. In this context, I think it would be interesting for us if you could tell us some of the internal priorities that Romania has in order to recover from the gaps with the other Member States and contribute, by itself, to the future of the Union.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, President Iohannis, welcome to the European Parliament! You have not spoken ill - here, before we are members of a political party, we are the citizens of a country - and I congratulate you on the pro-European approach that you have put forward - all Romanians are pro-Europeans, they are good Europeans - but I want to ask you the following question. I know that, for the institutional memory of Bucharest, the Republic of Moldova is the second Romanian state. You talked about national priorities, you talked about the future of Europe and you did not mention the Republic of Moldova. My question - I hope it doesn't sound dramatic, but I'm asking you - have you abandoned the Republic of Moldova? Because in the last four years of your mandate you have only been to Chisinau once.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: "Mr President, I sincerely commend you for taking a stand against illegal migration and trafficking in human beings at last week's EU summit in Brussels, and at home you have taken decisive action against corruption and defending the rule of law in Romania. For the future of Europe, I call on you to work with Hungary and the Visegrad Four to defend European values, our European Christian identity, the sovereignty of our nations. As a Transylvanian Hungarian, I ask you, as my German-Saxon compatriot, to defend the rule of law not only against corruption, but also against nationalist-communist anti-Hungarianism, so that we too do not end up in the fate of the run-out Saxons of Transylvania, who were driven from their homeland by the Ceausescu dictatorship.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am determined to defend my country, I am a great supporter of the European project. You talked about unity and cohesion, you took inspiration from President Juncker's speech - Europe with two lungs, eastern and western Europe, one heart - you talked about honour. Honour is that you represent a wonderful country like Romania, President Iohannis, but you have in the country a completely different language, you instigate division, your duplicitous language has divided the country in two, instigates hatred between liberals and social democrats, has created a rift between generations, between Romanians with different political options. Here, in the plenary of the European Parliament, and a few days ago in Italy you praised the achievements of the Romanian government. Why don't you do the same in Romania when you get home? Where is the unity for Romania, President Iohannis, in the context of you dividing, destabilising Romania?

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – The President of Romania said today that the European Union needs a vision to consolidate, he said, a genuine union that looks to the future. The question, however, is what a real union is. Many European leaders have outlined different visions from the President's vision, and you have also been presented with several scenarios by the Head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, who also encouraged them to be discussed in Member States, in different environments. I would like to say that such citizens' discussions, initiatives are already being created in Poland and Lithuania. The Europa Christi movement has been in operation for two years, which clearly defines its expectations for the future functioning of the European Union, the real union that the President has spoken about. Firstly, a return to fundamental values, namely Christianity, to which reference should be made in eu base documents. The protection of human life from conception to natural death must be a sine qua non, and the protection of the traditional family model must be guaranteed in Union documents. I would be grateful to take this into account.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Welcome, President Iohannis. I have been to Romania five times since autumn 2014 to talk to animal rights activists and politicians, including then Prime Minister Ciolos, about the horrific mass killings of stray dogs and the background to them. The population was manipulated by politicians and the media in 2013 to justify the dog massacre, which became a lucrative business in which corrupt authorities and politicians still earn. Before your election, Mr President, you spoke out against the mass killings and described them as barbaric. That's why you chose many Romanians. But stray dogs are still captured and brutally killed every day. Finally, make your political use of your political influence for humane and modern population management, taking into account that animals are sentient beings, as stated in Article 13 of the Treaty of Lisbon! What has happened and is happening in Romania, despite worldwide protests with the stray dogs, is a disgrace and has nothing to do with our civilisational values in Europe. Mr President, there is simply no place in our Europe for the mass killing of stray dogs. So, once Romania has taken over the Presidency of the Council, it can show whether it cares about all values – and animal welfare is definitely a European value.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, President Iohannis, welcome here to the plenary of the European Parliament. Speaking of the future of the European Union, you have placed a particular emphasis on security and prosperity. And I believe that these two components are very important, because in the coming years we, the European Union, must deliver exactly what citizens expect of us - and I think people expect, first and foremost, safety and prosperity. We must be aware that we are living in a changing world, and the pace of change will accelerate in the coming years. In the coming years, European citizens will consume new categories of products, services, new trades will emerge and many of the trades we have done so far will disappear. That is why I believe that the following four elements are essential for prosperity in Europe in the future: education, innovation, youth and digitalisation. We must prepare young Europeans to work side by side - young Romanians, alongside young Portuguese, Irish, Swedes and Estonians - and we must tell young people that in Europe, in the future, isolation is not a solution. Euroscepticism, anti-European policies are not a solution, Europe is our home. By building Europe, we are building our future and Europe will bring prosperity.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is rare in this House for most voices in Romania to express consensus around a central idea - that of our country's place and role in the European Union. That is why I am just saying that I am saying that this debate should continue at home because, yes, and for colleagues in the European Parliament, it is necessary to say - Romania does not see its place outside the European project and the NATO alliance, and this is a historical fact, which is shared by the political elites , by the country's intellectuals, by the economic elites. I have two questions for you, both of which will have the outcome at the Sibiu summit. Brexit - that's where the deal will be accepted. But how does your country and my country see future relations with the UK? And two, about the future of the defence union - European defence - how should this new European policy in which our country has enormous interests evolve from the perspective of our country and what will be the future of the defence union with the NATO alliance?

name: Romeo Franz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much, President Iohannis. We are very concerned about the situation of the Roma in Romania: exclusion, segregation, exploitation. Equal participation is not given to a large proportion of your Roma citizens, and human rights are also being massively violated here – including children's rights. The situation of these people is partly dehumanised. What do you want to do about it, and what do you want to do for inclusion?  I'm about to go to Tinca, which is a small town in your country. There are major incidents involving these human rights violations. I would like to inform you about this.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: –Mr President, President Iohannis, it is a joy to have here in the European Parliament a voice from Romania that defends the Union and thinks about its future. Unfortunately, three weeks ago I had another voice from Romania, that of the head of government, who attacked the institutions and who openly showed that he did not want to cooperate with the European institutions. You are right when you say that the Union should not leave any Member State behind, but I think it is just as true to say that the governments of the Member States need not to forget Europe, not to leave it behind. And unfortunately, what has been happening in Romania for two years now is precisely this - Europe is forgotten. I do not know of any government of the many teams proposed by the PSD-ALDE that will ever be defended by the European Union, which has talked about what Europe actually means. None, there's a minister who's done that. You say it will be a fruitful presidency. I'm afraid it won't be. With whom should we defend Europe, Mr President? With Daea? With Andrusca? With Olguța? Cu Tudorel Toader? Do you see them presiening any meeting of their counterparts? No way, Mister President. I am sorry that Mr Verhofstadt left because I would have told him that in Romania the corrupt safeists are defending the independence of the judiciary by talking about secret services. That's the reality, it's not a liberal point of view. And Mr Verhofstadt told us that in 1990 he gave a radio in Romania - he gave it to Calin Popescu-Tariceanu, he forgot to mention the owner. And to this day, he holds Tariceanu in his arms, no matter what he does. Shame on the liberal family, shame on the socialist family, they both hold in their arms corrupt!

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is not really a debate to talk about what is happening in your country: it is a debate to talk about the future of the European Union. That is what I would like to talk to you about, Mr President, because in the next period you are going to preside over it and, at the beginning of this mandate, we had set ourselves a target, which is for the weight of industry to reach 20% of our gross domestic product and, unfortunately, we are seeing how industries – especially steelmaking and aluminium – are closing day yes and day also in the whole of the European Union. Our industrial weight is diminishing and, despite some measures taken by the Commission, they do not come to a close of unfair trade practices and dumping in countries such as China.  That is why I am going to invite you, Mr President, to push a genuine European industrial policy together with the remaining presidents of governments. This is the future of Europe: to have more weight, and to avoid closures like the ones that are currently happening in our country in the aluminium sector.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: "Dear Mr. President, We want a Europe where, I quote you, 'nu lasă în urmă niciun cetăţean european'. Romania is a member of this Europe, and so are minorities in Romania. I hope you do not say that the protection of minorities in Romania is exemplary, because you were the one who tried to revoke existing minority rights in the defence of the administrative law in the Constitutional Court. Europe, as you said , is 'unitar și indivizibil', that is to say, this is also described in the Constitution, as we hear a lot at home, but attempts such as yours share Romanian society, where minorities are considered second-class citizens. We're both minorities, you're German, I'm Hungarian. Perhaps the most loyal citizens of Europe and Romania, because we have remained in our place despite all attempts to merge. Do your best so that in 2020, when Romania is 100 years old, no of its citizens will feel second-class. Respect and respect the rights of minorities to their mother tongue, symbols, property, homeland.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at this very important time for the future of the European Union and where we are talking about its unity, I ask you that, as President of the sixth largest and most important State in the European Union after the exit of Great Britain and a state that has remarkable economic growth and which can be considered a true regional leader of Europe , strongly request that by the end of the mandate of these European institutions - that by May 2019 - Romania become an integral part of the Schengen area. I am aware that you mentioned this in your speech, but I ask you, as Romania's representative in the European Council, to resolve this injustice for Romania, because there we have a situation of deadlock and ill will. Also, Mr President, democracy is ensured by respecting fundamental rights and freedoms, the presumption of innocence, respect for the decisions of the Constitutional Court and without the citizens of our country being misused by the secret services through protocols. You had a constructive message today, but let us have the same constructive attitude in our country. Let us together protect all Romanians, and enjoy the same fundamental rights and freedoms as European citizens.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, you must note that This is what Romania looks like, this is what it thinks, this is how it positions itself to and from the European Union, as President Klaus Werner Iohannis has said today. He is the only man, the only Romanian mandated by Romanian citizens to represent them, by a massive and legitimate vote of more than 50% given in 2014. Anyone but the President of Romania is arrogating this right is an impostor and should not be taken seriously, no matter what it is called. For example, those who govern Romania today have been voted on by only 18% of the total number of citizens entitled to vote and do not have the moral of this right.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, President Iohannis, I must admit, and I appreciate your speech and thank you for it, and I can say that I also agree with my colleagues who say that we would like this speech at home and i read you an article of the Romanian Constitution, "The President of Romania ensures that the Constitution is respecting and the proper functioning of public authorities.
