To that end, the President shall exercise the function of mediation between the powers of the State and between the State and society.' We'll think about what this article means when we get home. With regard to the European Union, Romanians are discriminated against in at least three reports that I am working on in the Committee on Civil Liberties. One is Schengen and on time I would like you to tell us under what conditions would you accept a two-stage entry into Schengen for Romania, even though we have been meeting all the conditions since 2011? The second report is CVM. Are you or are you not for removing the CVM? The third report concerns visas that are still needed for Romanian citizens to go to the US. We are discriminated against from this point of view, and the European Commission forgets to act, so it is basically in breach of European law. The fourth file is from the Committee on Labour and Social Affairs. When we talk about social dumping - and we had a vote in the European Parliament against social dumping - we must also talk about social dumping with regard to Romanians working in multinational factories in Romania and getting somewhere at 10% of what workers who do the same work in the country where these multinationals come from.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr President, thank you for your clear words about a common and united European future. You have already mentioned that you expect a unified approach to Brexit, a single procedure for the Multiannual Financial Framework. I am interested in how you see a solution in the case of your Presidency if it has to complete the negotiations on the asylum system, and you are also waiting for the completion of the negotiations on the mobility package on social security for drivers. This is a subject which, of course, also affects Romanian workers and entrepreneurs very much.  I very much wish that young people would not have to leave East to West, from Romania to the West, from the Czech Republic to the West. I very much wish that they would feel safe in our countries to see their future here. Unfortunately, your Prime Minister has not allayed our concerns about developments in Romania and we have high hopes for you.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr President of Romania, you have spoken about the need for unity and inclusion in the European Union. At the same time, the multiannual financial framework. However, if you look at it, there are large decreases in funds for cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy. How will you act in such a way that Romania's level of development and the standard of living of Romanian citizens are close to that of the old members of the European Union? At the same time, Mr President, I want to tell you that we, all Romanian citizens, have been waiting for 28 years for a president of all Romanians, a moderator president, a facilitating president, a president balanced by all citizens, regardless of their political choice. At the same time, Mr President, we have seen that in your programme today in the European Parliament you have not included a meeting with all Romanian MEPs. Mr President, we are the representatives of the Romanian citizens in the European Parliament, and such a meeting would have been beneficial for us and for you.

name: Klaus Iohannis
text: President of Romania. – Mr President, thank you to all the speakers for their positions. There were numerous, I wish there were more numerous. Thank you to those who have found words of appreciation for Romania, and thank you to those who have found words of constructive criticism, because otherwise impic criticism I do not imagine that it can be done in the European Parliament. "Unity in Diversity", this was the concept with which I concluded my first presentation and the positions in this room show, indeed, that this is where we need to work. Very different approaches, but obviously each with its weight and parliamentary representativeness. Let me propose to you a way by which I can interact with you, those who have spoken, and perhaps with others who have not yet done so. Given the diversity of themes - and I assure you that they are all important, I am interested and we have firm positions on all - I cannot go into all the details and all the answers. Together with my colleagues and colleagues, we will ensure that every speaker receives a written response, and I believe that this will improve the dialogue between us. Once again, thanks for taking your position. Let me conclude, Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, to return to a few key words, because today we are talking about how we will shape the future of the European Union - unity and cohesion, closeness to the citizen, the internal security of the European Union, the security of the borders of the European Union, weight in the european Union's international policy, approaches that respect and cultivate diversity, but allow for unity on the outside - these are the themes that concern us all , themes that concern Europeans. I believe that it is our obligation to find not only answers, but to find policies and to apply practically what we believe is important for our citizens, but in the same way for the European Union. Thank you all. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you once again, Mr President, for accepting our invitation and for taking part in a heated debate on the future of Europe, not even refusing to listen and answer questions concerning your country. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. In my view, it is important that we understand Europe as a whole again and do not divide it into small groups. We are all Europe. I am pleased that President Iohannis has highlighted this point. We are not Western or Eastern Europe, Visegrad or Club Med countries, but a Europe. And as Europe, it is also our task to draw attention to and to address abuses in our Member States. Romania has shown a great deal of will to reform since joining the EU and has achieved a great deal. However, there are still many problems that need to be tackled. Regressions in the rule of law are unacceptable, such as systematic corruption. I wish Mr Iohannis much strength and courage to combat these problems.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today we should have debated an important theme - the future of Europe. Unfortunately, we have witnessed many speeches with direct attacks on Romania in the presence of the President of Romania. The theme was not Romania, even though it is a Member State of the European Union. That is why I would like to ask the President of Romania whether, as a representative of the Council, He will argue that Romania and its citizens should be treated equally by waiving the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism and establishing a mechanism for the supervision of all States, given that, lo and behold, it is found that the great corruption is in other states, as the recent corruption scandal in 9 Member States shows. I would also like President Iohannis to tell us whether he will agree to the new conditionality for the allocation of European funds, namely the functioning of the rule of law. Last but not least, because we are talking about the future of Europe, I ask you, Mr President, whether you support a law of magistrates' liability in Romania and in the Union, given the huge sums paid from national budgets to citizens wronged by prosecutors, a chapter to which Romania is champions?

name: President. –
text: I just want to make a small personal announcement. The gavel I am using was produced by the Men’s Sheds in Ireland – they were one of the winners of the European Citizen’s Prize. I thought it might be a nice touch for me to use this to call order today, and I in particular mention the Drogheda Men’s Sheds in Ireland. (Applause) It’s one of the privileges of this job, but let’s see how the votes go!

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Emilian Pavel
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, a brief remark about three of these six states - I have not forgotten and I want to say this in front of all my colleagues - that Saint Kitts and Nevis, the Bahamas and Mauritius are tax havens, but we cannot punish the citizens of these states. We will have to work together to find other ways to prevent the money from leaking that must remain in the European Union, in these states, and I invite you to do so together.

name: Michel Dantin
text: Rapporteur. Madam Vice-President, in accordance with the rules of our Assembly, I formally request that the report be referred to committee and that it be the basis of inter-institutional negotiations.

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: on behalf of the rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The rapporteur, Mrs Vélean, cannot be here and has asked me, on her behalf, to ask that we refer the report back to committee so that we can negotiate with the Council. Now some lawyers are saying that I should do so on behalf of the group. I am happy to do so on behalf of the group. The main thing is that we can negotiate with the Council.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Rory Palmer
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I think when many of us turn on the taps in our homes or our workplaces we will take it for granted that the water in our glass will be clean, safe and of sufficient quality to drink, and Parliament has today gone some way to ensuring that remains the case. We’ve taken important steps on endocrine disruptors, on Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and on microplastics in our water. We are responding to the concerns of citizens on the safety and quality of our drinking water. I want to turn though to those people who do not have a tap to turn on, those who are homeless, who live in the makeshift refugee camps we see in European cities. Parliament today could and should have gone much further on the right to water. We have missed an opportunity today to respond in full to those 1.8 million EU citizens who signed the European Citizens’ Initiative on the right to water. Those in this House, who chose not to respond positively to that call from our citizens will have to answer to them next year in the elections. Finally, I want to turn to the issue of water leakage. Leaking water from our pipes, from our networks is not just bad for the environment, it isn’t just wasteful, it means water bills are higher for customers. I particularly want to mention the campaign by the GMB trade union in the UK, the Take Back the Tap campaign, which is seeking to get water back in public hands, and properly accountable to the public. 2.4 billion litres of water wasted every single day in the UK by the privatised water companies, 432 million litres a day leaking from the Severn Trent network in my region and at the same time, those companies in the last five years have paid out GBP 6.5 billion in shareholder dividends. We all have a right to clean, safe drinking water and those water suppliers should be acting in the public interest, not in the interests of bonanza shareholder dividends.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: –Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution because of the urgency of setting minimum parameters for water quality in the Union and for ensuring that all citizens of European territory have access to this fundamental good.  Access to drinking water must be considered a fundamental human right. Precisely because it is essential to human health, water cannot be a slave to the distribution business. As a public good, I advocate quality standards and waste prevention that are only achievable through the ethical exploitation of water. It is these values that should be promoted when we talk about the efficiency of distribution systems.  Furthermore, in 2010, the United Nations enshrined water as a human right, alongside sanitation, and that access to drinking water should therefore not be conditioned by the lack of economic resources of the end-user.  That is why I voted in favour of making drinking water points available in public places of controlled quality, as they already exist in many Member States on a voluntary basis, in the desire that it should also become a rule for the whole Of the European Union.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, 1.2 million bathtubs’ worth. That’s how much water Anglian Water wastes every single day through leaks. Yet the privatised water company showered their shareholders with a total of GBP 320 million last year. It’s another 1.2 million bathtubs’ worth for Affinity Water, 453 000 for Essex and Suffolk Water and 93 000 for Cambridge Water. All wasted.  It’s time for change. We need a water industry that works for everyone and England’s water needs to be in the hands of the public. After all, water is vital for life and about as natural a monopoly as you can find. Where’s the need for a market? When you run the bath, the choice is hot or cold, not Anglia Water or Thames Water. As this report rightly says, leakage rates need to fall, and that is why I am proud to back the GMB’s campaign. It’s time to take back the tap.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it is indeed remarkable how many EU citizens participated in the Right2Water initiative which gave birth to this European Parliament resolution. Therefore, I have strongly supported this proposal to revise the EU’s Drinking Water Directive. Having access to high quality drinkable water is essential for people’s health and the quality of their daily life. The proposal aims to adjust the Directive so we can better address new challenges such as climate change and adapt the rules to the new scientific environment and circular economy. In addition, with this proposal we aim at more ambitious water quality standards for human consumption.  I hope that as soon as such standards are set in place the Member States, including mine, Lithuania, will do their best to achieve them; for example, by providing more public drinking-water fountains and improving water infrastructure. We have to ensure safe, affordable and high quality water for our citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, water is a social good, it is essential for life and health. That is why the citizens' water initiative has gathered over 2 million signatures. Everyone requires quality water, clean water, water accessible to all, universal access to water. This means, of course, that the price of water must be accessible to all and there must be special tariffs for vulnerable social groups, such as the unemployed, to have zero value added tax on social services for water supply, to prohibit the interruption of water supply in the event of debts from sensitive social groups, such as pensioners, to have the overdue debts of the unemployed erased. Water is, of course, supplied by the State and not by private structures. At the same time, there should be no sale of EYDAP and EYATH in Greece, since they have joined the super fund.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we would have expected a bolder text from this House, and that is why I abstained on this vote. We would have expected more courage in following up the Right2Water initiative and, in particular, more courage in expressing zero tolerance towards PFAS substances that poison the blood and lives of thousands of people in the Veneto region. We have been listening to the 'NO PFAS' mothers and their concerns in recent days, but we have also listened to those who have brought us medical studies that testify to how these bioaccumulable substances, both short-chain and long-chain, have the power to poison people's health. In a European Union where the precautionary principle applies, we would have consistently expected a total ban and zero tolerance towards PFAS substances.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this draft report and would like to comment on this subject. I think we are all aware of how crucial this area is to the future development of the European community. It is indeed the primary source, water is the primary source for our lives, which is also an important part of the daily life of each of the Europeans. The people of Europe do not yet feel that they are personally concerned with problems with the availability or quality of drinking water. By availability I mean both the physical availability of this commodity and, of course, affordability. However, this does not mean that we should not take new steps in this area to improve the current situation. Access to drinking water and its quality are the primary interests of the EU, yet I think we should be very careful in creating new legislative measures. In this area, we must not forget to respect the principle of subsidiarity. Water resources should be primarily managed and treated by individual Member States. I supported this report, I also supported certain measures that embodied the role of municipalities and towns.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we need to be ambitious when it comes to our water quality and water supply. That’s why I abstained on this because this report, this was not ambitious enough. The reason why I say it wasn’t ambitious enough is because it went below the minimum standard. The idea that it would be acceptable to people in here that you can go in and cut off the water supply to a house with children in it, if that’s a minimum for you well I can’t go along with that. But then again it can’t be a surprise, because we have a Commissioner for Agriculture who is actually here because of what he said on this issue in Ireland. He said that if people didn’t pay their water bills, no matter how much they needed it, their water would be cut down to a trickle. His punishment was to be thrown out of Irish politics, but in the bizarre world of European politics his reward was to get that job here. But let there be a warning to people here: you need to be more ambitious than you were today. The idea that you can cut off someone’s water supply when they need it for their bottle to feed them and to quench their thirst … you cause major problems for them, and this is what you will do by voting for what you did today. That’s not ambitious enough for me. Is it too much to ask?

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, yet again I find myself asking, to what problem is this legislative proposal the solution? Clean water and its spread has been one of the miracles of our lifetime, not only in Europe but world-wide. One of the extraordinary and unreported wonders is the number of people who are no longer subject to water-borne diseases. But it is not a problem in the European Union and if it were, there are ample national regulations and laws and legal remedies open for an individual who has been injured without needing additional regulation. Smuggled into this report is something quite different as well. The proposal that restaurants should all have to supply free water on demand. Now again, I think this is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of how the private sector operates and what free contract is. Nobody has to eat in a restaurant, and if they choose to it’s surely up to the restaurateur to offer whatever terms he wanted. You’ve got to ask, is there any crevice, is there any nook or cranny of national life so small that Brussels doesn’t seek to thrust its stubby fingers into it?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, this is the first citizens' initiative since the Lisbon Treaty to actually succeed, which has gathered more than 1 800 000 signatures and which we have taken seriously as Parliament into consideration. I am pleased that today Parliament voted overwhelmingly in the right to water. I am convinced that every citizen should be entitled to quality water and I believe that these negotiations will end as soon as possible, that member states will agree and that every citizen will be entitled to clean, drinking and quality water. I believe this is the smallest standard we can afford for our Citizens of the European Union. When it comes to Croatia, we are the third country in terms of water wealth in the European Union and I am sure that my state of Croatia and its authorities will allow our citizens to have access to water, because I believe that this is primarily a civil right and I agree that the United Nations has declared the right to water a civil or human right.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, we must ensure basic labour rights, because I think that is the key element in the modern era, especially in the countries of the European South, especially in Greece, where the payment of wages is no longer even guaranteed, because we have too many employers who do not pay their workers. At the same time, these employers often force them to pay in kind. Moreover, these employers do not even pay the insurance contributions.  One realizes that the exploitation of workers continues, especially in times of crisis, with the Chineseization of wages that has taken place in the Greek economy, with daily interventions in their trade union rights and, at the same time, the reduction of wages, as we have thousands of illegal immigrants, who act as a reserve army to reduce workers' wages. So we must have concrete measures to protect workers' rights.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This report is a steak of nonsense, inducement and some such socialist whining, meddling in their own affairs at all. The very list of those institutions that have been set up and which are mentioned is impressive: the Europe 2020 strategy, the European Social Fund, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions, Creative Europe, etc. Mother of God! What we have here is already full communism in the onslaught. We try to manage every area of life with 100,000 different agencies that no one is in control of anymore, and no one has any more knowledge of what they're doing. This is a completely unnecessary report written in gibberish language. No one will read it. No one is interested in this and there is no reason for us to do so.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am a little surprised that my colleague does not know all the instruments used by the EU, but this is perhaps just a sigh. On the contrary, I think the report is rather restrained. They talk about a number of models of financial participation of employees in job creation and their motivation. We are talking about models such as financial share of profit, individual employee ownership, ownership of employees within cooperative shares and programs of so-called employee ownership. These are really diverse options for motivating these workers, and I find it desirable to motivate employees to create new jobs. I am also glad that, as I said, the report is quite restrained, it really says that the role is primarily up to the Member States. And for me, it is only essential that the rules laid down above all by those national rules are as predictable and transparent as possible. And since all this report met, I was actually happy to vote in favour.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Commission's statement on the Commission's work programme for 2019 (2018/2850 (RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I have literally come running from the College meeting that has just ended to present to you the work programme for 2019 that we have just decided. I think we are all aware that the next six months will be crucial for our Union. For Europeans going to the polls next May it is not enough that the Commission has made proposals to make their lives better, they want to see results on the ground, concrete decisions.  Together we have a very short window of time in which to find agreement on the many proposals that are on the table and thus show that the European Union can deliver solutions to the challenges that cannot be addressed by any of our Member States acting alone.  Challenges such as ensuring that Europe’s return to economic growth benefits all, and creating opportunity in the transition to the digital and low carbon economy. Challenges such as demographics and migration, climate change and the competition for resources, which require a shared push towards sustainability. Challenges to our values and democratic societies from terrorists, cyber-attackers and disinformation campaigns. In an increasingly volatile world, we have to show that Europe is able to deliver solutions to these biggest of questions.  Today’s work programme reflects fully the ambition of Jean-Claude Juncker’s State of the Union address last month and the accompanying letter of intent. It represents the Commission’s commitment to work intensively with you, and the Council, to deliver what we promised under the 10 priorities on the basis of which this House approved the Commission’s mandate, as well as, of course, to prepare the Union for the future.  Our work programme has been enriched by the fruitful exchanges we have had with Parliament, through the structured dialogue with the Conference of Committee Chairs and with the Conference of Presidents as well. We have also had a good exchange with the Council in line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making.  So the first priority for our work in the coming year is all about delivery. With the initiatives presented alongside the State of the Union address, the Commission has tabled all of the legislative proposals needed to deliver on our common agenda for jobs, growth, fairness and democratic change. Together with this House, and the Council, we have found agreement on nearly half of these and a further 20% are well advanced in the legislative process. The priority must now be to turn the remaining proposals into legislation and then to implement it effectively.  The Joint Declaration on the EU’s legislative priorities for 2018 and 2019, signed by the Presidents of the three institutions, has proved valuable in helping us to find shared priorities, and especially to stick to them. I know from our dialogue that this Parliament shares the commitment to maintain and further step up the momentum.  The Commission will be a constructive and energetic partner to you, as well as to the Council, in helping find the agreements needed to deliver what we promised on migration, on the reform of our common asylum system, on the digital single market, on a fairer and deeper economic monetary union, on the European Pillar of Social Rights and on internal security, to name but a few. To keep strong focus on delivery on these shared priorities, we are only proposing a very limited number of new initiatives in our work programme. Some of these are policy initiatives which are needed to complete the 10 priorities in areas such as further boosting investment, addressing the challenges of artificial intelligence or tackling disinformation campaigns which threaten our democracy. Whilst continuing the significant efforts to ensure an agreement with the United Kingdom, we will bring forward the necessary measures to adapt the acquis ahead of Brexit.  We will also continue our better regulation work. To consolidate this as part of our collective DNA, we will present the results of our ongoing stocktaking this spring. Today we are announcing evaluation work and fitness checks to ensure our existing laws are fit for purpose and up to date, including in areas flagged in the opinions of the REFIT platform. We will also pay particular attention to ensuring the laws we already have are properly implemented and applied. In parallel with the work programme, we are also presenting a Communication which sets out how we propose to strengthen the role of subsidiarity and proportionality principles in our policymaking.  Finally, our work programme takes forward the roadmap to the Sibiu Summit on Europe Day next year. This will be a crucial moment for the EU of 27 to shape our collective future. The Commission will help prepare this discussion with contributions on delivering a sustainable European future to implement the sustainable development goals and surpass our Paris commitments.  We will advocate moving to more efficient decision-making in energy and climate, tax and social policies. We will also look at how to strengthen the international role of the euro and, as we will discuss further in the debate later this evening, at strengthening the rule of law framework. To build a strong foundation for our European future it is clearly essential that we find agreement before the Sibiu Summit on a future MFF – multiannual financial framework – which will enable us to deal effectively with the challenges ahead.  Honourable Members, this is the time to deliver; let’s get to work.

name: József Szájer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I think we can all agree here that democracy is a good thing. There will be a new mandate from next year, both for the European Parliament and our connected institution – the Commission – which is very dependent on us next year. But this debate this year should take place at the same time for that very reason: about the future but also about how we complete our five years’ work together. From that point of view these two elements are mixed here. The first thing I would like to say is that our group is very keen to work on, and insists on the need to deliver on, the legislative proposals which are still pending. Parliament should complete its work and the Commission should table everything which is still missing from the table. From what we have seen so far, this is possible. For the EPP Group, the most important element – and the number-one question we would like to see completed – is, obviously, the security and migration issue, where border protection – not just border management, but real protection of the European Union – should be achieved, as well as cooperation with Africa, keeping a vigilant eye within the continent on the Western Balkans. The Vice-President mentioned cybersecurity, especially concerning the possibilities of disinformation in the European Parliament election campaign. We also insist on implementation, not just on completing pending legislation, for instance in the area of PNR. This is a very important thing. I would also like to use this opportunity to welcome – as we have discussed in this Parliament several times, parallel work is not something which we need to do concerning the Commission work programme – the withdrawal of the mandate from the migration compact, which is a decision that I think the Commission was right to take. It should be left to the Member States and we should find our own way to find our own possibilities at European level. All these aspects are very important to ensure the stability of the continent. On solidarity, I would also like to draw your attention to the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, which is very important, and also to the fact that the Parliament will be ready – and this is a message to the Council rather than the Commission or ourselves – with the MFF proposals by the end of this year. With all due respect, some elements are still missing, but I think we can achieve it. From there on, it will basically be the Council’s job. But we are delivering our results here. Regarding trade policy and climate change, my colleagues will expand on my speech, but I would like to welcome the Commission’s quick response to these issues. I wish for ourselves the successful completion of our work of five years, both for the Commission and for Parliament.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the First Vice-President: yes, what is at stake is knowing what kind of European Union we can present to our citizens in the upcoming European elections. A Europe which can really deliver on solutions for their problems, or a Europe which is paralysed by the forces of the status quo? We, the S&D Group, are really striving for real European solutions, and we need to deliver them in the last months, for sure. When it comes to tackling social inequalities, this means fully implementing the European Social Pillar. When it comes to climate change, this means having an ambitious strategy for a low-carbon economy. When it comes to the digital revolution, we need to frame it, to conduct it in such a way that we improve working conditions and we control the effects on our democracy. And when it comes to migration management and the refugee crisis, we need to make sure that Europe counts not only on the European border, but the real European Asylum System and a real partnership with Africa. Then we can ask: but do we have the means for this? And we think we have, because if we fight tax evasion – tax avoidance – the means will be there. We need to turn these into a future Community framework and also a proper reform of the eurozone, overcoming the current differences. And then we can ask: can we decide on this? Yes, we can. In the European Parliament we decide by a majority, so let’s see now how the different Groups promote these real European solutions. And yes, when it comes to the Council, these proposals coming now to extend qualified majority voting in the social area, taxation and foreign affairs – this makes sense – will support the Commission in this direction. Let’s make the best of the upcoming months. This is indeed the moment for us to strengthen European sovereignty as the main leverage to increase citizens’ ownership of their own lives.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Dear Mr Timmermans, ladies and gentlemen, time is running out. We are moving towards the end of the legislature. 'A Union that listens more carefully to its citizens'. It was only a few fine words at the start of this Commission, because backroom politics was the common thread throughout the policy of this Commission. You spent taxpayers' money on expensive foils in the hope of winning souls. Just think of the free train tickets and the free wifi. In turn, you wasted valuable time on useless proposals such as transnational lists. Money and time that you could better spend on what the citizen is really awake to: limiting migration, ensuring our security and creating a job-friendly climate. Soon your last policy year will start. Your last chance to fully commit to the real priorities: jobs, security and migration. Additional resources for Frontex and therefore a better strengthening of our external borders, these are hopeful measures. We have also always been – and still are – asking for more support for Erasmus+ and research, and for more cooperation in the field of climate and defence. I hope that these words are not empty this time and you will be better at some extent to prove that you are taking the concerns of the citizens to heart.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I believe that we should now focus a little bit less on the current Commission’s legacy and try to make a real effort to deliver on our commitments. We need to prove to our citizens that we hear their concerns and we act upon them. In my view, the Commission needs to be realistic in what it wants to achieve before the end of its term and concentrate on a few key priorities, instead of opening a number of new issues. Sometimes less is more.  So what should the Commission do next year? First and foremost is Brexit. In 2019 the EU will go through a major, unprecedented moment in its history. It is in our common interest that this happens as smoothly and peacefully as possible for citizens, for businesses, for the entire European Union. The Commission must do its best to finalise an agreement together with the UK. Beyond Brexit, we must continue our work on key issues, border security and the personal prosperity of EU citizens. We have passed through difficult periods in Europe recently and we need to make sure people understand that the EU is on their side and prevents effectively potential future crises.  I agree that one way to prevent external crises is to work better with our neighbouring regions, including Africa. On the other hand, I wonder if it’s time now to come up at the end of the Commission’s mandate with long-term proposals, such as the voting procedure within the Council, without having an in-depth political debate with this Parliament and the Member States. Let us focus on fixing the big problems we have right now instead of focusing on creating new ones.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for your presentation, which was, as usual, concise. The Commission cannot be blamed for wanting to deliver results, to your credit. My question to you is this: like me, you are witnessing a growing disaffection among many of our fellow citizens with regard to European integration, while you and I know that it is an essential element in the exercise of our democratic sovereignty. Do you think, then, that it is by continuing to work by doing a little more of the same thing or by working incrementally that we will rekindle the European enthusiasm of those of our fellow citizens who have lost it? I think what we really need is a paradigm shift. I agree with you that it is not on the eve of an election that we are initiating a paradigm shift, but on certain points - the Commission has made proposals, I am thinking of the Euro in particular - which I think are up to the challenge; however, the Council must follow. However, I think we need something much stronger. In fact, our reading of things is that our societies are threatened by two time bombs: on the one hand growing inequalities and on the other, an ecological footprint that exceeds what our planet can bear. So, clearly, we need a paradigm shift, a reorientation of the policies of the European Union, and instead I must note that traditional political families, here in the European Parliament and in the Council, continue for the most part in the same direction. I have listened to you, Mr Sz-jer, when you say that we need to put the package on the issue of security and migration. For my part, I note that for our fellow citizens, these concerns, while important, do not come first. You persist in a path that is also that of your Bavarian friends, but I see that it is in whole battalions that their constituents have left them, for the extremes for some - because in fact, by imitating them you strengthen them - and, for those who were disgusted by this development, for the Greens, and I think their choice was the right one.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, your speech is nothing new, just the usual rhetoric and propaganda that omits the consequences of the policies that the Commission and the European Union have imposed on workers and peoples. If the evidence were lacking, there is the discussion of the next Multiannual Financial Framework that anticipates brutal cuts in cohesion, deepening the unequal, unfair and asymmetric development, imposing the divergence between the different Member States as 30 years of Portuguese integration demonstrate. At the same time, fatten the rubrics that underpin your repressive, security and militaristic policies. A costume that makes it clear that EU funds have never been the expression of solidarity or even compensation for the loss of sovereignty, the destruction of national productive tissues or the asymmetric impact of the Single Market, the euro and common policies. No people are condemned to be tied to the constraints of the European Union. It will be their will and struggle that a Europe of peace and cooperation, progress and social justice, of free, sovereign and equal states in rights will be built.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Dear President, we are often invited in this Chamber to talk about human rights violations in the countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America. Ominous resolutions are adopted. The so-called rule of law against Poland or Hungary is often waved. Yes, the Commission's agenda for the 19th year is full of beautiful words. It contains everything but lacks respect for its citizens. I therefore ask: what can the President of the Commission of the European Union personally and the Commission in corpore do to bring the Human Rights Convention into force in Lithuania, a State of the European Union, to regain citizens' civil rights, and the judgment of the Court of Human Rights, adopted eight years ago, finally enters into force? Because we all know that late justice is no justice.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, I had just walked into the chamber and i heard the Commissioner talking about fairness. When I hear fairness, i'm always in the selmayr case. Then I think, how can that be that I walk into this room and the first word I hear is fairness. Selmayr, the most scandalous chapter in this Commission's book. Not to mention a report by the European Court of Auditors on CCS. That is the storage of CO2 in which EUR 3.7 billion has been invested. We looked at that and we looked at where the money went. Nothing happened to that. It's gone. 3.7 billion. Just like the $2 billion that should be used for innovative renewable energy technology. Gone, too. That is why, on behalf of the Dutch taxpayer, I say thank you.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. In 2019, the European Commission's priority is to find a seven-year budget, a compromise with the Council and Parliament. The main challenge is to reduce the gap between the centre and the peripheral countries and to prevent the union from falling apart. To this end, effective use of EU funds is needed, above all joint action and rigorous action against corruption. Priority should be given to SMEs with significant added value, which will thus be able to raise wages, curbing one-way labour migration within the Union, causing social tensions on both sides. This is contrary to the Commission's proposal, which would significantly reduce cohesion funds. Parliament has expressed concern that the Commission is weakening the EU's main solidarity policy and is particularly opposed to the reduction of the Cohesion Fund. I trust that, as co-legislators, we can assert our expectations.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, as for the Commission, the main priority for us next year will be the adoption of the multi-year financial framework.  Our citizens need certainty and we need financial stability to face all the challenges in the sphere of external action, an area I am dealing with here in Parliament.  With regard to the new external financial instrument NDICI (neighbourhood instrument, development cooperation and international cooperation), we were surprised that the Commission's proposal did not take into account Parliament's position, which was to keep a separate instrument for the neighbourhood.  There are also many questions about the governance of this global instrument, including the new external financial architecture. Secondly, the Western Balkans must remain at the centre of our attention. 2018 was the year of opportunity for the Balkans in terms of European integration; 2019 must become the year of coherence. I think we need to continue our commitment to this area and export our stability there. Finally, I welcome the plan to strengthen the mechanism on the rule of law. You are familiar, Mr Vice-President, with the situation in Romania and I thank you for your commitment. I hope it will be the same between now and the next European elections. We must also be very firm when abuses of the rule of law occur in our neighbourhood. I am thinking in particular of Moldova, where all the consequences must be drawn, including at the budgetary level.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I wonder: does the European Commission want to be the gravedigger of the European project? That's the question I'm asking you. While Monsanto and Bayer have just been sentenced on appeal by the US courts this morning, when 1.3 million European citizens have signed the 'Stop glyphosate' initiative, while this Parliament has set up a commission of inquiry into the procedures for authorising pesticides in Europe following the "Monsanto Papers" and the controversial renewal of glyphosate, what are you doing to protect the health of the 500 million European citizens? You oppose the brussels Capital region's ban on the use of glyphosate-based products in defiance of precautionary principles. Do you know, Vice-President, that human health is the number two concern of Europeans as I speak? Do you think that such a decision is appropriate and encourages citizens to go to the polls from May 23 to 26? I refer you to Article 191, paragraph 2, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which states that "the Union's environmental policy aims at a high level of protection [...] and is based on precautionary principles." I hope that the European Commission will plan to propose a revision of European pesticide legislation in 2019 and respond to the flaws in the current system and the expectations of the 500 million Europeans in this area.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work The Commission's work programme contains comments on the deepening of monetary union. It calls for us to finally have a functioning, comprehensive monetary fund and for us to complete the banking union so that the risk can be shared. These are clearly the wrong measures. Instead of needing more transfers, we need more personal responsibility. Instead of an inappropriate corset for all, we need more freedom for everyone. The euro has failed in its present form. It cannot be continued in this way, with the same measures for all. Instead, we should provide for action in the work programme: how can we dismiss countries from the eurozone in a way that minimizes damage to the eurozone's economy – both of these countries and the remaining countries. Now it would be possible to prepare the whole thing so that we do not experience chaos, otherwise we will see the markets collapse if we do nothing and allow debt spirals to continue.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: 'blue card' question. Germany has been unified for about 150 years and has been reunited for about a quarter of a century. Despite this long history, Germany remains an economically inhomogenic country today, so what makes Germany stand together are massive financial transfers between the wealthiest regions of the country and the least wealthy regions of the country. These transfers use the tax route, the federal budget, the federal social security route and the voice of the "Finanzausgleich". That is what makes Germany stand together. Explain to me how, in the eyes of European unity, we could do without these mechanisms which are indispensable to German unity? I still don't get it.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Lamberts, thank you very much for this question. In fact, we have a model that works. This works because Germany accepts that there is a balance between the poorer and the richer regions. And I have absolutely no objection to the introduction of such compensation in the EU. But you have to ask the citizens if they want to do that. You should not just look to Germany, you should ask all the citizens of the EU whether they are prepared to work longer hours, or– in other words, that some work longer and others retire earlier and that is financed by financial transfers. Moreover, it is precisely a question of not penalising countries with an inappropriate currency. I would like to give back freedom to the countries so that they can become competitive again through devaluations. We should not think in transfers, but in genuine solidarity and fairness.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, the obsession with neoliberal prescriptions and immobility feeds the anti-European, far-right populism that seeks to break up European unification, shrink democracy and a major social setback. You can hear them in here, too. The question is what do you do – not in words, but in practice – to deal with the critical changes that citizens demand: a real social pillar and not just a label on words, a multiannual financial framework that will be adopted before the European elections and will support development and cohesion policies that reduce inequalities, reform asylum policy so that greece and Italy do not burden all the burdens on refugees , enhancing transparency and democratic accountability, more ambitious targets for tackling climate change. That is what they judge evolution and that is what you will be judged on. Not from words, but from actions. From what you will do "delivery" at the end of the day.

name: Patrick O'Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, in the United States of America, where I believe they directly elect their presidents, a president who is in the last year of his term and is not standing again is described as a lame duck. On that basis, this is a lame duck Commission. Were it wise, it would reflect that modest status with modest targets. But no, right across the piece, the Juncker Commission is attempting new power grabs for Brussels, from permanent structured cooperation in defence to a common European asylum system, to beefing up the sanctions on Member States which displease it in what it euphemistically calls the rule-of-law agenda. That’s the rule of Brussels law over national democracies, by the way. But with its two federalist engines wheezing badly – Macron in France and Merkel in Germany – one can’t help but notice that the Commission is on collision course with the two other heavyweights, with Italy in regard both to migration and economic sovereignty, and with the United Kingdom on its right to run its own affairs even after it’s left the club. I had to laugh when Mr Juncker in his State of the Union package went to great pains to highlight one area where he felt subsidiarity could be enforced: changing the clocks. Countries are going to be allowed to set their own time. Big deal: given the rest of this federalist agenda, that just gives the nation the right to decide whether its sovereignty will be stolen at 4 o’clock or 5 o’clock on any given day. Mr Juncker told us in September, and I quote, ‘The time for European sovereignty has come’. No, it has not, at least not in the eyes of Italians, or Hungarians, or Austrians or Swedes, or German surging towards the AfD. Even at its fag end, this Commission continues the great eurocrat mistake of overreaching and seeking to govern without consent. Well, the British people have had enough. We’re off. We will run our own country again one day, no matter what Mrs May connives to bind us into. If you don’t change your ways, I predict we will be the first of many.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while every election renews people's condemnation of austerity policy, the wrong immigration policies and the non-existent social policies of this European Union, the vast programme with which we are presented at the end of this parliamentary term is a tired repetition of all those vague promises and commitments that no one has actually ever kept. With a novelty: a big investment for disinformation campaigns.  While there are countries like my own, Italy, which have 5 million poor people – and fortunately there is a government that has finally made a social contribution, because Europe had not thought about it – I believe that we need to reflect on the election results that are being repeated, to reflect on the problem of the challenge of immigration, on which you are not saying anything, there is not a word about readmission agreements. , you have done absolutely nothing and you do not intend to do anything to solve these problems at the root. Aid to Africa, a Marshall Plan for Africa, of course, not by financing the usual corrupt satraps but through a system of investment by our small and medium-sized enterprises. We must bring work, we must recreate the conditions for there to be work, here and in the countries that export immigration ... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. President Timmermans spoke of meeting the pragmatic expectations of citizens. It was a good formula. The question is how do we understand the pragmatic expectations of citizens. I think they concern at least three areas: security, and full-scale security, not only the fight against terrorism, the security of the southern flank of the European Union, but also security in the East and sensitivity to hegemony on putin's part; secondly, to set an example of cost-effective legislation, which is not always a good thing, to set a model for transparency in the european Commission's work; and thirdly, the rejection of socialist prescriptions. The European Union needs an injection of economic freedom, competitiveness, the fight against protectionism, equal rules that will give economic strength to the whole of Europe. I think that is what citizens, certainly very many citizens in Central Europe, expect.

name: Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In principle, I welcome the European Commission's plans for the coming year. We are at the end of the parliamentary term of office, and we must, of course, try to complete open dossiers as best we can. The rapid ratification of the EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement is of great economic and symbolic importance. It is currently the most important trade agreement in European history. But it also has a symbolic meaning on a global level. The EU stands for sustainable free trade and against short-term protectionism. We must, of course, try to promote the international trading system, on a rules-based basis. This means that we must press ahead with the reform of the WTO – we are working on this here in Parliament – and that we should try to find a common solution with the United States. If it turns out that the United States wants to work with us again on a joint trade agreement, as has become apparent, then I very much hope that the Commission will seize this opportunity. But what I really hope for in the next few months is that the Commission will get a communication strategy right. We must all communicate with each other in such a way that our citizens know that we want a Europe that protects, but not a Europe that is closed.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, last year of work. You could say we're still doing a little bit or you could say no, we're going to set the tables for the next legislature. That's kind of my plea today. We know we need to radically reform our economy. We know that we have to take radically different options for the future. The good news is that the script is actually ready for that. We didn't write that in Europe. We have written this at the united nations level, with the so-called sustainable development goals. We, as a group, totally embrace them. For us, that's almost become the Bible. We're going to have to implement them and that means very concrete things. Get out of coal, stop investing in fossil energy, but also stop the race to the bottom of our workers' wages and working conditions, turn them around and bet on social it. But – and this is my but also my plea today – we know what to do, but in terms of governance in the European Union, we do not have the means to do so. We are still stuck with that stability and growth pact, in line with that European semester, linked to narrow fiscal targets. Budget targets make sense if they are linked to social objectives. That is why it would be good if the Commission came forward with a proposal to radically implement that European semester and apply the sustainable development goals. This means that the budgetary objectives are no more important than social objectives or environmental objectives. In particular, approaching together and putting together mandatory conditions in our governance is an essential condition.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: Madam President! This Commission's period has been marked by a state of crisis: from the euro crisis to Brexit to the migration crisis, and now to a general crisis of confidence on the part of the peoples of Europe. It is therefore almost tragikomic to imagine that what really takes up the most space in the presentation of the work programme is the banning of single-use plastics and balloons, as well as the idea that Member States should now be free to choose whether or not they want daylight saving time and what time zone they wish to belong to. If the Commission had really wanted to address the root of the nettle – instead of talking about future projects with the United States of Europe, about a single president, about a common foreign policy, about a budget for the euro zone, etc., but instead it would have addressed the very specific concerns of the peoples of Europe about their security and completely uncontrollable migration, and if it was to intervene and interfere with the internal democracy of the Member States. Then the EU had a much better chance of surviving in the post-Brexit process.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President-in-Chief for the work he has If we look at the political activities of the Commission, which is still in office, the stocktaking is simply disastrous. The Commission has completely supplanted the problems caused by illegal migration for years until 2014 and, since 2015, has completely misled the seriousness of the situation that has arisen. To this day, you prefer to deal with placebo solutions and forced migrant redistribution, rather than finally protecting the external borders, as it has long been necessary. You are also facing a gigantic pile of shards in the euro and finances. Matteo Salvini teaches you today that Italy is still a sovereign state. As such, it decides on its own fiscal, economic and budgetary policies, and the Commission cannot do anything about it. The EU's rules, which have been hailed as binding, are once again proving to be a completely toothless tiger. That is why we are working for a Europe of the fatherlands, in which each state decides on its own responsibility and then, of course, also trains the consequences of its political decisions. Only in this way can Europe function – no other way.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The European Commission's work programme for next year, which for all of us in the Union will be a year of decisions, changes and challenges in terms of development cooperation and humanitarian aid. From the perspective of the Committee on Development (DEVE), which it represents, but also other committees in Parliament, the key focus is, of course, the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, as well as the related negotiations and discussions around the Commission's proposals for a new neighbourhood instrument and international and development cooperation.  President Juncker's speech included proposals for a more effective governance model and for increased cooperation between multilateral and national development actors. Personally, I believe that this is the right direction to create jobs and make use of investment opportunities in partnership with Africa and with neighbouring countries. I believe that we, as the Union and the Member States, must avoid duplication and strengthen their effectiveness and complementarity more.  I would also like to mention the 2030 Agenda and the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which are also included in the European Consensus on Development. I hope that, on the basis of the European Commission's analysis, to be published later this year, it will be possible to develop a comprehensive strategy for the implementation of the SDGs in 2019 and to include these objectives also in the future financing architecture for development aid.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Vice-President, I welcome the results that you have identified, which the Commission has identified, and also that it has also opened up a horizon for the institutional reforms necessary to save the European project. I believe that this is the perspective we must move towards if we are to make Europe love again, and I believe that it is right for the forthcoming elections to speed up much more the adoption of the code of conduct for social networks and social platforms against organised disinformation, which gives rise to many populisms and nationalisms. I was a little surprised, however, that compared to the reference you made to social pillar and also sustainability as a great perspective, you did not indicate in the least its educational and cultural aspect. Without access to culture and education, an increase in the quality of education systems, citizens' participation in cultural production and also participation in programmes, such as Erasmus and Creative Europe, which are successful but underfunded programmes, there will be no future for the European project. You know that because you have always said that, but you do not say that in this report. Please keep these as high goals.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, I would like to thank mr Timmermans for his work and for his work I pick out a small sentence from the trade sector. The work programme states that you want to overcome the deadlock in the implementation of dual-use export control. Yes, we must. In 2014, we adopted a joint declaration between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, where we called for greater control of goods that can be used both to violate human rights and also to be used for civil purposes. 2014 - that's four years ago! And we have a proposal. We, as a Parliament, have taken a decision on this – with more than 500 votes, which is a clear signal – and we are still unable to negotiate, the Council is still blocking. Can it be that economic interests are above the protection of human rights? No, I believe that we must move forward here. We cannot allow European software to be used to control and persecute opponents in other countries. We need a strict export regime here.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I see your programme of work for 2019, and I want to tell you in this Parliament, focus on the essentials and ensure that we can achieve results. From this point of view and within the framework of my responsibilities in the European Parliament, I would like to stress a few points. Firstly, when it comes to the supervision of banks and financial markets, we must implement this famous reform of the supervisory authorities, and for that we need the support of the Commission.  You must also convince the Council to move on the deposit guarantee, because otherwise the whole system of the banking union will collapse. We must also convince the Council, with your support, about the famous CCP, those clearing houses that will be shaken by the departure of our British friends. In tax matters, perhaps I misread your work programme, but I did not get the impression that you were putting enough emphasis on two very essential aspects: both the digital taxation and this famous common corporate tax base. Finally, I fully agree with my colleague Kathleen Van Brempt that you need to review economic governance in the light of the sustainable development goals.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Socialists and Democrats are convinced that people want an EU that takes care of them and does not want an EU that increases their concerns. I realise that the big brakes on many of the things that we would like to see together for the positive development of the European Union are in the Council of the European Union. But I would like to talk today about the Commission's initiatives, especially in the social dimension. We are pleased with the success of the Posting of Workers Directive. We have thus made a major contribution to reducing an urgent social problem within the European Union. But we are concerned about the corporate law package.  Vice-President Timmermans, corporate participation – as we can see on every corner in Germany – is a model of success. But this legislative package could damage this model of success. What we also urgently need are initiatives that bring living conditions and social security systems in the Member States of the European Union closer together. The MFF may not do this well, because cohesion benefits are declining here. What we want is a directive on upward social adjustment.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we could spend the little time we have left to lament the mistakes made or we can turn our efforts to restore the soul missing from the Union project, with a Europe, with a strong social pillar that advances social rights, in a minimum wage framework, in decent pensions and living wages; a leading Europe in the fight against climate change, as an issue on which losing a single minute would already be a serious irresponsibility; an egalitarian Europe that does not renounce the eradication of violence against women and which attempts to unblock legislative initiatives such as the Women on Boards or, for example, the Equal Treatment Directive. Mr Timmermans, you from the European Commission cannot afford to resign yourself and we from the socialist family will shoulder your shoulders to build that Europe.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, the electoral deadlines certainly make 2019 a special year, a year in which we must close the many projects that have been carried out but also try to project Europe into the future. I would like to focus on two issues. Firstly, we must complete the construction of the digital single market. We have done many things in this legislature, but it is clear that platforms and artificial intelligence now need new rules. We must avoid, Mr Vice-President, the digital revolution asserting itself in a contradictory way to the principles on which the European Union is based. Secondly, this year we celebrated the twenty-five years of the single market, a success story of Europe. Of course, as we have built it in recent years, the single market, as it is, is no longer enough. We need stricter rules on market surveillance, product controls and clear rules on how services are carried out. I believe that these are the messages that we must send to the citizens of Europe for the next elections.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Vice-President Timmermans. The work programme we are discussing is shorter, given the imminent electoral deadline, but there is still a great deal of work to be done, in particular we see the inability of european leaders meeting in the Council to find common solutions, we see dossiers blocked, we see Europe's inability to advance a political and legislative agenda. We need to unblock this situation, I am thinking of migration issues, I am thinking of the reform of the Dublin Regulation, but I am also thinking of the implementation of the European social pillar with a social fund, cohesion funds that are able to respond to European children, so that everyone has the same opportunities, with the guarantee for children, with innovative tools to support work and lifelong learning. , in order to bring the Union's action into line with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Otherwise we will continue to set great goals without the means to achieve them and we will only increase the anger of nationalists and the rhetoric against Europe.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: "If everything is a priority, then unfortunately it is not a priority. I sympathize a little with the Commissioner because I have listened to nearly 30 speeches, and only a dozen speeches were the most important of these priorities. Rather, the rest are criticisms of the EU institutions or wishes for specific priorities in the long term.  I will say what is most important to me. Firstly, to put an end to all those issues that require a long time, namely, above all, budgetary and financial issues, including, for example, the emched Erasmus+ programme. The second point is, of course, security in the broadsense, that is, everything from which we started this parliamentary term and ended in completely changed conditions. And thirdly, Brexit. Solving the problems of the agreement with the UK, its departure, will be crucial in terms of the whole next prospect of cooperation not only with the UK, but with other countries as well.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President; Unfortunately, Mr Vice-President, the European Commission, which had set itself at the beginning of its mandate that the weight of industry reach 20% of GDP, silently assists in the closure of industries and businesses and does not present the industrial plan so often claimed by Parliament and the Commission. In the steel, aluminum and steel sector, it is even more serious. Closures have just been announced in companies in Spain by Alcoa (in Avilés and A Coruña) or, a few days ago, by vestas. It is therefore necessary not to stand by and take action and take initiatives; and the measures promoted at the time by the Commission are not attaining unfair trade practices and dumping in countries such as China.  I stand directly with you, Mr Timmermans, to deal with this situation and help us maintain the use of key strategic industrial sectors for our Europe and for our country.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam Chairman, the single market today is the greatest value of European integration. It brought economic prosperity, greater job opportunities, stronger competitiveness, growth in innovation and better and cheaper products and services to much of the European continent. That is why I support efforts to deepen it in the areas of the digital economy, energy and financial services. Every form of protectionism is a path to stagnation and lag behind other global giants. I believe that until the Brexit referendum the Commission had solidly arranged priorities, but after that it focused too much on the project of further political integration, feeling that with the departure of the chief brakeman of the federalist model comes an opportune moment. The vast majority of citizens live not from the blue flag and yellow stars, but from bread they earn on the market. That is why until the elections we have to do even more in terms of economic integration, and the political one, which does not have the support of citizens, is removed from the agenda.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, if one was to be getting divorced next March, no matter what else was happening in your life, whether you were getting a more energy-efficient car, whether you were insulating your house and no matter how deluded you’d want to be about what was important next year, what would be important next year would be the divorce. And you wouldn’t put it number four on the list. It should be number one on the list, otherwise you would be in denial. We are talking about Brexit; we are talking about the second-biggest economy in Europe leaving the European Union. Like it or not, they’re leaving. Billions of euros in trade, billions of connections in many other areas – family-wise, social-wise – in many different areas. That has to be the number one priority. If it isn’t, there’s something wrong here. In particular for Ireland, we need the endgame to be: no restrictions on trade, no restrictions on movement of people and no border. People talk about the Irish border – it’s not an Irish border, it’s a British border. If it was up to us it would not be there.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker and the Commission have one last chance to correct their policies before they are definitively written in black in the history of Europe. The uk's withdrawal, uncontrolled illegal immigration, terrorism and prolonged economic austerity among European citizens, especially in the countries of the South, show that their programmes have achieved their purpose. In other words, they nationally alter Europe, impose fear and take over the economically weak countries.  But Europe is changing, citizens are awakening and demanding respect and dignity. The Commission must respect their decision and proceed immediately to the repatriation of the sovereign rights of the Member States to their respective governments and to deal exclusively with the normalisation of the economic inequalities it has created with its wrong policies. Otherwise, the Union will collapse and the disaster will have a name.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – I welcome the European Commission Work Programme 2019.  We are achieving enviable economic results in the European Union. We need a good agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework, which will enable us to face the challenges that we face.  Migration and security, the challenges of global digitalisation, a deep monetary Union, a fair internal market are just one of the important areas. We must not allow ourselves to reduce funding for agricultural and cohesion policy.  In addition to the conclusion of the negotiations in a number of areas and the adoption of open proposals that are still under consideration, we must also not forget the long-term objectives, where we must continue to discuss the future of the European Union, especially in the light of possible institutional changes that will strengthen the link and bring it even closer to our citizens.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, we must be realistic - 2019 is a short year for the Commission and for us. I think the priorities need to be very clear and have been said here, it is Brexit. We need to see how it will have a very big impact - I am the rapporteur on the customs union - it will also affect the customs union and many other regulations that we have in the works. But, Commissioner, I believe that every day we must be concerned about the future of Europe and this morning we discussed this. I think it is essential to see how the Commission finds other means, other tools to be able to establish that trust of citizens and Member States, to stop having this perception of states divided into two - first-hand/second-hand citizens. I believe that confidence in the future of Europe does not start after 2019, even though 2019 is a very difficult year. Then the trade defense. I have been talking here for four years that third countries - sure, we have the market, the entry of products - but there is no good verification and it is unfair competition, we have deindustrialised. And last but not least, I would like to say that it is very important what we do with the multiannual financial framework. So how do we make it the best division?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Mr First Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab, There are a few months left in this term of office, and you have heard how great the expectations are. All the more so it is necessary to close unnecessary cases. I am thinking first of all of this of the proposal that the European Commission has made against Poland. As you have seen, many countries have spoken at the last General Affairs Council, but this is not the majority needed to determine the risk that democracy is not functioning in Poland. Anyway, we had local elections recently. You could see them yourself. It is time to finally close this case. If you believe in the rule of law, please remain within your remit. This is clear from the principle of separation of powers. If you believe in democracy, please make it clear that there is no majority – again – of the majority required, because not every majority is the majority required by law to continue this procedure. And please take up the issues that the House has asked for today.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, now that we are at the end of the term of office, it is time to be able to finally implement in the form of rules, budget and public policy instruments one of the best ideas that this Commission, which is the European Pillar of Social Rights, has promoted. We have several tools on the table to be able to adopt the Transparent and Predictable Working Conditions Directive, to combat precariousness and regulate new forms of work; the labour reconciliation package, which is a key part of bringing gender equality to the labour market as well; or the European Labour Authority, which has to be an instrument to combat the abuses of many European workers. These are some of the ideas on the table, but there are also old ideas, such as European unemployment insurance, which new governments, such as Spanish, are committed to boosting. Now that we finish the mandate, let us use these tools to gain legitimacy for European citizens in combating a social and just Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, European citizens are demanding a change of course: abandoning austerity, abandoning violent fiscal adjustment, emphasising social Europe, solidarity, strengthening territorial and social cohesion and, at the same time, the functioning of relocation mechanisms in relation to refugees. In addition, a modern European industrial policy must be developed. With regard to the euro area, the institution must function much more flexibly, the Stability Pact must be abolished, the Member States must be able to regain and function, they must be able to implement what their people believe and demand in budgetary matters and, at the same time, the recovery of monetary sovereignty by the Member States within the euro area will now be considered in the future. , so that their own central banks exercise this sovereignty by their shareholding in the capital of the European Central Bank. With a more flexible euro area we can have answers to economic growth.
