name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, so many subjects were raised by the Members that I can’t go into all of them, and they will come back in the committee meetings and in the plenary during the course of the rest of our mandate. But there are a few remarks I would like to make.  First of all, there’s no reason to be so gloomy! Look at the Eurobarometer. Our citizens, in a vast majority, believe the European Union is their home and their collective home, and a vast majority believe in the European project. They don’t agree, very often, with proposals we make. They don’t necessarily like the European Commission, or even the European Parliament, but they do understand that they share a destiny with other Europeans.  Sometimes that feels uncomfortable because we don’t know whether we are really fully in control of that destiny. But the very fact, the very basis, that Europeans understand that it is better to solve our differences around a conference table, even if that takes time and it is tedious, rather than to go back to Europe’s history of solving differences on the battlefield, is something that is shared by a vast majority of our citizens – even in countries where political forces do their best to rekindle age-old controversies based on nationalism, even in those countries the majority of the population is in favour of the European Union. So please, take some courage from that. That is a good starting position to be in.  And then yes, of course we need to take steps on issues that have been left alone too long. But if we look, for instance, at the migration issue, has that not been solved because European institutions have failed to act or has that not been solved because Member States, very often based on nationalism, did not come together and did not want to compromise? Answer that question! We have nothing to be ashamed of, neither the Commission nor the European Parliament, but put the onus where it belongs.  Do we really think that going back to nation states on their own is going to solve the problem of climate change, is going to find solutions for migration issues, is going to give us the force to negotiate fair trade agreements with big partners in the world like the United States and China? The leader of Mr Flynn, or the de facto leader of Mr Flynn, does not know whom he admires more – Putin or Trump. Are they going to help us decide the fate of Europe, Putin and Trump, or should we be masters of our own fate in Europe? I believe we should be masters of our own fate.  Somebody ridiculed the plastics strategy. I would say, go and watch what science comes up with now! Our oceans are suffocating in plastic. Every human being has microplastics in his/her body. Every single bought bottle of water has microplastics in it. Is it not urgent? Is this not something that more than 80% of Europeans want us to act upon? Is it not a good choice to interdict single plastic use, stuff that is made in a few seconds and stays in our environment for hundreds of years, and for which we have perfectly feasible alternatives that do not pollute our natural environment? Why ridicule that? It is a great change for our society. It is something our citizens want. This is something we need to do and we can do it now.  On the banking union – let’s complete the banking union. In my political life, one of the most horrible moments I can remember is in 2008 when I was in national government, when we were told we need to save the banks because they are too big to fail. We could not hold the bankers accountable. We needed to pour billions of taxpayers’ money into saving the banks. Do we still want that? No! We never want that to happen again. If that is not to happen again, if banks are to be held accountable themselves for their mistakes, we need a banking union and only the European Union can provide a banking union. There is not a ‘ concert de nations’ that can provide for that.  The same goes for taxation. How fair is it that huge corporations can negotiate with individual Member States so that at the end of the day, they don’t pay tax? Should the rule not be that you pay tax where you make profits? The only way we can achieve that, especially against the big tech corporations, is if we are united on this, as Europeans, and not divided. They will play off one Member State against the other.  Please make speed with the changes in company law, because it will help us on the one hand to especially allow small and medium-sized enterprises to act on a European scale, and at the same time we will protect the rights of workers in this so that you cannot use letterbox companies to avoid taking your responsibility towards your workers and towards your other social responsibilities. Let’s act on that!  Of course, this is not always the big picture, but these are concrete measures that make the lives of European citizens better day by day.  With all the differences we have across the board here in Parliament, compromise is never a bad thing. Why did we bad-mouth compromise at some point? In a democracy, compromise is a thing of beauty because it brings together a majority to make positive change in this society. This is the force. This is where the force of the European Parliament lies and yes, the SDGs can be a good framework for that.  We can certainly mould Europe along this global picture. This is, I think, something we can do in the future, but for the year to come, let’s try and finish a number of the subjects that are still on the table – on fiscal policy, on completing the economic and monetary union, which is urgent. Again, it is not complete. It needs to be completed. But again, solidarity and responsibility go hand in hand. Of course, you can ask solidarity of other Europeans, but then you also have the responsibility to act within the rules in the economic and monetary union. Otherwise, other Europeans will not want to share their destiny with you.  I think on all these subjects, we have so much to do. We have little time, but there is no need to be complacent. There is no need to be fatalistic. We can do this together. With all the political differences we have, the Commission is ready to work with you and the Council to get this done – also dual use, let me insist on that. We salute Parliament’s position on that. Hey, Council, now get going! Make sure we can get this done soon.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Council and Commission's statement on the "CumEx Files" scandal: financial crime and the shortcomings of the current legal framework (2018/2900 (RSP)).

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you very much for inviting the Presidency to participate in this debate. Recent emerging media reports have referred to ongoing investigations in relation to the so-called cum-ex trades that reportedly involve tens of billions of euros. At this stage it is our understanding that systematic investigations have been initiated and searches are being conducted at national levels in several Member States on suspicion of tax evasion. As the Honourable Members are aware, the fight against tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning both at global and EU levels is a priority for the Council and one of the key focuses of its work. The Presidency therefore continues to follow closely all relevant information and developments. So far, we have no indications that there would be any direct link to, or breach of, current EU legislation or rules. No discussion on this issue has, therefore, taken place in the Council and its preparatory bodies at this stage. I will listen attentively to your debate and as I said, we will follow the developments closely.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for organising this debate so quickly. Once again, thanks to the work of journalists, whom I want to salute, a new tax scandal is revealed that shows that in order to reduce their taxes the richest and most powerful taxpayers do not lack imagination and make fun of solidarity, ethics and sometimes legality. The patterns of fraud that have been revealed are shocking and even unbearable. They are shocking because they involve some banks that abused public treasuries at the height of the crisis, when large sums of public money had just been injected to save the banking sector. Unbearable, because these are less revenue for the Member States and therefore also less investment and additional taxes for businesses and citizens who respect the rules of the game, so this is not permissible, of course. What does this new scandal tell us - one more? That in the past, the rules on the exchange of information could and should have been more effective, but above all more respected. It should be remembered that at the time of the events, these exchanges were said to be "spontaneous", that is, left to the discretion of the States, and these rules did not, it must be noted, prevent fraudulent behaviour. They have not prevented these flows from moving from one Member State to another. However, since 2014, this Commission - and I am proud to have contributed to it in my place as Commissioner for Taxation - has started what I have called the 'transparency revolution', following an extremely simple principle which is to strengthen and even systematise cooperation and information exchange between Member States. The exchange of information is really the key concept that made us change, I think, from time to time. As a result, the Directive on Administrative Cooperation has been considerably extended. It now includes the mandatory automatic exchange of information in many cases. It is true that information held by some Member States is indispensable to others, for example on financial accounts - this is the end of bank secrecy - on tax decisions made by Member States, on country-by-country information - these are the famous decisions on tax rulings - or on the CBCR (Country-by-Country reporting), which I still believe should be public. , and finally, on the sharing of information between national tax authorities and anti-money laundering authorities.  More recently, this directive has been supplemented by new reporting provisions for tax intermediaries; you voted for it and I thank you for that. It is scheduled to come into force next year. It will change everything because it will force these intermediaries - bankers, lawyers, legal or tax advisers - to report abusive or aggressive tax arrangements that they sell to their clients. I call on Member States to now use these tools which are available to them to cooperate, to exchange information more quickly. Speed, precisely, is essential to prevent this kind of aggressive scheme from spreading between Member States. Last week's revelations demonstrate, once again, that these tax justice issues are of great interest to the general public. They are even now at the very top of the priorities of our opinions and that is why I call on Parliament and the Council to quickly adopt our proposals on country-by-country reports and on the protection of whistleblowers. In addition to strengthening cooperation with tax administrations, this Commission has systematically proposed to the Member States, as you know, an ambitious collective approach - and here, Parliament and the Commission have always found themselves side by side - by defining a common corporate tax base. Progress on this issue is real and must be achieved, because a harmonized base would significantly reduce the potential for tax evasion by better taking digital activities into account. And I believe that a European response is the only one that can lead the rest of the international community to a serious reform of the legal framework, through the adoption of a common list of tax havens, which has given us enough clout to obtain, I believe, a whole series of reforms that allow us to make progress in the fight against harmful tax regimes around the world. We have also proposed that Member States negotiate certain aspects of double taxation prevention treaties at European level in the FATCA (Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act) agreements with the United States. Some Member States were not 'ripe' for such a coordinated approach and it may be time - it is not a will, it is a proposal - to revive this idea. Here, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, everything is not yet settled, everything is not yet put in place, but precisely with regard to what is raised by this scandal, it turns out that significant progress has been made, although I cannot say that everything we have decided together is likely to make such a scandal impossible. But I can say with great confidence that it would be much, much, much more difficult if the tax administrations fulfilled the legal provisions to which they are now bound. When all these laws are implemented, I believe it will be much more complicated to do this kind of tax optimisation and evasion in Europe and you can count on my determination and that of the Commission to ensure that. I also believe, as always, that we must turn to the Member States because it is up to them to enforce these provisions more than those which dealt with the exchange of spontaneous information at the time. Now the spontaneous is automatic and therefore mandatory. I really rely on the Member States, that is the least we can do, to comply with their obligations.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Cum-Ex frauds follow a pattern that we should actually be very familiar with. A tax loophole is identified, which is problematic and which is easier to use the worse tax authorities communicate. That is why we also need an automatic exchange of information for capital gains tax and withholding tax, as we have already indicated – as the Commissioner has indicated – with corporation tax. I had already proposed to the Commission in the spring of this year that the existing mechanism should be extended to capital gains tax or withholding tax. In the reply I received from you, Commissioner, in a letter dated 5 October this year – it was not very long ago – you write to me: 'However, I can say that the analysis carried out does not justify an extension of the scope of the tax systems for the automatic exchange of information'. It has not been three weeks since you wrote this to me. I do not know what you have analysed, but the Cum-Ex scandal definitely justifies an extension of the automatic exchange of information. You said it yourself, then please do it! What I am saying here is not just that problems are not being recognised. It is worse if we refuse to cooperate in solving the problem. But that is exactly what you have written to me. With this attitude, the Commission is repeating the mistakes that have also in the past ensured that multinationals have been able to play off the member states' corporate tax systems against each other for years. The Commission's learning curve is very, very flat.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, this is an exceptional debate for a tax scandal which, unfortunately, is not exceptional.  After the evasion in tax havens, we are faced with a fraud of banks claiming the taxman the refund of taxes never paid. Behind all this, there may be a need for further structural reforms that would monitor how, in some Member States, tax credits on dividends are distributed and are the basis of this fraud. And then, why not admit it, the real financial transaction on high-frequency transactions would probably have allowed us to move forward against such fraud, against the manipulation of title rights, which we can see, here too, one of the impacts. The exchange of information between national tax administrations is essential, as you said, but we also say that these frauds are carried out at European level. We must therefore provide a European solution. It is also up to the European supervisory authorities to find, in accordance with their mandate, the means to act in this area. It is in this spirit that this Parliament is determined to act by the end of its mandate.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, here we are once again discussing another unacceptable tax evasion scandal affecting a large number of countries. Even more damning is the fact that the German authorities stopped cum-ex trading in 2012 only for it to have reared its head again in Germany and other Member States. The role of the banking industry in facilitating this large-scale tax fraud emphasises the need to hold tax administrations, banks and others responsible to account. The question is, why are the authorities not doing more to prevent this form of illegal tax evasion? And how is it that, every time these scandals are uncovered, it is left to investigative journalists to do all the work? In the TAX3 Committee, we will pay the utmost attention to these revelations and continue to work to find solutions to ensure effective legislation, efficient implementation and robust enforcement of rules across the EU. In this latest scandal, it is estimated that taxpayers were swindled out of EUR 55 billion. This has to stop. Hard-working people are seeing their money disappear into black holes due to a combination of unscrupulous individuals and, at times, the incompetence of enforcement authorities. Citizens deserve better.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This scandal is intolerable from a dual point of view. It is intolerable because it is about very, very high financial losses – at least EUR 55 billion for European taxpayers, probably much more, some of it fraud, another part probably tax avoidance – and also intolerable, because the actors who are putting the integrity of the European financial markets at risk here are the same ones who have been bailed out with billions of dollars, who have repeatedly stated publicly that they have now understood and are acting on the basis of ethics. That is why this tax scandal in this combination is a real attack on the social market economy. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has The citizens will not be watching this for long. At some point, they will run into the hands of populists in even greater numbers if they do not feel that the state, the European Union, is really capable of putting a stop to such machinations.  That is why, Commissioner and also to the Council, I would ask that we now really take all the measures that we have. We, like you, Commissioner, may ask the European supervisory authorities to launch a special European investigation under Article 22 of the regulation of the supervisory authorities. On the basis of this study, it must be established that which institutions were involved, with what sums did they work, on the basis of which licences? There must be consequences. Moreover, I expressly agree with Mr Ferber's call for the automatic exchange of information to be extended to include capital gains tax.  Mr Moscovici, I hope you will do these two things. Present these suggestions!  Incidentally, it would be a good thing if we were to receive different answers than before, namely that the European Commission, in its letter to the consortium of journalists, said that it was not competent, that this was a national task. No, this is a European task, Commissioner.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, the Cum Ex scandal is the definition of economic crime. At least EUR 55 billion has been stolen from the public purse from at least 11 Member States. I asked yesterday to have this debate as a matter of urgency in plenary, because once again, Mr Moscovici, the European supervisory mechanisms have been caught sleeping. After the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers, another scandal is revealed, not by the European control mechanisms, not by the competent institutions, but by the whistleblowers and this catastrophic failure, this fiasco, but also the guilty political silence that accompanies it – what the Council has told us a monument of hypocrisy and guilty political silence – poisons democracy and burdens all citizens. What the Council has told us: 'we have not discussed it so far, we have not seen anything illegal'. I don't know. Is that how you respond to citizens when it is revealed that EUR 55 billion has been stolen? And who paid for that? Honest taxpayers, the public purse, the social state, small and medium-sized enterprises. We therefore need a common European response that closes all the holes in legislation, automatic exchange of information, stronger tools and sanctions. I conclude, Mr President, political silence and inaction is complicity, because this blatant injustice poisons democracy.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is another huge scandal, almost comparable to that of a few years ago relating to the Euribor fraud caused to society by huge business banks, the famous too big to fail, which we saved with so much public money, as other Members here have also said, and very often it is they, because of their greatness , to dictate the rules. Well, politics and Europe in particular, the European Union, must react strongly on this issue on the back of tougher legislation on the exchange of information, because it is impossible for these banks to continue to practice both fraudulently and pseudo-legal practices in the management of their tax practices, and there is a need for clarity on this. In order to be clear, the only way is to make transparency and transparency, we need a greater exchange of information. On this issue, my movement, my government and my country agree to do more.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, so here we are again with another tax scandal on the agenda. After Panama, Bahama, Paradise football leagues and other revelations, we have a cum-ex scam that cost EU Member States almost EUR 50 billion. A network of equity traders, tax advisers, bankers, lawyers and investors has conspired to remove – or should I say steal – this amount of money from Member Statesʼ tax coffers. The cum-ex  scheme had only one purpose: to grab tax reimbursement from the state – but for tax that had never been paid. The modalities are now very well known. We are all shocked by the amount of this monumental theft. Mr President, we should be grateful to the group of journalists from Panorama and die Zeit for uncovering this malpractice. But should I ask: what about the law enforcement institutions? Where have they been when these criminal activities were taking place, and why was this kind of swindle at all possible in the EU in the first place? I am calling on this Parliament and on the Commission to take immediate steps in order to eliminate these malpractices.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have to say, this cum-ex scandal is a true scandal of how you can do a robbery against our population, against our state coffers. Taxes that people have paid out of their hard work were stolen by people working in the biggest banks in Europe – lawyers, accountants, advisors. To me, this shows that we need really to do much more in Europe. I want to use an example from this scandal. Germany already discovered, in 2012, that there was a cum-ex scandal. They even started to arrest people. But they didn’t warn the other Member States on the list that they found among these fraudsters. They didn’t warn Denmark, France and the other countries that they were the next in line. And now we have a bill of at least more than EUR 50 billion stolen from the population. So what we need in the EU is a 112 number – an emergency number you can call when you see fraud in your Member State and have tax authorities and the police working together in a coordinated fashion, assisting Member States and stopping these fraudsters once and for all.

name: Martin Schirdewan (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European citizens are tired of the states being deprived of their tax revenues by fraudulent bankers. However, European citizens are just as tired of the fact that politics seems to be powerless.  This time, therefore, we are dealing with EUR 55 billion, which have been stolen from public tax coffers by fraudulent transactions in eleven European countries. This EUR 55 billion is missing in kindergartens, schools, research and development, but also in social security systems. That's what I call theft from society.  What is also scandalous about the recent Cum-Ex scandal is that the German federal government has been aware of these events since 2002, but has not informed its partners until 2015. Watching tax theft by bankers for years, but at the same time enforcing a tough austerity and austerity policy in Europe, is sometimes a very dialectical relationship with the European partnership.  Let us stop these criminal and immoral transactions once and for all! Let us stop tax-driven stock transactions and protect the state budgets from the gangsters in pinstripes! That is what the citizens of Europe expect of us.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the tax system we are now using is maybe well suited for the middle of the last century. Since then the world has changed. It is smaller, it is quicker and it is virtual to some extent. States even now are slow to react to this situation. At best we are filling the holes and sometimes creating new ones. The cum—ex scandal is about sophisticated greedy people, about the bankers and the lawyers, and about victory over tax authorities equipped only with the data and sometimes slow. It is a very sad story and billions were lost. I hope this will finally help us to team up together and start to trim the tax system so that it reflects the reality of the 21st century. If not, our economy will be harmed and public confidence will be lost.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for her excellent work. We need a European FBI against financial crime. We need a European solution. More transparency, yes, but we also need a national response, namely more auditors, more company tax auditors nationally. In many cases, a great many states have begun to get a bit sloppy and lax here, cutting staff here, rather than strengthening them. So more legal rules, but above all more implementation. I have to admit, I'm really shocked. We are already used to the Panama Investigation Committee and all the other committees. But this is once again more or less particularly violent tobacco. It's a veritable tax robbery scandal, crime in pinstripes. I would like to read out a short quote from a meeting of the Cum-Ex specialists: "Those who cannot identify with fewer kindergartens being built because we do such business are wrong here." So, this is so sick that we, as legislators, that the Council, the Commission, are called upon to be much more committed and far-sighted here. So, a European FBI would be appropriate.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: "Mr President, there is a saying in the casino economy that "banking always wins". Unfortunately, this seems to be the current motto of the European Union. How long are it going to take to stop the benches? We are seeing a real fraud of democracy.  In Spain, the Supreme Court has suspended its own judgment, which required banks to pay the mortgage tax, arguing the serious economic and social consequences that this could generate. Do banks address the social consequences when they plunder billions of euros from public coffers? When do you organize your accounts so you don't declare benefits and don't pay taxes? When do they evict families from their homes? We can't keep allowing it, ladies and gentlemen. Those who systematically defraud citizens must have their bank licence withdrawn. Credit must become a public service, with socially controlled banking. It's time to set rules so that this time, at once, whoever wins is the people.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Yes, it is a scandal – we are no longer able to review a new tax fraud in every parliamentary debate, to re-examine it, to consider which committee – fortunately we have the TAX Committee – should look at these files again.  This is undoubtedly the largest tax fraud case in history. Eleven countries are involved. More than EUR 55 billion in taxpayers' money was defrauded and remitted. We therefore call very clearly for all those responsible to be held accountable on the basis of a comprehensive independent and cross-border investigation, to remove all gaps and ambiguities within national systems and to tighten controls, to finally extend the existing European rules on information exchange to capital gains tax and to have strong, dissuasive sanctions mechanisms in place. We must act, act concretely, not just investigate and follow the tax fraudsters.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this Cum Ex scandal, plus one, is absolutely intolerable. It is EUR 55 billion that has been withheld from the public administration and the national states, that is, at the same time that the national states fell mercilessly on taxpayers with a huge tax burden to recapitalise the banking, this same bank engendered tax evasion schemes with this technique of buying and repurchasing shares to evade payment of taxes on dividends. This scandal reveals once again that a serious fight against tax fraud and tax evasion involves questioning, questioning, questioning, two sacred cows of this European Union: the private banking that has to be publicly controlled and the full liberalisation of the transit of capital that has to be controlled.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – I am a member of the Committee on Terrorism and I must say that financial matters take us the most time. Issues relating, in particular, to the financing of various illegal activities which threaten the security of European citizens. Among them are various elements. There are elements of these large euro denominations – EUR 500 – banknotes, commonly known as bin Ladens, but also tax fraud, which we are talking about on this occasion. I believe that the sensitivity of the European institutions in this matter is absolutely insufficient. That, whether we are talking about such an affair or a Vata, or we are talking about special taxes or the removal of funds from countries where certain goods are being worked out, such as Cyprus or tax havens, we are still ineffective and, I stress, late to various criminal groups. This absolutely needs to change.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we must thank the press, because many of the irregularities are unhappy with the press and not the competent institutions. Commissioner, fraud of tens of billions is missing from the budget of the Member States, from the budget of the European Union and from the citizens, after all. What does the Commission propose? Because sometimes the Commission sits and counts certain pieces of legislation from a single state and does not focus on the internal market, on photographing what is happening throughout the internal market, throughout the European Union, because tax evasion is cross-border, they are very well developed mechanisms. And although we have Europol and many other security and verification agencies, nothing is happening. I would like to understand in your reply, Commissioner, what you are proposing concretely now, on this concrete situation - evasion of over 50 billion - and what mechanisms you will use in the future to stop appearing, to prevent these things.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, after the Panama Papers, another scandal, the Cum Ex scandal. They did not pay taxes on wealthy taxpayers, big investors, big banks, banks that were saved with taxpayers' money to which governments imposed taxes in order to save the banks. We have had a short-term transfer of securities in order to have tax relief on dividends. The measures that need to be taken are certainly transparency, exchange of data at European level, and above all the institutionalisation of a European Glass–Steagall Act to separate banks' commercial activities from investment activities, because only with a new European Glass–Steagall Act can we limit fraud of this type.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, one more scandal is added to the many who have come out. This one is fat: about 55 billion euros of fraud to the Ministries of Finance. It cannot be considered a matter of exclusively domestic fraud because there are clearly cross-border elements; and it is particularly scandalous that this occurred in the midst of the era of austerity in Europe and others continued to occur even after the major financial scandals of 2007 and 2008: banks calling for the refund of taxes that they had never paid. This is totally intolerable. So we have to see how we deal with this at European level, because one of the big problems is that national finance ministries do not coordinate sufficiently to give an answer to this phenomenon. Automatic exchange of information is therefore essential, the revision of the Administrative Cooperation Directives is essential and, as my colleague Sven Giegold pointed out, Article 22 of the Regulation on the European Supervisory Authority must be used to initiate a pan-European investigation into this financial crime.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. President Timmermans has just given such an elegiac speech on recent plans. And I have déjà vu again, as I am listening to our debate today. I am reminded of the beginning of our term of office – the Luxembourg scandal, and then we also talked about how the state is pulling money out of the budget. And let us really consider whether our tolerance at the time is not the reason why we need to talk about a similar topic today. This is not a new topic at all. This is firstly because CumEx has been written about many, many months, and even more ago. Secondly, this is not only a matter of people who have been wronged, of the limited budgetary functions of the state, but of the functioning of democracy itself. Because the Lobby Control Institute, a prestigious German institute, wrote about how the omissions of the German state in relation to the fight against such things looked like. So really – as we look for places where democracy is badly functioning, let's start from the top.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, your exchanges this afternoon show that we all share three sentiments. First, a legitimate indignation at these new revelations. These are practices, as many have said, that must be stopped. Second, a sincere and profound recognition of journalists. This is further proof that the investigative press is an essential pillar of a real and vibrant democracy and it is a reminder that no one should attack press freedom in any way. Finally, our common determination to act is also a way of paying tribute to the work of these journalists. In this regard, let me correct what may appear to be a false impression: no, the repetition of scandals is not a sign of our impotence. There is always a time lag between what is revealed and the state of the law. The joint action that we have been taking on a continuous basis in recent years is not in vain, but it is the perpetual race. It's an old story between the constable and the thief. Our fight against tax evasion will never be over because, as I said, the imagination of fraudsters is limitless and the possibilities offered by technology must also be explored. These revelations thus show that fraudsters have been able to take full advantage of different laws between states, the lack of information between them and the specific provisions of bilateral conventions. From that point on, the lessons we public policy makers have to learn from it are that we simply have to put an end to purely national, piecemeal approaches, because it does not work. We are faced with international, European mechanisms and the answer must obviously be international and European. I want to make it clear that we now have rules and tools in place that allow states to alert their counterparts to fraud. It is not a question of means, it is a question of will and attitude. Member States need to understand that tax administration is an increasingly Europeanised area. I will ensure that this message is conveyed to the heads of tax administrations at their next meeting in Brussels. I have often had the opportunity to say this in this House: in order to be real, fiscal sovereignty must be exercised in common, at European level, otherwise we are deprived in the face of these phenomena which are for many cross-border phenomena.  I know that this paradigm shift is difficult for everyone, starting with the Member States, especially when it comes to taxation, because they consider - as we know - that this is one of the essential attributes of their regal power. But it is not a question of renouncing this sovereignty, it is a question of exercising it together at European level in order to work in the general interest of the European Union. It is a question of deciding on a collective approach that is the only one that can offer an answer that lives up to the ingenuity, again very great, of the fraudsters. With a coordinated tax policy, no more holes in our tax laws and finished, so the opportunities for fraud. That is the idea I will carry out when I put forward proposals for the change to a qualified majority in tax matters early next year. It is time to start the debate with the Member States. Several questions have been addressed to me about the possibility of extending the exchange of automatic information to dividends. I think it is a perspective that deserves to be explored. Let us recognise, however, that at this stage, when we are in your mandate in the European Parliament and ours in the Commission, this is something that will have to be dug deeper in time. But I want to tell you that we have already extended this exchange of information a great deal, that many Member States do not use the information they receive from other States and that it is important, even fundamental, to put in place what is already adopted. I do not deny the commission's responsibilities, and both the work of Parliament, the work of journalists, the change of mind on the international stage, have together given us tremendous opportunities to move forward. But still, I say, in particular to Mr Giegold, I appeal again and again to the Member States. Their responsibility for implementing what we have decided, including the completion of what is already proposed - such as the ACCIS project (consolidated common corporate tax base) or digital taxation - is absolutely major. Qualified majority or not, they have a responsibility. To us, institutions that embody the public interest, remind them, and I do so in the Council. I hope that under the Austrian Presidency, which is very active on these subjects, in particular on the CGTA and on digital taxation, we will have final results in this semester, because then it will be too late. I therefore encourage the Austrian Presidency to continue its efforts so that we can mark this progress long awaited by you, ladies and gentlemen, but in reality, above all by the citizens of Europe.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to your comments and to the concerns raised. And yes, you are completely right. We are aware of the seriousness of the affair, its possible repercussions and the financial impacts for the institutions involved. I can only second what the Commissioner said and confirm that the Presidency stands ready to look further into the issue. And thank you, Commissioner, for the encouragement. We are really doing a lot and trying our utmost to reach good results under our Presidency on all points, not least in the matter that you have mentioned.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place during one of the following part-sessions. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This CumEx scandal, plus one, is all titles intolerable. €55 billion was withheld from tax administrations between 2012 and 2015. In other words, even as EU governments fell mercilessly on taxpayers to recapitalise banking, this same bank was creating tax avoidance schemes with exchanges of shares with non-residents in order to avoid taxing dividends. This case reveals once again what we have long advocated. A real fight against tax fraud and evasion necessarily involves questioning and stirring two sacred cows of this European Union: the financial system and the free movement of capital. In this sense, public control over banking and control over capital movements is now fully topical.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul (2018/2885(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for having decided to put this issue on the agenda of your plenary today. I think it is extremely important for Parliament to have its voice heard on this. Let me start by saying something basic and very clear that I think we have to start from, namely that a crime against one journalist, wherever in the world, is a crime against freedom of speech and freedom of information. As such, I would say it is a crime against our societies everywhere in the world, our way of life, in particular in Europe, our principles and our values. It’s a crime against all of us. Three weeks after the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, we now know that he was killed in the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul. Saudi Arabia has now arrested a number of officials in connection with the case, yet too many details about what happened to the journalist are still missing. The confirmation of his death is a first step towards the truth and towards accountability, but the explanations offered so far by the Saudi authorities leave many doubts and many unanswered questions. From day one, we have been asking Saudi Arabia to shed light on the events of 2 October through a full, credible, transparent and prompt investigation. We expect the Saudi institutions to provide all the information they have about the case and to ensure that those responsible are brought to justice. Last week, the Foreign Affairs Council – all 28 Foreign Ministers of the EU Member States – agreed to demand, united, a credible and transparent investigation. Together with the Foreign Ministers of the countries of the G7, we have coordinated our approach, first asking for a credible investigation and, right now at this moment, working on further statements and steps to be taken together. Just a few days ago, I expressed once again, on behalf of the whole European Union and of all our Member States, our expectation for clarity and full accountability. We have also asked Saudi Arabia for full collaboration with the Turkish authorities. We hope that everyone will work towards the goal of establishing the facts. This is the starting point. The investigation must be driven by the search for the truth, and not by geopolitics. We will not merely wait for more clarity or ask for it: we will also continue to act, together with our partners, for achieving clarity. The European Union’s reaction from now on will depend on the next steps taken by the Saudi authorities. We will continue, first of all, to coordinate among ourselves, with united European Union positions, but we will also continue to coordinate with our partners around the world and continue to follow the case and work to coordinate the appropriate reaction. As I said, this will have to be a united one at European level and together with our international partners. The Saudi leadership has promised ambitious reforms for the country. The way this investigation is managed is a very important test in terms of free speech, human rights and the rule of law for all the people of Saudi Arabia. Just a few months ago, our staff at the External Action Service in Brussels welcomed Jamal Khashoggi for a conference on Saudi Arabia and on the situation in the region. We engaged with him on several occasions as a credible and authoritative voice in the debate about his country and the Middle East. In his last op-ed, which was published after his death, he asked for a free and independent platform for Arab voices. Through the years we, as the European Union, have worked precisely to support young and independent Arab voices. We have trained young Arab journalists, we have financed independent media and we have engaged in policy dialogues through initiatives such as Young Mediterranean Voices.  Free speech lies at the core of our values and it will continue to be the basis for our foreign policy. We believe that national interest can never be a justification for curbing freedom of speech. On the contrary, when basic human rights are violated, our countries get weaker. I think this is the voice that needs to be heard at this point in history from the European Union and from this Parliament, united. It’s a point of strength to respect and protect human rights, starting with freedom of speech. It’s not a point of weakness. It’s a point of strength of our societies. (Applause) When fundamental freedoms come under attack there can be no peace, no security and no human development. Repression makes states and societies weaker and not stronger. Jamal Khashoggi had always advocated not only free speech, but also greater tolerance and respect for diversity. Reading some of his words today is quite painful, thinking of the way in which the story ended, but the best way we have to honour his memory is to be firm and determined in asking for the truth and working for the truth – not only for the truth, but also for accountability, which is different both from scapegoating and from revenge. It is important for us to say this now. We will not only ask for justice, but we will also keep working for justice, for free speech and human rights in Saudi Arabia, in the region – in the whole region of the Gulf – and everywhere in the world. (Applause)

name: Tunne Kelam
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, one of the most influential Saudi journalists residing in the US has been killed, in all likelihood brutally murdered. It was a flagrant attack against independent journalism. A week ago the British Times newspaper concluded that it was worse than a murder, it was a mistake. After hiding two weeks behind lies and disinformation, the Saudi Foreign Minister finally admitted that yes, it was a tremendous mistake. While the whole truth has still to be fully revealed, at this moment it is practically impossible to believe that the Saudi Crown Prince was not informed of the murderers’ plan. Stopping arms sales to this country, at least on a temporary basis, is absolutely needed. The moral we cannot escape is the following: in autocratic systems, even under the so-called modern reformers, worse things can still happen. Real reforms can succeed only under democratic transparency and control. A critical Khashoggi could have been an integral part of credible reforms in Saudi Arabia. Instead, he has been brutally cast overboard. Therefore, the democratic world has to reject strongly and unconditionally such behaviour. Saudi Arabia must pay a high price for the tremendous mistake of its present leaders or middlemen.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I trust we all share today the dismay and outrage towards the killing of Jamal Khashoggi. ‘Killing’ – I don’t know whether this is the most appropriate wording to define the crime committed in Istanbul and the horrific manner in which it appears the prominent journalist and opponent has been tortured, murdered and dismembered by agents close to the Saudi regime. This is an unprecedented crime and case in the history of the world, at least since the Second World War. Never, never have we seen such a case!  I also feel the need to emphasise that this is one of a long series of human rights violations and widespread crackdowns by the autocratic and discriminatory regime on prominent activists – journalists and writers, lawyers and human rights defenders – oppression that has intensified since 2017. Finally, I would like to insist on what are probably the two most important points. First, the explanations given by Riyadh are insufficient and absolutely not credible. They are mostly a whitewash of an appalling and flagrant assassination and violation of human rights, and of diplomatic and consular law.  The second: these events ask for a collective, clear and loud response that goes beyond the short-lived international uproar. It is time to reconsider western relations with the Kingdom. Whereas I can only welcome the position of some Member States, as well as economic actors and international organisations, to boycott today’s future investment initiative in Riyadh, what is key is to have real measures to target those responsible beyond the number of operatives which were acting in Istanbul. We will invite all EU Member States to reconsider the export of arms to Saudi Arabia.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, High Representative, as ever more gruesome details emerge surrounding the brutal murder of the Saudi dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the more obvious become the inconsistencies and, basically, the cover-ups in the explanations given by the Saudi authorities. News sources are now reporting that dismembered body parts belonging to Khashoggi have been found, supporting the Turkish claims and their narrative of the events. Clearly, there is more to come and an international investigation into the case is urgently needed, as called for by France, the UK and Germany. I also note the comments made by the British Foreign Secretary in which, pending the investigation, a UK arms embargo has not been excluded. I note also the temporary one already imposed by Germany, much to its credit. We in the West had welcomed some of the recent reforms led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, in a country more often known for its internal social repression and global export of Wahhabi Salafism. However, we have also witnessed a young despot consolidating his power at home and intervening more widely and aggressively abroad, from the Saudi blockade of Qatar and the atrocious bombing campaign in Yemen to the support for jihadists in Syria. The brazenness and the location of Khashoggi’s murder are, however, without precedent, and the use of torture crosses the line which makes this an international crime under the Torture Convention of 1987. Pragmatism, driven by commercial ties, has been the watchword for relations between Saudi Arabia and the West for many decades. It is time now for our common EU values and fundamental human rights also to reassert themselves.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the  revelations about the brutal murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi demand European action so that  perpetrators will be held to account. Additionally, a regime that lies and deceives the international community cannot be trusted to handle war weapons. I applaud Chancellor Merkel’s expressions towards an embargo, but I wish it had been an EU initiative from the beginning. Weʼve called for this in this House four times. Unfortunately, our friends in the EPP and the ECR have always been very reluctant to condemn the human rights violations in Saudi Arabia. Some see the murder of Mr Khashoggi as a tipping point, but I see it as the cumulation of inaction when the human rights of the Saudi people were violated over and over again. Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi continues to suffer in prison and has been flogged for expressing himself. The 50 out of 1 000 lashes administered almost killed him already. Women’s rights activists are facing life sentences, and the kind of intimidation that we see here cannot be masked by the long-awaited so-called freedom for women to drive cars. And many human rights defenders such as Manal al-Sharif have had to flee Saudi Arabia already. The kingdom decapitates people with swords on public squares as a common form of capital punishment – around 150 people a year. Homosexuality is punishable by the death sentence, and so is atheism. We now need human rights sanctions, including a ban on the export of surveillance systems used to track and trace dissidents, and I hope this House will support a strongly-worded resolution. While the Khashoggi case is a game-changer, it would be a mistake to limit the lessons learned only to this specific case. The Khashoggi case is not only a murder, but I fear it turns out to be a suicide.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The Saudi government's statements on the killing of the journalist Khashoggi are completely inadequate. I therefore welcome the fact that you, Mrs Mogherini, have called for a full and transparent investigation. Appeals alone, however, must not be allowed to continue. The killing of Khashoggi is a result of the Saudi ruling house's zero-tolerance policy toward its critics. Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi and many other non-violent political prisoners have been in prison for years for critical expressions of opinion. They must be released immediately. We must not move on to the agenda after the violent death of Khashoggi. The European Parliament has repeatedly called for a ban on arms exports. We must prevent weapons from Europe from being used in war crimes in Yemen. All EU Member States must finally draw conclusions and not only announce but also enforce an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this brutal crime has made some of them drop their blindfolds. But no, it wasn't a mistake or an isolated case: it was a cold-blooded crime of the many Saudi Arabia commits at its borders. Fustigations, amputations, beheadings, stoning, submission of women, juveniles sentenced to death, not to mention the thousands of civilian deaths in Yemen. Saudi Arabia is a feudal, criminal regime, which thinks that with its money it can buy the wills of the entire international community and, until now, experience certainly gives them reason.  Mrs Mogherini, in the face of this ruthless murder, in the face of the genocide of the Yemeni people, listen at once to this Parliament, which has urged it several times to the embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia. Do not pretend that the contradictory versions or the multiple lies of Saudi Arabia are believed. Be brave, promote the European embargo on arms sales at once. Leave the double standard. With facts and not in words, we might still think that this Union defends and protects human rights; if not, our great Quevedo has already said: "Mighty knight is Don Money."

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, the Khashoggi episode is a freezing shower for all those who saw Mohammad Bin Salman as hoping for a new Saudi Arabia, reformist and more respectful of human rights, despite the fact that it had long been clear that the prince was aiming more at cosmetic makeover than substance. Reconstructing exactly what happened on October 2 is difficult. The only sure fact is that Khashoggi entered the Saudi consulate and never came out alive, probably came out quite in pieces, in a briefcase. The usual ballet of statements began immediately. The latest version is that it was a "rogue" operation conducted by the secret services without, of course, Prince Salman and the intelligence chiefs being aware of it. The truth, we all guessed it from the beginning. Never before has we needed a strong signal from us, because in the midst of so many doubts only one thing is clear: Khashoggi was killed also because those responsible believed that they could do it with impunity. Crushing internal dissent works best when it is accompanied by the deafening silence that comes from outside, which, in fact, makes those who dare not dare to protest complicit. Khashoggi is not an isolated case, but a real modus operandi case against dissidents. Kidnappings, extrajudicial killings, enforced disappearances and vicious smear campaigns are sadly common practice. Despite all this, Saudi Arabia inexplicably sits on the UN Human Rights Council. Even in a world of masks and hypocrisy, as ours has become – in other circumstances, turkish rebukes in Riyadh would make us smile – there must be a limit. The king, or rather the prince, is now naked. In the Saudi kingdom, leaf does not fall without him being fully informed. What will be our answer? Will we hide once again behind false indignation, a whisper in a storm, unless we return in a short time to business as usual? How many more Khashoggi, how many more Badawis will we have to tolerate? As long as impunity reigns, as long as the multimillion-dollar contract business triumphs over rights we will have cases like Khashoggi's. Many of you are outraged only today, but we have always said it: it is time to implement a total ban on the export of European weapons. It is time for appropriate sanctions for those responsible. It is time to stop being complicit in this regime.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – (beginning of speech without microphone) ... a little hairy, a little doubtful when you think of making this as a unicum, just think of the KGB, just think of what happens to the opponents in China, in Iran, and then see – given that we obviously also condemn this crime – see from the West, and Europe in particular, consider the public prosecutor of European democracies to be that Erdogan who keeps more than 300 journalists in prison. Your friend Turkey is the world capital of journalists' prisons: 5 sentenced to life imprisonment, 3 000 deprived of the right to work in their profession.  So let us look for this truth, I agree with the High Representative, but let us look for it in all directions. Let us tell the full truth, for example, that this journalist is not the Regeni of the situation: he was a man who, from his point of view legitimately, supported Qatar, supported the Muslim Brotherhood, which is not really a democratic organisation. So let us move forward, let us be clear and ask ourselves who may be the political victim of this attack, perhaps the one who wanted to reform the internal situation in Saudi Arabia in his own way and perhaps very concrete oil interests.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, Saudi Arabia is a country that violates human rights and harshly avenges its defenders, but also those who criticise it. Under this condition, Kasogi's murder could have been part of this reality if it were not for that man's special ties to the United States. So the following questions are asked: Why did the Saudi state order Kasogi's murder? Was Kasogi a mere critic of his country's government, or did he know of other information that might reveal it? Also, the United States secret service knew about Kasogi's murder and, if so, why didn't they notify him?  What matters is that these questions will not be answered, because the United States and Saudi Arabia have special ties, both economic and military. A contract to purchase $110 billion worth of military hardware has recently been signed. So it is more likely that the Kasogi case will be placed on file, because the United States is using Saudi Arabia both against Iran and against terrorism.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, on the basis of the principles we profess, we must express our strongest condemnation for the death of journalist Yamal Jashogui and call, as the High Representative has done, for a credible investigation to make those responsible available to justice. This crime, because of its circumstances, can really compromise the credibility of the reform process and have unpredictable consequences on the international order. Saudi Arabia is the world's leading producer of crude oil, the united States' main partner, a partner of the Union within the framework of the Gulf Cooperation Council, and an inessible player in the already very flammable situation in the region: the wars in Syria and Yemen, the division in the Gulf Cooperation Council and , at the same time, the worst situation for many years in the Middle East peace process. We must support the high representative to provide a coordinated response to the region's crisis, based on our principles, and to smartly prevent Russia, which sells $3.2 billion in arms, from being no longer just the main valedor of Syria and Iran, but rather from becoming the partner or hegemonic player in the region.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the truth is that it is very difficult to speak in this house of such a scabous crime — according to the police, an authorized murder; perhaps a state crime—but our mission is political. We could say that Jashogui is one more of the victims of that medieval Saudi monarchy that persecutes and executes dissidents. The one that hasn't released our Sakharov Prize yet.  But what happens is that Jashogui has become the victim who has shown that what has to change is the game of thrones and clans between Saudi Arabia and Western countries; of course sanctions and stop selling to Saudi Arabia are always significant political gestures.  We know that the truly effective response is to restore the legitimacy and strength of the international order in the face of abuse and aggression, wherever they come from, and that should be the effort of all powers and all European countries: to make a common front — as the high representative has said - to show firmness to those responsible for crimes against humanity in Saudi Arabia , and in Yemen and Syria and Libya. We must urge the Secretary-General of the United Nations to lead a rapid, independent and effective international investigation. The United States should also participate in this effort. It is a good opportunity for your own foreign policy, so far removed at this time from universal values. The whole policy of the European Union must be directed to rebuild the force of international law. We strongly support the efforts of the high representative.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, the scene is truly grotesque. In a country where the press is silenced in all sorts of ways, it happens violently with a Saudi journalist. However, what exactly does the Turkish government know about the totally abject – let there be no doubt – about the totally abject murder of Khashoggi? President Erdoğan did not answer this crucial question again today. Meanwhile, media and politicians in Europe have been stumbling over each other for days in calling for punitive sanctions against the perpetrator, the regime in Riyadh. A responsible consideration of the geopolitical and economic effects of European punitive measures is urgently needed. Further implosion of the Middle East must be avoided. I would like to underline that. That danger, that saw the late Jamal Khashoggi as a convinced Islamist and kindred spirit of the Muslim brothers – see his writings, which I have studied – absolutely not. He saw it differently, and with this political agenda, he served the Washington Post as a columnist. How was it possible – I wonder as a former journalist – a close friend of the late Osama bin Laden on your pages.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr What we have learned so far about the circumstances of the case of the murdered Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi is terrible – and i very rarely agree with the President of Turkey, who does not have a good reputation for human rights. In this case, however, I would also like to stress that it is not enough to blame the security men who carried out the murder. Someone planned, someone ordered. An independent and fair investigation is needed. My thoughts on Saudi Arabia's respect for citizens' human rights have never been high, but now the Saudis have crossed all borders. It is appalling that it is a country with which many EU countries have close ties, not least because of arms exports. I would say that any sale to Saudi at this point is contrary to our common rules. In this House, we have repeatedly called for an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia. Mrs Merkel is honoured that she wants to stop German exports, but it is time for more people to follow suit. And it is time to implement the embargo, Mrs Mogherini. Anything else would, in fact, be shameful.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the despicable murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi should finally allow us to stop turning a blind eye to the barbarity of the Riyadh regime.  When we listen to you, Mrs. Mogherini, we have doubts. Let us not be fooled by the intentions of Turkey, which suddenly becomes a defender of freedom of expression. It took three weeks for the Saudi regime to admit that the journalist had indeed died in the premises of his embassy - let's go on the different versions, developments and information. 18 people were reportedly arrested, several relatives of the crown prince deposed for a simple brawl that went wrong. We're going to make the lampposts pay, or rather the ones who were wrong to get caught. But who is the client? Is the Tiger Squadron a reality? Who does he obey?  Yes, we need an investigation, but independent, international, under the aegis of the United Nations and we must sever relations with this regime which represses, including in blood, its opponents and funds international terrorism and, above all, yes, we must stop selling them weapons in defiance of international law.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, Khashoggi's story could be the plot of a spy story, or a pulp film: it is a story set in a consulate, in which the protagonist is torn to pieces, in which disguises of lookalikes, secret agents and autopsy experts who vivise with rye intervene. Unfortunately, however, we are not talking about Hollywood fiction but about the very sad reality. Yes, because in this unfortunately real affair is the victim, the pain of the family members is real, to whom we offer our condolences, and the main ones are the sponsors. The embarrassing version of events provided by the Saudis, who claim that Khashoggi died as a result of a scuffle, is fictitious. Of course, a scuffle between a 60-year-old and fifteen men who came specially from Riyadh: it is a very credible thesis! The prince, no longer being able to deny Saudi responsibility, now requires, under international pressure, an additional month to carry out the investigation. This suggests two possible scenarios: either the Saudi prince no longer has control of his kingdom or, more likely, he is directly responsible for the tragic events in Istanbul and just wants to buy time. What has happened is clear to everyone: the remains of poor Khashoggi's body have recently been found, but nevertheless, once again, there will be no consequences. Once again we will allow the Saudis to make fun of us, to slam all their brutal inhumanity in our faces, we will allow it in the name of two universally revered deities: the god money and the oil god. Ladies and gentlemen, this case is in addition to countless other human rights violations by Saudi Arabia, present and past. That is why I still wonder how it is possible for Saudi Arabia to still occupy a place on the UN Human Rights Council. This is indeed a scandal, and we have a duty to ask the United Nations General Assembly to take action. In this serious context, Europe should learn to speak with one voice, clear, unequivocal and resolute, avoiding unacceptable leaks by individual states.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: Mr President, it took the assassination of journalist Khashogghi for Western governments to pretend to discover the true face of Saudi Arabia, the opposite of the sympathetic petromonarchy it claims to be.  Last February, the Saudi Foreign Minister, before our Foreign Affairs Committee, engaged in a "taqîya" exercise, praising the crown prince's reform policy for Islam, I quote: "open, inclusive and tolerant". Western chancelleries asked no better than to be fooled in order not to give up their juicy contracts. Thus, when Saudi Arabia openly supported the jihadists in Syria, Western governments at its side preferred to condemn Russia in the fight against terrorists.  The Saudi army is bombing the civilian population of Yemen, our governments continue to deliver weapons to it.  His entry into the Human Rights Council and the UN Commission on the Status of Women had provoked only strong protests.  Without this Western hypocrisy and the sense of impunity enjoyed by Saudi Arabia, this journalist might still be alive today.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, Yamal Jashogui was brutally murdered and quartered at the Consulate of his country in Istanbul. This murder at consular headquarters is an extrajudicial execution, it is state violence executed outside its territory. Yamal was upset and they decided to eliminate him. In addition, murder is another attack on freedom of opinion and expression: Daphne Caruana, Jan Cusack, Martina Kusnirova, another. The murder and persecution of journalists or opinion-trainers is a devastating blow to civil liberties. We call for a rigorous and independent investigation to clarify the facts and punish the culprits. The international connotations of the case are enormous, far beyond what Erdogan said this morning in the Grand Assembly. In this house article 19 Universal Declaration of Human Rights and article 11 of our own Charter oblige and bind us. Our freedom depends a lot on the free press and without borders.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, this morning Hatice Cengiz, Khashoggi's fiancée, sent me a letter that I gave you just now for information. What you have written in this letter is enough to understand what happened in Istanbul, which a committee of inquiry can only confirm. Let us be clear: it is completely ridiculous to claim that 15 men who arrived from Riyadh entered the consulate in Istanbul and tortured and killed a journalist by operating in the dark about the Crown Prince. What has happened is not only a matter of unprecedented gravity but shows, once again, that the changes announced by Bin Salman, with his tour of world capitals, were nothing more than a cover-up as the regime continued to behave in an authoritarian and repressive manner. What has happened now requires the European Union and the Member States, including my own – true, Mr Corrao – to close a realistic political phase and reconsider the framework of diplomatic relations with Riyadh, providing, on the one hand, for the suspension of the arms trade and, on the other, targeted sanctions against the current Saudi leadership. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mr Panzeri this: it will not be enough to issue an arrest warrant for the murderers, but I believe that we also need personalised sanctions for all those who were involved in the action. Do you think that freezing accounts and travel bans, as we do in other countries, with personalised sanctions would be the right approach?

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I am talking about targeted sanctions against the Saudi leadership. I do not have the truth in my pocket, but from what has happened I think I can say calmly that there is a political responsibility, there is a principal. The principal is in Riyadh and so it is somehow important that we get there, find out the truth there and put in place all the sanctions policies against that leadership, using all the instruments that the European Union has at its disposal.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that I do not share the false shock of the brutal murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. If anyone pretends to be surprised, they're a hypocrite. I don't share it because it's no surprise the actions of the secret services of a country - a brutally theocratic Islamist dictatorship.  Saudi Arabia has not once supported groups linked to Islamic terrorism whose methods are no different from those used in the journalist's murder. Let's face it - Saudi Arabia is nothing more than an early version of The Islamic State, which has its international legitimacy. Saudi Arabia is the homeland of Islam's most extreme radical and barbaric doctrine, Lahabism. Saudi Arabia is spreading this Islamism beyond its borders. More than once in this room, I have given examples of how Saudi foundations generously sponsor radical Islam in Europe, from the Balkans to the UK.  It is time for the problem to be clearly and categorically identified. Islamism and radical Islam must be eradicated from Europe. Otherwise, brazen killings like that of a journalist in Istanbul will become more common. It is right, dear, that all these countries here, such as President Macron, clearly declare their attitude and stop selling arms and stop profiting from the bloody petrodollars of the Islamic State.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, when an authoritarian regime appears to be involved in the brutal murder of a citizen in one of its consulates, as seems to have happened with the journalist Mr Khashoggi, democratic governments have two possible reactions: putting human dignity above all or clinging to the economic interests that tie them to this regime. This afternoon, the Spanish Congress has shamefully chosen the latter. The status quo parties, aligned with the interests of the Crown, prefer to protect multi—million euro arms contracts instead of choosing dignity. This is nothing new. Member States have systematically been violating the common position on arms exports to countries such as Saudi Arabia, which use the war machine to violate human rights and prolong conflicts. Ms Mogherini, the European Union and its Member States must opt for dignity. Before arms and business there is life and justice. We must put a ban on arms sales to Saudi Arabia.

name: Jacques Colombier (ENF).
text: Mr President, the Saudi authorities can no longer hide the atrocious truth: journalist Jamal Khashoggi was cut up alive and the disappearance of his body speaks volumes about the horrific fate he suffered, the victim of a murder planned days in advance. The real face of Mohamed Ben Salman, a true darling of the media, politicians and lobbies in Europe, appears to be that of a sinister, bloodthirsty and brutal tyrant, living in the opulence of petrodollars. He has already shown in the atrocious war against the people of Yemen, in the barbaric repressions against his country's Shiite minorities and in the hunt for opponents, such as Raif Badawi, that he is undoubtedly one of the worst incarnations of the power of this real rogue state that is Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia, which promotes radical Islam around the world and funds the construction of radical mosques and whose responsibility for the September 11, 2001 attacks is overwhelming. So instead of focusing on Russia, banish this rogue state that is nothing but an institutionalized Daesh.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The assassination of Jamal Khashoggi is an act of unimaginable bestiality – like from a horror movie. This is proof of the ruthlessness and ignorance that the Saudi regime is being shown to human rights. This must finally have consequences!  The regime in Riyadh must no longer be courted and, above all, the supply of arms must be stopped. We have already heard that today. However, doubts are warranted, and it is to be feared that we will fall back into the usual mode: excitement, sharp criticism, and then succumb again to the lure of Saudi money. That's not going to happen! We do not need a PR-driven revolution like that of the crown prince, but real change, and that was what Khashoggi had in mind. In his last posthumously published article for The Washington Post, he announced the creation of a transnational Arab information platform to end the disastrous cycle of poverty, mismanagement, and lack of education. That was his legacy. That is why we must not give up the belief that there will be an Arab democracy.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The arrogance, ruthless brutality and derisive contempt with which the Saudi royalty organised the murder of Khashoggi have awakened world public opinion. As early as February 2016, this Parliament called for an arms embargo to be imposed on Saudi Arabia. We have repeated this on several occasions since then. For as extraordinary as this one murder stands out, he stands alone. Just think of the war in Yemen, where eight million people are currently at risk of starvation because the blockade does not provide enough food. We must act, Mrs High Representative, Vice-President Mogherini! Now, through an arms embargo, Europe must show that it is drawing a line.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have two points to make. It’s terrible what the Saudis did to Jamal Khashoggi.
