There are no words for this savage killing of a journalist – and I say this as a fellow journalist. But we must not forget how gingerly we have been treating Saudi Arabia for years, and how they practically get – and got – away with anything and everything, regardless of the brutal atrocities they have been committing on their own soil, to their own people, and in Yemen and Qatar, and so on. The second point: it’s all too ironic (if it were not so sad) that we rely on Turkey, of all countries, and on President Erdoğan, of all people, when we discuss the brutal murder of Jamal Khashoggi. I just wonder what all the Turkish journalists may think of us – journalists who were dragged to jail more than two years ago by the same leader who is now our key witness in the Khashoggi case. It’s only logical, therefore, to call for an independent, unbiased international investigation.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, the sinister and macabre circumstances of Jamal Khashoggi's death have placed on the media agenda around the world what, for a long time, that respected Washington Post journalist denounced and the Rasis regime and its allies were trying to whitewash: the vague arrests, repression and attempts at public humiliation of intellectuals and religious leaders disagreeing with Prince Mohammed bin Salman , the country's de facto leader. Madam High Representative, the European Union must condemn this murder and urge the Saudi authorities to reveal the whereabouts of Jamal Khashoggi's body, to allow a credible and transparent investigation into what happened at its diplomatic mission in Istanbul, in a shocking violation of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations and Saudi Arabia's international obligations as a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council. In memory of Jamal Khashoggi, we must also, once again, demand the release of all his colleagues, such as the writer Saleh al Shehi or the blogger Raif Badawi, who pay with prison sentences their legitimate claims for political rights and civil liberties in that country. The arms embargo on Saudi Arabia now becomes, more than ever, a moral and decency imperative.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I will also make it clear that I will give a voice to those mainly colleagues who have not yet had a chance to speak.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative, thank you very much for your strong presentation on press freedom and for the freedom of journalists.  We support that.  Parliament has already twice called on you to enter into dialogue with the Member States on arms exports. Saudi Arabia should no longer receive arms exports, as the Conservatives here in the House have decided. It is now important that we maintain this issue. Even the German Government acknowledges that if one country does not deliver, the other countries are not allowed to deliver. Coherent foreign policy means a coherent arms export policy. Accordingly, I hope that we will succeed in this and that you will support us in calling for us to give Saudi Arabia the European response here together to stop giving armaments to that country, so that we can send out a clear signal. This is also a basic line for the European Parliament, which we are also following with the arms export control reports.  I would be very pleased if you could take this message out of the House.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the work of a journalist has become dangerous. According to the Committee to Protect Journalists, 64 journalists have already been killed around the world this year. One of them is Khashoggi, who was murdered at the Saudi-Arabian consulate in Istanbul. It is of the utmost importance that an open investigation into Khashoggi's death be carried out on a fast schedule, so that the course of events can be clarified and those responsible for murder brought to justice to answer for their act.  It is in no way acceptable for journalists' work to be disrupted in different ways, even by murder in extreme cases. Freedom of the press is a very important value that must be defended. I therefore hope that Parliament will give its strong and clear support to the investigation into this and the murders of all other journalists.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Mogherini, you rightly call for an investigation into the murder of Journalist Khashoggi, an open investigation, but that is not enough. EU countries must commit themselves not to sell arms to Saudi Arabia. It's the least. Now the EU's values are in the pound. Do we value human rights and freedom of the press? Or is it the most important thing to get oil and money to talk? This murder has been brutal. We do not yet know all the details, but everything we have heard is something that cannot be left unpunished.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we condemn this terrible murder, we condemn the murders of human rights defenders, journalists, lawyers, people, men and women, writers. We condemn the double hypocrisy of the photos of the King of Spain, which is photographed with the Saudi prince; we condemn that there are governments and that there are Parliaments that are able to look the other way when you see these tragedies, when you see these massacres on Yemen's civilian population.  While some are taking pictures, while Mrs Mogherini is asking for common resolutions with which our group fully agrees, while Mrs Merkel already breaks a spear in this battle by moving tab, what does Spain do? We want to know, because they are the states with the greatest involvement.  And that is why we are also calling for the European Union, at the next Meeting of the United Nations, at the meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Council, to present a Resolution on the situation of human rights defenders, which also establishes a sanctions regime precisely against these abuses. Killing is a crime, but putting a blindfold on your eyes too.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, The murder of Jashogui is not just any murder, it is a murder of state. It's no coincidence and it's not an isolated case. It is one of many cases that demonstrate the brutal dictatorship that is Saudi Arabia; a brutal dictatorship that is a preferred partner in the purchase of European weapons. So what do we do? We made nice statements. We have drawn up statements not to sell arms to Saudi Arabia, which bombs civil society in Yemen. But are they fulfilled? We're still selling guns to Saudi Arabia. We have seen how the Spanish government continues to sell arms to Saudi Arabia. We need a common position so that arms are not sold from Europe to Saudi Arabia, so that measures can truly be taken that can stop what we are seeing, which is this brutal dictatorship. We must also investigate the commissioners, such as Mr Bourbon, who are engaged in doing business on behalf of all with this dictatorship. You have to take sides once and for all.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, this murder is unacceptable. But what is most unacceptable: the death of a journalist, Muslim brother, or the millions of deaths in Iraq in an illegal war that we had approved? Turkey, which eliminates its political opponents more discreetly and which we continue to support? The silent deaths in Mrs. Clinton's entourage, which no one talks about but which have been eliminated? Colleagues, there should be no one-sided condemnations. You would be more credible if your indignations were directed at any regime that murders its opponents, and believe me, there are many state crimes.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Parliament for the quite strong and united voice that I’ve heard from different groups and different national backgrounds that send the same message. This very much supports and strengthens the work and the words that weʼve been doing and saying in recent weeks, namely that we want to know the truth, that we want justice, and that we will not settle for anything less. We will continue to demand a full, credible and transparent investigation. As this Parliament was debating this murder, we released a common G7 statement going exactly in the same direction, which I think is a good message of unity and strength. We, as the European Union – and myself personally – have been very explicit so far, and we will continue to do so. We are also united. As you know – and as some of you have said – individual Member States have either taken steps or indicated that they would be willing to take steps. Some have decided to withdraw their participation from events in Saudi Arabia and have announced other possible measures. Collectively, I believe that, as the European Union and in the Council in particular (so here I would have to cross the Chamber and sit on the other side), collectively we will have to monitor the situation as it continues to evolve in the coming days – hopefully not weeks – and decide on any measure to be taken collectively, as the European Union, based on, first and foremost, the steps that are taken by the Saudi authorities to establish the truth and to bring those responsible to justice. As I said, accountability, not revenge or any fig leaf that could hide real responsibilities. I can also point to the fact that those of you who have taken the floor come from different political groups and different countries. Most of you come from parties that have a majority in the national governments. Maybe there is something you can also do when it comes to your national governments’ positions. It’s true that there are different attitudes among Member States at the moment on some of the measures. I notice that there are also different attitudes within government coalitions in single countries that are quite evident in this Chamber. So we can all work on more unity, and I think we have the duty to do so in the coming days: to react properly, rationally, united and in coordination with our international partners. I also want to thank the Parliament for a second reason, and I will finish with that. This debate was important, but the constant focus that you help us to put on freedom of speech and the support we give – not only to journalists around the world, but also to human rights activists, civil society organisations, and to political opposition in some cases – is vital. This will remain at the core of our foreign policy, with one key element that some of you mentioned today and that to me is really vital, namely that this is done, and will continue to be done, in the case of the European Union, regardless of geopolitics. It’s not because we like one country more than another; it’s not because one country is more, or less, credible than another that we will stay more silent. We will continue to support civil society, human rights, journalists and activists everywhere in the world, and we will continue to denounce and to oppose all measures against a free, open society everywhere in the world. We will continue to engage in every situation where freedom and human rights are under attack, whoever the victim, wherever it takes place and whatever the country. (Applause)

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 25 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is deplorable that the EU has not had a clear, united and firm position, as soon as there have been reports of the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The assassination of journalist Khashoggi results from the perception of total impunity instilled in the Saudi dictatorship, right from the outset by its American and European allies. Impunity continues even after Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman kidnapped Lebanese Prime Minister Saad Hariri in 2017 and the French President's intervention was needed to rescue him.  It is high time to put an end to the cover-up and collusion with the Saudi outlaw regime. This Parliament and the whole EU must demand an independent investigation, under the responsibility of the United Nations, which determines who was responsible for the murder of Jamal Khashoggi and forces them to stand trial by an international tribunal. All esbirros already identified as having been involved in the murder, including that of Mohammed Bin Salman, must be on the list of personal sanctions, including asset freezes and bans on entry into the EU. European governments must immediately stop the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, which is scandalously violating its own binding Common Position on arms exports.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – An independent and transparent international investigation must be launched to clarify the circumstances of the death of The Saudi Journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed at the Consulate in Istanbul, saudi Arabia, and an international response must be taken to the case. The culprits must be identified and prosecuted before a recognised, credible, independent and impartial court. If the saudi authorities' involvement in the disappearance and killing of a journalist is clear, the EU and the Member States must be prepared to impose sanctions on Saudi Arabia, such as a visa ban and the freezing of the assets of those responsible for the murder. The EU Council needs to discuss an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia from EU countries. A ban should also be imposed on the export of surveillance systems and other dual-use items used to suppress the population to Saudi Arabia. The EU must hold talks with Saudi Arabia on its human rights and fundamental freedoms issues and saudi arabia's alarming behaviour in the wider Middle East region, including Yemen. Khashoggi's murder case is extraordinarily brutal, but unfortunately many human rights activists, journalists, lawyers, bloggers and writers have been the victims of the persecution of the Saudi authorities. It's inside and around the country. Saudi Arabia must accelerate social and political reforms and respect human rights. The EU must also continue to call for a moratorium on the death penalty.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – We are facing another nationally ordered murder, where istanbul is the venue. Not Bratislava, Valletta, or Sofia. And in this context, there are also some links to the state-commissioned murders in Salisbury. Such governments, rooted in the Middle Ages, should not enjoy the support of societies founded on the foundations of freedom, equality and brotherhood. At the same time, the world is tough, and the economic growth mantra also requires arms exports. This is both due to geo-strategic considerations and to broadening the opportunities of the labour market. I would recall, however, that both Iran, Russia and Saudi Arabia, which freely take their foreign nationals to assassinate, are, above all, petro-dollar countries. And that's why we don't have to start with a ban on arms sales to them, but a ban on Gazprom and Aramco. And given the circumstances surrounding the last abominable crime, we should instead impose export restrictions on crops – Husqvarna, Stihl and Hilti sawn producers should see where they sell their goods....

name: Puhemies.
text: – The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the Azov Sea (2018/2870(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament for keeping a strong focus on the security situation around the Black Sea after the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula. We do not and we will not recognise the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula to the Russian Federation.  It is first and foremost a matter of principles, values – principles and values that all European nations agreed in Helsinki in 1975. We all agreed to the basic principle that our frontiers cannot be changed by military force. And this is a principle, it is a value, on which our common living together is based, but it is also a fundamental interest of all Europeans, because this is the foundation of peace and security on our European continent.  When this principle is violated, as it has been, we are all less secure in our continent and the events in the Sea of Azov are a demonstration of this. When the basic rules of peaceful coexistence are disregarded, instability and tensions are bound to rise. The construction of the Kerch Bridge between the Crimean Peninsula and the Russian Federation took place without Ukraine’s consent and it constitutes another violation of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. On top of that, the bridge hinders the passage of vessels to Ukrainian ports, to the Azov Sea.  Six months ago, Russia started to apply a new inspection regime for cargo vessels coming from Ukrainian ports in the Azov Sea or heading towards them. These inspections lead to long delays, which have increased dramatically over the past months. This has direct consequences on shipping costs, not only for Ukrainian exporters but also for vessels flying a European Union Member State flag. So far, more than 200 vessels, under both Ukrainian and international flags, have been affected by these controls by Russia, which in some cases lasted several days.  Even more worrying, tougher controls on naval traffic in the strait have come in parallel with the militarisation of the Azov Sea. Russia has recently started deploying military vessels to the area in significant numbers and Ukraine has partially responded with an increased military presence.  Let me recall that the Azov Sea used to be almost fully demilitarised and that Ukraine and Russia have signed a cooperation agreement on the use of the Sea of Azov and the Kerch Strait. This agreement implies that disputes between the parties are to be resolved through consultations and negotiations. We appreciate that Ukraine is seeking justice in international courts, such as the ongoing case under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.  When international law is violated, when Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity are violated, the European Union stands by the people of Ukraine. We immediately condemned the construction of the Kerch Bridge without Ukraine’s consent, in July. The Council added six entities involved in the construction of the bridge to the list of those subject to restrictive measures over actions that undermine the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.  A militarisation of the Azov Sea is in no one’s interest and it can only destabilise the delicate security situation in the wider Black Sea region. And let me remind us all that the Black Sea is a European sea and we do not want to witness yet another military build-up in our immediate region. So we will continue to push for the respect of international law and conventions, and to support Ukraine in these challenging circumstances. I am sure I can count on the support of this Parliament in this work we are doing.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Madam Vice-  President/High Representative, blatant violations of international law by the Russian Federation are nothing new. Since 2014, the EU has been able to unite itself in the response to them. But the creeping annexation of the Azov Sea and partial blockade of all the Ukrainian ports is one more serious challenge to our determination to uphold the European peace order. It is a direct concern of EU security and commercial interests, as the financial losses directly concern also EU merchants. But it is obviously more serious than a commercial and legal issue. The situation in Azov gradually turns into one more open conflict waiting to happen. The EU so far has not been up to this challenge, projecting weakness and disinterest rather than strength and determination. At the very least, you, Madam Vice-President/High Representative, I thank you for the statement you made today and I expect you to join Ukraine in using all diplomatic action and international legal procedures to counter the hostile Russian actions in Oslo.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, High Representative, the construction of the Kerch Bridge and the developments in the Sea of Azov are yet another offensive by Russia against the sovereignty, security and territorial integrity of Ukraine and are a clear violation of international law. It is beyond question that, after the illegal annexation of Crimea, after backing the separatists in Eastern Ukraine, after the suspension of gas supplies and after unlawful elections in the occupied territories and cyber-warfare, that this is an additional move by Russia to destabilise Ukraine from all corners. The Socialists’ and Democrats’ Group once again stands by Ukraine and calls for EU unity and determination in managing this issue. The situation must be reversed and the governance of navigation in the Sea of Azov must return to the basics of international maritime law. The EU should act as a mediator between Kiev and Moscow and avoid further escalation. It is in the interests of the Member States to have free navigation in the Sea of Azov and to avoid further militarisation there, as has taken place in the Black Sea, placing NATO’s entire eastern flank and the security of Member States, including the Baltic countries, Romania and Bulgaria, heavily at risk.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, during the Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) mission to, amongst other areas, the eastern part of Ukraine, including Mariupol and Talakivka, we were able to see with our own eyes the gravity of the situation in the Sea of Azov region. The draft joint resolution that we are able to present to Parliament describes precisely this situation. I would like to thank my colleagues for this.  The aggressive posture of the Russian Federation in the Azov Sea area turns our attention to yet another pattern that this country uses to deny access to territories. I am well aware of this. It happens in the Vistula Lagoon in Polish territorial waters. It has happened in many areas close to the Baltic Sea and I would also like to turn the attention of my colleagues to the denial, or partial denial, of access to seaports by Nord Stream 2. It is also an important factor added to this project.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, more than 10 000 lives have been lost in eastern Ukraine. Almost two million peaceful Ukrainians have had to flee their homes as refugees. As if that were not enough, Putin is continuing and has now moved his offensive to the Sea of Azov. With his personal approval ratings plummeting in Russia, it is only natural that the master of the Kremlin should be looking for more outside enemies. Throughout the ages, this pretext has been well tested by Russian tsars and comrades. Just as Stalin started his political career by robbing bourgeois on Russian trains, so is Putin now raiding Ukrainian and foreign ships, including the ones under EU flags. If not properly countered in time, sooner or later such hostile practices will be treated by the Kremlin as a sort of approval to be used in other waters. The only response to this blatant violation of bilateral agreements and international law must be additional restrictive measures against an aggressive Kremlin.  The situation in which the illegal bridge is constructed with the participation of EU companies, thus undermining EU restrictive measures, is pathetic and unacceptable. The EU must come up with specific legal instruments to deal with this. We need to have an independent EU legal authority empowered to look into cases where EU companies – or persons or countries – have violated our own decisions in place. Those in the EU found to be in breach of the EU’s sanctions must be penalised themselves. To conclude, it is regrettable to see how Putin is able to turn everything upside down. Throughout the centuries, people across the globe have been proud of building bridges. And then along comes Putin, who transforms the ‘bridge-building’ narrative into another form of aggression against a neighbour.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank mrs Mogherini for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The development in the Sea of Azov must be seen in connection with what has happened since the Russian invasion and the beginning of the occupation of Crimea. Russia has developed Crimea into a major military base, and this development – the militarization of Crimea – is far from over. That is why we must take very seriously what many commentators call Russia's gunboat policy in the Sea of Azov. I very much share Mr Bostinaru's reference to our problems, our common problems on the eastern flank. I would like to propose six points for consideration: in my opinion, the OSCE's mandate should be extended to monitor the situation in the Sea of Azov. In my opinion, it is essential that the European Union strongly and clearly support Ukraine's legal position in all instances – at the UN, in the OSCE and also in international courts. The European Union must ensure that there is no technical and military cooperation with the Russian Federation, which may also strengthen the operational capability of the Russian navy. In my opinion, it is essential for the EU to consider how projects can strengthen the ports of Mariupol and Berdyansk. And the EU and NATO must clarify whether they can prevent further escalation through escorts and presence in the region. In any case, new sanctions should be discussed.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the Sea of Azov is actually the Gulf of the Black Sea between Crimea and the southern Russian steppe. In its surroundings it is spread out beautiful black-earth and when viewed from the plane it looks very idyllic. Everyone who knows the name of one of the private armies, battalion Azov, has completely different impressions. The destruction of high-voltage masts bringing electricity to Crimea and the crossing of the canal through the Perekop isthem – these are just two examples of the so-called good work done by this or similar units.  It is not clear to me which governments of the European Union countries are interested in escalating tensions in this part of the world. Please stop these attempts to start another senseless conflict and contribute to the re-establishment of peace in this part of the world. I understand that, for some colleagues, the Sea of Azov is far away, but be aware that this is part of Europe, which is less than an hour's flight from Romania or Bulgaria, that is, from the territory of the EU. I therefore ask you not to allow, as in the recent past, to fight hard again in these places.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Madam High Representative, the rising tensions in the Sea of Azov have a simple cause: the decision of the United States, announced at the end of August, to increase its arms deliveries to Ukraine and in particular to its navy. Ukraine, the failed government of a coup, wants NATO to conduct maneuvers in the Sea of Azov, in violation of the 2003 Russian-Ukrainian treaty. These decisions show that Washington, like Kiev, is seeking a confrontation with Russia, in defiance of the Minsk agreements. Once again, the European Union is complicit in this rise to extremes by supporting NATO and its recent military exercises in Ukraine. And we have, logically, on the one hand, the denunciation by the Ukrainians of their treaty of friendship with Russia of 1997 and, on the other hand, the denunciation by the United States of the treaty that limits the Euromissiles. All this to make Europe a new field of nuclear confrontation East-West. The European Union says it promotes peace, but actually encourages war in Europe.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, a few days after NATO, the situation in the Azov Sea and the Black Sea is also being discussed in the European Parliament. It was to be expected. It is an area with energy sources and pipelines, but also a key role in Russia's military encircling the European Union and the United States, and with a NATO base in the context of their escalating rivalries and with the withdrawal of the United States from the nuclear arms agreement. In the big picture, the same strategy includes the intervention of the Euro-NATO in Ukraine, with a government also supported by Nazis. In the Balkans, by strengthening their presence with the unacceptable agreement of the Prespas, while the change of borders continues, as in Kosovo. The NATO fleet is invited to the Aegean Sea, other military bases are created throughout Greece by the SYRIZA-ANEL government. The knives are out, the people are in immediate danger. The only solution is solidarity, the common struggle against the plundering of monopolies, which a spark is enough to throw the peoples back into a generalized conflict.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Once again, I note that the Moscow group is the victim's fault for his situation. I do not think we can let that go through. I believe that the treaty of friendship that was concluded at the time has already been obsolete by Russia's military aggression. We should examine whether the 2003 agreement declaring the Sea of Azov to be a kind of inland lake between Ukraine and Russia might weaken Ukraine's legal position and whether UNCLOS, that is to say the international rules, is better for Ukraine's legal position.  We must insist to Moscow that our merchant ships are no longer checked there as necessary and that waiting times are no longer there, because time is money. We have to support our ships, which are on shipands waiting for them to be controlled, and we call on Russia to put an end to the practice that has been in place.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I can only agree with most of the speakers in this House. I also believe that we must show a very clear position on what is happening there in the Sea of Azov. It is not about any bilateral problem, it is about international law. It is about our solidarity with the people of Ukraine. It is in our own interest that the ships flying the EU flag are not unduly there. That is why it is absolutely right that we ask the High Representative to use all her means to promote an improvement in the situation there. Don't be alarmed, Rebecca Harms, I would sign the first four of the six points immediately. I am glad that we did not immediately resort to sanctions again. But the Russian side must know: we are serious. We want to talk, but it is right.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, the tensions in the Sea of Azov are yet another example of Russia’s expansionist campaign to destabilise Ukraine politically and economically. Since Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea in the Black Sea in 2014, Ukraine’s Azov ports, principally Mariupol, are now responsible for handling 80% of the country’s maritime exports. Journeys that before could be made in a day are now taking up to a week, as the result of Russian restrictions. Russia seeks to defend many of these as being necessary for the security of the newly constructed Kerch Bridge linking mainland Russia to Crimea, the construction of which is, in itself, a violation of Ukraine’s territorial integrity and sovereignty. Therefore, I welcome the Council’s decision to extend restrictive measures to entities involved in its construction. With ever-increasing militarisation of the Sea of Azov, we must ensure that this cannot become a flashpoint for further conflict in future. NATO recently highlighted the need to continue with the political support that the alliance is offering to Ukraine, helping to modernise the Ukrainian armed forces and security institutions.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, I believe that Russia's intentions are clear: it is trying to deteriorate the social and economic situation in south-eastern Ukraine and to create the conditions for the establishment of a future land corridor leading to Crimea. Indeed, I believe that the Kremlin is no longer content with the forced integration of the peninsula, its isolation from Ukraine; now Russia also wants full control of the Sea of Azov. In doing so, it does not shy away from obstructing, among other things, international trade. I am thinking, for example, of the random inspections of the Russian security services, which cause delays and cost Tens of thousands of euros to European boats, especially Romanian and Bulgarian boats.  In this context, I believe that we must be united and help the Ukrainian partners to use all diplomatic and legal channels to deal with these Russian pressures.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, not satisfied by annexing Crimea and supporting rebels in eastern Ukraine, Russia is now trying to choke Ukraine’s economy. Russia’s blockade is impeding civilian and maritime traffic, against international law. I fear military force will neither prevent a potential invasion nor de-escalate the situation, so therefore, High Representative, I urge you, if you have a moment to listen, to engage in mediating in this crisis and to revive a serious peace process. With Ukraine’s election campaign soon in full swing, time is of the essence. Both sides will soon expect more political gain from further escalation. So my questions to you, High Representative, are: are you considering a UN maritime peacekeeping operation to maintain freedom of maritime movement in the Sea of Azov? Maybe a neutral third country could be responsible or involved. Secondly, reducing tensions at sea could help restart a process for the political situation in Donbass.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank High Representative Mogherini for a very clear and strong statement based on principles, and this is an ideal point for Parliament to support this.  Systematically stopping merchant vessels in the Sea of Azov sea gives a signal that Russia is unilaterally expanding its control there. We can see it as a creeping attempt to annex the waters of Azov and turn the sea into a sort of Russian internal lake, and this in a situation where most of Ukraine’s exports are passing through the Azov Sea ports. Russia’s overtures to expanding its control over Ukrainian territories and borders in this indirect but systematic way are most alarming. In this situation, the EU is once more called upon to demonstrate its strong, unanimous and unconditional support for Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Federica Mogherini, with her aggressive action in the Azov Sea, which once again focuses on ukraine's sovereignty and, in particular, with the construction of a bridge in the Kerch Strait, which restricts navigation in these waters, Russia is reinceable in its project of geopolitical destabilisation and defiance of international rules. We are aware that the sanctions so far have not yet produced the desired effects. Nevertheless, it is not possible to react to Russia's disruptive actions with political statements only, so the restrictive measures announced by the Council against some entities involved in the construction of the Kerch bridge are relevant. The European Union should support and encourage the legal path that Kiev is exploring, in particular, the complaint made by Kiev under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. Along the same lines, the proposal to strengthen the mandate of the OSCE's special monitoring mission makes sense so that it also covers tensions in the Azov Sea. The European Union must therefore adopt an energetic stance, retaliating with concrete measures, always taking care to discourage decisions on both sides that could lead to military escalation, but without hesitation in its support for what is arguably the weakest part, Ukraine.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, here we are again, speaking about the threat posed by Russia. The security of the Azov Sea is linked to the security of the Black Sea and EU security in general, not only Ukraine. The further militarisation of the Azov Sea area, the construction of the Kerch Bridge without the consent of Ukraine and the restrictions on maritime transport once more show that Russia wants to undermine the sovereignty of Ukraine and test how far it can go before the EU can react. As President Putin does not seem to be really interested in dialogue, I urge the Member States and the EU to act. First, we need to extend the sanctions to include the companies that use this infamous Kerch Bridge as well. Such illegal actions cannot bring economic benefits to Russia. Secondly, the Mariupol region still needs more assistance from the EU, especially now while it is under even more military and economic pressure from Russia.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I very much welcome the fact that, in this case, we are also discussing situations that are hardly reflected in public perception, but which have an extremely important geopolitical significance. Russia's increasingly aggressive and protectionist behaviour in the Sea of Azov is one of these and a continuation of the expansionist policy that we have seen in recent years and which we condemn in the strongest possible terms. Today, it is a bitter reality, as we were able to foresee at the beginning of the construction of the bridge over the Kerch Strait in 2016: the comprehensive and targeted inspections of ships, including under the European flag, lead to costly delays and are solely due to Russia's long-term goal of bringing international trade in Ukrainian ports to a standstill. We must ensure that the destabilisation of the region is stopped. Russia must abide by the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, comply with its obligations under international law and lift controls in order to restore the free movement of goods.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the quiet escalation of the situation in the Sea of Azov over the past year requires our utmost attention. First of all, while ignoring international law on close and bilateral agreements between Ukraine and Russia, Russia proceeded with the construction of the Kerch Bridge. This constitutes yet another violation of Ukraine’s territorial integrity and aims at limiting economic activity in Ukrainian ports. The recent concert of illegal activities might have a trade character, but it has the clear political objectives to endanger Ukrainian ports and solidify Russian economic and military presence in the Azov Sea, and by extension the Black Sea, and to transform the Azov Sea into an internal lake of the Russian Federation.  We have to be clear and vocal in our opposition to these activities. Our condemnation should concern also the overall intensification of the military presence in the Black Sea, otherwise we risk the opening of yet another front in our neighbourhood, this time with maritime dimensions. This should be prevented.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of Russian operations and ship blockades, the profits of the Ukrainian Azov ports of Mariupol and Berdiansk have decreased by 30% over the last period. After the illegal annexation of Crimea, up to 80% of Ukraine's exports are now routed through these ports. Russia's actions on the Sea of Azov have a clear goal. Further economically and socially subvert Ukraine. But military targets are even more serious. Positions are being building for a possible attack on Ukraine. The Russian army is building a naval base in the Sea of Azov in the occupied territory, which is called Obryv. Russia's illegal operations on the Sea of Azov must be strongly opposed. We can prevent a further sharpening of the situation by an international naval operation led by the United Nations or the EU, or by imposing sanctions on Russian ports in the Sea of Azov. Ukraine cannot be left alone.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Dear President, what Russia is working on in the Azov Sea is a continuation of aggression against Ukraine. Russia's actions in the Kerch Strait result in losses not only for EU Member States Such as Romania, Bulgaria and others, but also for Turkish vessels. This is a maritime blockade by Russia aimed at causing even greater tensions in the region, as much as even greater economic losses for Ukraine. The ports of Mariupol and Berdiansk are the two main ukrainian steel and grain export ports in the Azov Sea. The losses they suffer are enormous. Ukraine is considering terminating the bilateral agreement with Russia, which has been in force since 2003, on the status and use of the Azov Sea, because this agreement on the Russian actions we are discussing is no longer meaningful. International maritime law would then be in force, and we, the European Union, should ensure compliance with its requirements. If not, sanctions against Russia are even tougher than they have been so far. We should pay more attention to that region and the militarisation of the Azov Sea.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Russian activities in the Sea of Azov are, of course, illegal actions against Ukraine, they are part of the warfare against Ukraine. But they are more than that. This is a violation of the freedom of the seas: it violates international laws; it is a demonstration that Russia does not respect the order of the international community. It is an action against us all. It is an action against European sea vessels. And, of course, we need to react because if we can’t demonstrate to Russia that it is not acceptable for it to break international laws in the Sea of Azov we are opening the way to further such action by Russia in other parts of the world and also directed at the European Union and its Member States. Madam President, High Commissioner, we need to be firm regarding sanctions and firm in telling the Russians that we do not accept this – not in the Sea of Azov and not anywhere else.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, once again we are here to speak of a country and a people fallen into the worst of miseries, the disintegration of an entire nation.  Since the illegal annexation of Crimea in March 2014, we have seen a constant militarisation of the entire area and a number of Russian aggressions aimed at the economic strangulation of Crimea and the destabilisation of Ukraine. What is happening in the Sea of Azov is part of this strategy. After devastating tourism and agriculture, the foundation of the Crimean economy, Mr Putin now wants to expand his control over trade and navigation of the Azov Sea by blocking merchant ships trying to reach the ports of Mariupol and Berdyansk.  What is happening in the Kerch Strait threatens not only the security of Ukraine, but also NATO's freedom of movement in the area of political stability in the Black Sea region where Russia regularly and provocatively conducts large-scale military exercises. Madam High Representative, there is a need to ensure the effective implementation of the restrictive measures agreed at the European Council, and Ukraine needs us Europeans more than ever. Thank you very much.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, today the ports of Eastern Ukraine are emptying. Putin has decided to take de facto after the illegal annexation of Crimea, including the Sea of Azov. In recent months, Putin has once again sought to re-enerish the conflict with neighboring Ukraine in order to further destabilize it. After the construction of the Crimean Bridge over the Kerch Strait, he thinks it is time to expand his sphere of influence at sea. And time and time again, Russia flossssing every international rule. He is not concerned about the fact that he is thus fighting the European Union. Madam High Representative, tensions are rising at the fragile back gate of the European Union. The slightest incident could put the fire on the fuse. And the possible consequences for both Ukraine and the European Union are incalculable. I thought it was an interesting debate and I support the concrete proposals of, among others, my colleague Rebecca Harms, whom she has put here. And I support you, Madam High Representative, for the pressure you are exerting on the Russian Federation, with any diplomatic pressure you exert there. I am counting on you to do so with the necessary decisiveness and clarity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, once again, there is tension in Russia's relations with Ukraine because of the events in the Azophical Sea. Ukraine accuses Russia of obstructing access to the Azophic Sea ports, Ukrainian ports, of merchant ships crossing the Kurtz Strait. Of course, she, for her part, has kept a Russian fishing boat and a tanker. At the same time, it has increased its naval presence in the Azophical Sea with two gunboats and by the end of the year plans to establish a naval base in the region.  This tension also involves the United States, which, in order to serve its strategic interests, is trying to contain Russia and not allow it to supply energy to the countries of the Middle East, but also to some countries of the European Union. This whole situation can easily get out of hand, because let us not forget that the Azov Sea is Russia's only maritime access to the South.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much want to welcome today's debate, which has been extremely interesting and is, to some extent, a response to all those who question sanctions against Russia in Europe and who say that sanctions should be lifted. Alone in the Czech Republic, where I am from, I feel in some extremist political forces that we should be more accommodating towards Russia. Today's debate clearly shows that, on the contrary, the EU must be more forceful, it must be tougher, and that the situation in the Sea of Azov described here today is another form of aggression against Ukraine. This time, it is essentially a form of trade blockade that significantly restricts the form of exports of Ukrainian goods from Ukrainian ports. I therefore join those, Madam High Representative, who beg you to take a hard line on Russia. It is not possible to make compromises on this issue that harm Ukraine and the EU's values and positions.

name: József Nagy (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Mrs Mogherini, Thank you for your account of the situation with the construction of the Kerchi Bridge. I believe that the Black Sea is a European sea and the Sea of Azov is an inseparable part of the Black Sea, which Russia cannot unilaterally own, even under the pretext of building a bridge.  This harms not only Ukraine, but also the interests of other EU and non-EU countries. Very briefly, I would just like to say that I support the proposal, the monitoring of the situation, the european Commission's sending out of an expert group to evaluate the specific economic consequences. Assess the costs of obstructing traffic, stalling, molesting commercial vessels and also calculate the reduction in traffic at Ukrainian ports. I think that this data could still be good in our negotiations with Russia.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I am here also for the next debate so I will continue. First of all, let me thank the Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) and all its members, and in particular Anna Elżbieta Fotyga, for the work done in this regard, the visits made and the previous exchange of views we had. That was not with me personally but with our services, on 11 October, and, it helped to prepare for this plenary and helped with the work we are constantly doing on this issue. Keeping the focus on this is essential, for different reasons, and the speakers all mentioned them. First of all, for our principles and values; and then for Ukraine’s sovereignty, and also for the economy – both that of Ukraine and that of the European Union, as the speakers have emphasised – and for our collective security. I think we have many good reasons for keeping a close eye on what is happening in the Sea of Azov and we will continue to react appropriately and in a united manner. For this, the support of Parliament will continue to be key. Let me assure you, too, that part of the next EU-Ukraine Association Council that I will chair in a couple of months from now – together, I believe, with the Ukrainian Prime Minister – will also focus on to how to address this issue in the best possible manner, and what kind of support the European Union can give to Ukraine in this context. Among other issues on which we are supporting Ukraine, this is also extremely important.  I would like quickly to touch upon a couple of points that were raised, not probably all of them, but a couple of them. Some of you referred to the need to uphold international principles, including the international courts and legislation. As I said at the beginning, we appreciate that Ukraine is seeking justice in the international courts. You know that there is an ongoing case under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). So we trust the international courts, and in this case UNCLOS, as we always do, upholding international jurisdictions. The second point concerns the sanctions. As I mentioned before, we included new persons on our sanctions list in relation to the construction of the bridge. Some of you referred to the implementation of these sanctions. As you know very well, it is for the European Council, in unanimity, to adopt the sanctions and measures, but then it is for Member States to monitor their implementation and to take appropriate measures if needed. Obviously, as the Commission, we have our own say in pushing this monitoring of implementation by Member States, but it is very much an issue that lies in their hands. We will continue to assess the situation and the developments in the Sea of Azov. We will continue to count on the support of this Parliament and all the relevant committees to continue to build a united effort and policy and to work with our Ukrainian friends to invest in their resilience as much as we can.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I have received five motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 25 October 2018.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2018/2891(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, we discuss the situation in Venezuela relatively often and I can start by saying that we are now seeing a further deterioration in the situation and further polarisation of the political scene. Tensions are continuing to rise, social and economic conditions are clearly worsening quite dramatically, and, against this background, over two million Venezuelans have decided to leave the country. We often refer to crises caused by migration to Europe. I would invite you to look at these numbers. There are, as I said, two million Venezuelans fleeing to Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador, Peru and the Caribbean. Among those people, some are European citizens, so here we have an inverse situation: as you might know, nearly one million EU nationals have dual citizenship. There are also people of European descent who live in Venezuela, although many of them have already left the country. Even though an ocean geographically divides us, we Europeans cannot stand on the sidelines of this crisis. It concerns us simply because of the number of EU nationals who are also Venezuelans, not to mention the social, cultural and economic ties that exist between Europe and Venezuela.  Our response so far has been both humanitarian and political. On the humanitarian side, we are currently mobilising EUR 35 million in assistance to Venezuelans both within and outside the country. We are investing in health assistance, food and water sanitation. We are working to support the socio—economic inclusion of Venezuelans and to help the local economies of host communities in neighbouring countries. Half of this EUR 35 million package is already being implemented in near-record time and the remainder will be made operational by early next year. We are also exploring the possibility of further increasing the Commission’s financial support beyond this already very significant contribution. We have welcomed the appointment of Eduardo Stein as a UNHCR-IOM Joint Special Representative for Venezuelan refugees and migrants, and, with the Foreign Ministers of the 28 Member States, we had the opportunity to discuss the Venezuelan migration crisis last Monday in Luxembourg during the Foreign Affairs Council, expressing our support to both Mr Grandi and Mr Vitorino for this work, which we want to be joint work. On that occasion we had both Mr Grandi and Mr Vitorino with us. We didn’t focus purely on issues relating to migration and Europe, and I believe that to be right. We stand ready to support any further coordinated action, both at regional and international level, to address this humanitarian crisis more effectively. But the only possible solution is political. Last week – again with the Foreign Affairs Council, with the Foreign Ministers – we discussed what more the European Union can do to prevent a further deterioration in the situation or help change the course of these negative developments. Ministers from all 28 Member States have confirmed that, first of all, any sustainable political solution to the Venezuelan crisis has to be democratic and peaceful, and those are the two pillars that are guiding our action. External intervention or any use of force would simply be unacceptable to us and would make things much worse.  Our immediate request to the Government of Venezuela is that it takes unilateral confidence-building measures to ease tensions, first and foremost by restoring the full constitutional powers of the National Assembly and respecting the immunity of its members, releasing all political prisoners and taking concrete steps to restore political pluralism and guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. We expect, in particular, a full, independent and impartial investigation into the circumstances of Councillor Albán’s death. It is the duty of the State to ensure the safety and physical integrity of all people in its custody. Finally, we ask the Government to allow free, credible and transparent elections with full respect for the Constitution. On all these points, we have not changed our minds. You have heard them and have said as much yourselves several times. The requests from our side remain on the table and we don’t intend to change our minds on these starting points: the people of Venezuela are simply asking for democracy, and this crisis will end only with a political process heading in that direction. This is very clear to us Europeans.  In response to the human rights violations in Venezuela and the ongoing attack on democratic institutions, we decided a year ago to impose targeted restrictive measures on a number of individuals who are responsible for the current situation. This is the first time that we are imposing these kinds of measures in Latin America and, as you can imagine, we didn’t take the decision lightly. We took it not only because of the deteriorating situation, but also as a message for the authorities in Venezuela, with which we are keeping a channel of dialogue open, to commit themselves seriously to a negotiated political solution to the current crisis. Today, the situation has not improved at all. On the contrary. So we are sticking to our decision, and the restrictive measures will stay for as long as human rights are violated and democratic principles are disregarded. We do not intend to soften our position while there is no substantive progress on the ground. At the Foreign Affairs Council last week, we started a discussion with the Ministers on what else we, as the European Union and as Member States, can do, in addition to these positions and the decision to continue the sanctions, to end the downward spiral and help start some kind of political process, as the absence of a political process might in itself lead to a further deterioration in the situation. So we will explore, first of all together with Latin American countries, the possibility of establishing a contact group with relevant and interested countries, not only from the region, and international players. We don’t think that, at this point in time, mediation or a dialogue would have any chance of succeeding. I want to be very clear on that point. It’s not a question of buying time. No way. The conditions for either a dialogue or for mediation are not there, but an international initiative – a European initiative together with others – could, with plenty of question marks, help build the conditions that would eventually make it possible to relaunch a political process. For the moment, this is just a possibility that we are exploring. I don’t want to raise expectations. We are simply worried about the lack of a political process and, personally, I don’t want to be in a position, six months or a year from now, of looking back and asking whether we could have done more on the political side to prevent the situation from deteriorating even further.  So again, without raising expectations or launching an initiative today, the idea is simply to explore whether it might be possible to put something in place that could help create the conditions for something to happen in the future. I believe that we should try any peaceful option to end the current stalemate and prevent a violent escalation because, if the situation does not improve –  and we do not see the situation improving – an escalation of violence cannot be ruled out, and that would mean even greater suffering for the people of Venezuela. This is an option that we have to avert and prevent. We don’t want to impose any outside outsourced solution. That is never the European approach. We believe in democracy, we believe in ownership, we believe in cooperation and we believe in respect. We believe that the future of Venezuela – and also the present of Venezuela – must be written by its people and no one else, without any external intervention. But we will do everything we can to help the Venezuelan people take the future and the present of the country back into their hands. I am looking forward to listening to your views.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, democracy and human rights are in a critical situation in Venezuela: 2 300 000 Venezuelans, according to unHCR's official figures, have had to leave the country — in fact, the actual figures are three million. Three million, Madam High Representative, is a huge figure: it represents ten times the population of the city of Strasbourg that welcomes us today.  There are more than two hundred and fifty political prisoners, according to the Venezuelan Criminal Forum, and more than twelve thousand Venezuelan citizens have entered and left this sinister carousel with revolving prison doors; some have come out, like Lorent Saleh, tortured; others have not left, like Councilman Fernando Albán, to which you have referred; and others, such as National Assembly Mp Juan Requesens, are still in prison. The split face of Juan Requesens, Madam High Representative, is a living image of what democracy in Venezuela is today: bloodied, beaten, battered, but still standing.  I believe that in today's debate we have to reflect seriously on the message that the European Union has to send to this troubled people of Venezuela, and see if we can send them a message of hope. This Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to the democratic opposition. He told us about the discussions in the Council of Ministers; We welcome, Madam High Representative, that the Council has not changed its position. We know that there are Member States that want to soften it, but this is not the time to contemporise, this is not the time to loosen up. It is time to address our principles with determination and courage and to support solutions, Madam High Representative, with our partners in the region — you referred very well to the Lima Group or the OAS — to try to get the people of Venezuela, with all the guarantees, to take the floor again.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the question, as Mrs Mogherini rightly said, is: what else? Here's the question. And this is the time when we have to answer, because all of the above is already done: we have condemned Maduro and his regime hundreds of times; we have produced resolutions; we provide humanitarian aid; we have applied sanctions. The question is: what else, ladies and gentlemen? And I would like there to be a consensus in this House on 'what else'. And this I believe is a reflection that forces us to be intelligent and pragmatic: intelligent because we have to find in the region, in the international agents of the region, allies to help Venezuela, and to do so as a country friend of Venezuela, which is the European Union; pragmatic, because we must find peaceful and democratic outings. It has been said well, but exits, even to dictatorship, because dictatorships also need exits. And I think the important thing today is to send this message, because the house agreement, in addition to the convictions, is that, first of all, only the Venezuelan people decide. Secondly, there is no intervention by others and much less violent intervention, and I think it is appropriate to recall it. And thirdly, that is precisely why ministers - and Mrs Mogherini have said this well - have to explore whether the European Union can play a better role in helping a peaceful, democratic and dialogued exit.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we stand by the people of Venezuela in their dramatic situation with the spillover effect of this drama to the whole region. Therefore, we have to increase pressure on the Maduro regime to stop violations of human rights, including the rights and immunities of our colleagues, the parliamentarians. We have to increase pressure also to introduce reforms in the country and to keep cooperation with other organisations such as the OAS and the UN.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, this is the fourth resolution on Venezuela this year and we all know that the situation continues to worsen in Venezuela. The European Union cannot continue to wait for the human rights situation to deteriorate further and further. What else do we need to convince ourselves? How many more abuses, more testimonies of torture, the more deaths of innocent Venezuelans must we witness before the Union decides that the situation has deteriorated enough to justify a next step? First, we need concrete actions that have an effective impact. We need more selective sanctions that cover close relatives as well as the state oil company.  Second, we must cooperate internationally. That is why I call on the European Union and its Member States to join the request of countries such as Argentina, Chile and Canada for the International Criminal Court to open an investigation into the crimes committed by the Maduro regime, therefore to end once and for all the impunity that has prevailed in Venezuela for a long time. It's late, but there's still a little time to act effectively. We need no further evidence of the suffering to which the Venezuelan people are subjected to take this step.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I must start by expressing our deep concern over the situation in Venezuela. As Greens, we abhor any human rights violations and threats to the rule of law and are seriously concerned about the deepening humanitarian and political crisis in Venezuela. I would like to acknowledge and support your efforts, Ms Mogherini, to establish a contact group in Venezuela that may facilitate political discussions between different parties. As Greens, we are always strong supporters of a political process as a means to bring about peaceful resolution. We recognise that targeted sanctions can bring some progress, but they cannot replace peaceful diplomacy, and they must not be allowed to harm the Venezuelan people further. We have now had several debates in this House on Venezuela. We have them frequently, and it seems that there are some factions in the House who are unfailingly supporting the Venezuelan opposition. We are concerned that this may make the likelihood of civil conflict greater, and we see that as an increasing likelihood that we are very concerned about. I would urge my colleagues to support peace through diplomacy and negotiation, and not to stoke the fire with inflammatory rhetoric.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, another resolution on Venezuela, and I am already losing count. Looks like they're looking for the Guinness Record for country resolutions, and they're on the right track. Looks like there's no other problem in Latin America. But you are not looking to solve Venezuela's problems, but a change of government. Two events in these weeks make clear its double standard: Honduras, thousands of migrants fleeing their country, from the hunger and violence of the most violent country in the world. I have not heard them talk about humanitarian emergency, border pressure, or the responsibility of a government heir to a coup d'or sanctions against it. Another, the murder and dismemberment in life of journalist Jashogui. Where are the sanctions, Mrs. Mogherini? Where do you denounce the agreement with Saudi Arabia or the Gulf Cooperation Council? Where do the pronouncements against the theocratic and murderous dictatorship? There aren't any because those are his little friends. The furious harassment of this Parliament and the European Union pursues only an agenda of changes of government; criminalize and expel a president who, with more than six million votes, won the last election. But the reality is stubborn: no coups, no street terrorism, no sanctions, no economic war, no assassination attempts have succeeded in twisting the Venezuelan will expressed at the ballot box. It is what bothers them: that Venezuela follow its sovereign path that its citizens will only decide.

name: Mara Bizzotto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Venezuela, Maduro is the leader of an infamous Communist dictatorship that is killing the Venezuelan people. In Venezuela, political dissidents are arrested and killed by the regime police. In Venezuela, children and the elderly are starving because of a lack of care. There is a large community of Italian-Venezuelans, 150 000 people forced to abandon everything and flee abroad to flee the persecutions of the Maduro regime. Venezuelans are real refugees, anti-communist refugees and Catholics that Europe, you, Commissioner Mogherini, and the Vatican pretend not to see. Your silence, Mr Mogherini, is shameful, Commissioner Mogherini, the silence of the left, which thinks only of false African refugees and does not say a word about the real anti-communist refugees in Venezuela, is shameful. We have a duty to help our Venezuelan brothers and sisters, we must break down the Communist dictatorship, wipe out the dictator Maduro and restore venezuela's freedom. Freedom for the Venezuelan people, freedom for our Italian-Venezuelan brothers.

name: McAllister David (PPE). –
text: Madam President, I would like to underline what has been said this evening. Venezuela is facing an unprecedented political, social, economic and humanitarian crisis. The devastating political actions of President Maduro have resulted in an increasing number of deaths, refugees and arbitrarily arrested people. Three aspects should guide our actions with Venezuela, in my opinion. The first one is: the EU should continue to urge President Maduro to stop any human rights violations and to allow unhindered humanitarian aid to prevent the crisis from further deteriorating.  Secondly, I fully support the Foreign Affairs Council’s calls for new presidential elections. If these elections do not take place in the near future, we must act swiftly and impose additional targeted, restrictive measures, and thirdly, the European Union must enhance its political outreach with the democratic opposition and the civil society. It is high time for friendly, meaningful and result-oriented negotiations towards peaceful solutions but most important also, in my opinion, is that the Venezuelan people deserve an end to this Communist nightmare.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, last week of Last June, as part of a delegation from the European Parliament, I was in one of the poorest states in Brazil, Roraima, which borders Venezuela, and i had the opportunity at that time to visit several Venezuelan refugee camps. It's not fake news, it's direct contacts I had with people who were there, who I could talk to, Venezuelans, most of them poor, and who had fled Venezuela. I spoke to them and they pointed out the most diverse reasons: hunger, the lack of medicines, in some cases, a framework of political persecution. That's the reality. Far more than two million citizens who have left Venezuela in recent years, due to the dictatorial regime that reigns there. And we here cannot distinguish between dictatorships. There are no left-wing dictatorships and right-wing dictatorships, some better and some worse. All dictatorships are deplorable and the real democrats have an obligation to fight them. And we, who have the privilege of being in a democratic Parliament, have an obligation to denounce, fight and support those who fight for democracy in Venezuela, even if we do not fully agree with its ideological and political orientations.  I agree with the idea of promoting more negotiations, although those that have developed so far have failed. But I agree with that idea and I think that the European Union should invest, to the limit of its capabilities, in the effort to promote these negotiations between the various parties involved in the conflict in Venezuela. But that cannot under any circumstances mean that the European Union will withdraw anything firmly in its relationship with a dictatorial regime, such as the regime currently existing in Venezuela.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your meridian clarity. While some continue to fill their mouths with the word "dialogue" regarding Venezuela, the life of opponent Maria Corina Machado is in danger. After attempting unsuccessfully to frame her in a far-fetched plan of murder, the Chavista regime now seems to be planning an attack on her that would disguise her as an accident, exactly as she has attempted to disguise the death of Councilman Fernando Albán as suicide. "Dialogue", what dialogue are you talking about? In this brutal asymmetry of oppressors and oppressed, all that arises is blackmail. The European Union has two inescapable obligations. The first is to make every effort to ensure the physical security of those who embody Venezuela's democratic opposition. And the second, to maintain its position until it achieves the conditions approved by this House, which Mrs Mogherini has very well recalled: the release of all political prisoners, the opening of a humanitarian channel, full restitution of the Constitution and all legitimate institutions, and the call for transparent and inclusive elections, without impunity for criminals, who will have to respond to international justice.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE).
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini for your presence. Venezuela's situation seemed difficult to make worse, but it has occurred in unacceptable terms. The alleged murder of Councilman Fernando Albán of the First Justice party, by the crude system of throwing him out the window of the house of torture, is something that borders on what could not be believed. The high representative says— and she was very good today — that sanctions are not abandoned, but that she advocates dialogue. And in this we're going to disagree. This is the thesis of Mr Rodríguez Zapatero, former president of the Government of Spain, and who already, more than mediator, is beginning to be a necessary collaborator of the dictatorship. Unfortunately, the former President of the European Parliament, Mr Borrell, and Spain's current foreign minister is also on that line. It is impossible to raise a situation of dialogue, and I see that the high representative is also quite skeptical. But I have heard something important: we must completely rule out any kind of delucination about violent actions. Trump', Almagro's and even Ledezma's statements are unacceptable. The answers have to be democratic, impeccably democratic. The opposite causes victimism and produces reasons they don't have.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome High Representative Mogherini’s stance on Venezuela. The grave human rights violations in the country must be condemned in the strongest possible terms, and the European Union must lead efforts to facilitate political dialogue in the country. The situation in Venezuela has been blocked for several years, and there seems to be no end in sight. The EU should, as it often has done in the past, serve as a facilitator of dialogue in order for the Venezuelans to find a viable exit to the economic, social and political crisis they’re facing. It’s crucial to involve other countries from the region in order to ensure that peaceful talks can take place, whilst also joining efforts with them towards independent investigations into allegations of human rights violations and the prosecution of perpetrators. While we discuss the diplomatic solutions to the crisis, sadly, people are starving on the ground, fleeing to neighbouring countries because they lack public services. With the current state of affairs, our priority should be to deliver urgent humanitarian aid to the country, as the short-term consequences of the crisis for the population are dire.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as we speak, dictator Nicolás Maduro criticises Donald Trump for not opening the borders of the United States to thousands of Honduran citizens who want to enter the country. Nicolás Maduro just does not question the reasons why these people choose the United States as their destination, not Venezuela. Why do they prefer the arms of a democratic country, even if treated by Maduro as an imperialist with pretensions to the world's police, to chavista and totalitarian Venezuela where the most orthodox Marxist practices apply in the 21st century? And the answer is easy. If they were looking for Venezuela, they'd probably have their borders closed. Then, if they wanted to live and work there, what would they find? They would find misery and hunger, a people in the meantime, closed enterprises, the violence of the regime militias; if they got sick they would not have medicines in hospitals; if they wanted to be entrepreneurs, they would perhaps end up arbitrarily imprisoned, as happened to 34 supermarket managers, 12 of them Portuguese and Portuguese-descendants not long ago; and if they challenged the government, they might end up like Fernando Albán Salazar, a city councilman in Libertador, an opponent imprisoned by the orders of the dictatorship who may have stumbled from the tenth floor of the Bolivarian National Intelligence service building in Caracas. Madam President, this debate is about the situation in Venezuela. The situation in Venezuela, one of the richest countries on the planet, is a tragedy.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a profound institutional democratic slippage has created a huge humanitarian crisis in Venezuela.  A tragedy with the size of the one that is happening is always the result of a resounding political failure. The causes and contexts are various, but the role of the European Union should not be to fuel geostrategic rivalries or to make the characterization of the good or the bad extreme. The suffering of the Venezuelan people cannot be an instrument of political combat and I would therefore like to welcome the strategy defined by the European Union, and reiterated here by High Representative Federica Mogherini. This strategy must be supported by this Parliament. Targeted sanctions and the denunciation of human rights violations that occur systematically are the necessary basis for forcing a political solution that safeguards the bases of the rule of law, helps the people and resolves the brutal humanitarian crisis that is taking place in Venezuela.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by saying that it remains crucial that the EU support the International Criminal Court (ICC) in investigating repression and crimes in Venezuela. There can be no moving forward without seeking justice. In addition to the dire humanitarian situation in Venezuela, President Maduro’s regime continues to harass and torture political opponents whilst creating an environment of impunity in his country. I deeply regret the orchestrated accusation against the 2017 Sakharov Prize laureates, which, inter alia, effectively excluded them from competing in future elections.  The EU needs to be firm in its rejection of the illegitimate Constituent National Assembly authorities. Once again, our resolution must reiterate that the 20 May elections are illegitimate and not internationally recognised. As a response to the stance by the Venezuelan regime, we have adopted additional and revocable sanctions but need to make it clear that further deterioration of democracy will provoke a much stronger reaction from our side.
