name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Dear President, the situation in Venezuela is still deteriorating dramatically, and the country is facing an unprecedented political, social, economic and humanitarian crisis – we know this.  Since President Maduro took power, human rights violations and crackdowns on civil society have become routines. Hunger, lack of medicines – a situation so desperate that HIV and cancer patients are no longer treated and parents are forced to take their hungry children to their children's homes. Instead of long-awaited government solutions, there is an even greater effort to portray an alternative reality. Today has already been mentioned: more than 2.3 million refugees from Venezuela have recently been refugees. This is a huge humanitarian crisis and we need to find opportunities to respond to it.  Firstly, we need to help our partners in the region cope with the flow of refugees from Venezuela. Secondly, we must make sure that the Venezuelan authorities immediately inject humanitarian aid into the country. And thirdly, we need an international mediation and contact group acceptable to both sides. We need that political solution to the crisis and the only one in a peaceful way.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, the situation is critical: humanitarian disaster and very serious violation of human rights. Our role is fundamental. The Union, the United Nations and the free world must strengthen their strong commitment to the Venezuelan people and to Maduro's dictatorship and tyranny. We strongly condemn the brutal murder of Fernando Albán and call for an independent United Nations investigation that identifies the culprits and adds new incriminating arguments to the case before the International Criminal Court.  The Helicoide is an illegal center of repression, torture and death. We have already seen in Cúcuta and Boa Vista the tragic consequences of the mass exodus of Venezuelans seeking life and freedom. The impact on neighbouring countries outweighs their good faith and their chances of welcoming. Conviction is not enough. More tangible solidarity is needed. The Union is there and Parliament has to stay there, helping, pushing and denouncing. What is 35 million euros in the face of this tragedy?

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ... the murder of opponent Fernando Albán, who wanted to cover themselves as a suicide, is a tragic example of this deterioration. I have long argued that the European Union has had to be more active in the face of this crisis which seriously affects Venezuelan citizens and also neighbours Colombia, Peru, Brazil and Ecuador. I didn't like the results you read from last week's Foreign Affairs Council. I do not believe in any way that the conditions for a relaunch of a mechanism for dialogue or mediation are met. The Venezuelan regime, which controls everything, has no willingness to give in at all, nor to compromise. The background is very clear: failure in the Dominican Republic, arrest and murder, in some cases, of opponents. Anyway, dialogue formulas, as you know very well, give oxygen to the regimen, allow you to buy time. What do we have to do? In addition to helping the population, increase pressure on the regime. To make him see that his behavior does not go unpunished and force him to change course, in coordination with the countries of the Lima Group. The situation is very serious, the suffering of Venezuelans is enormous. We need to help them and help Maduro's regime de lay down its attitude.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to give my voice to the victims of Maduro's repression, as they cannot speak because, if they did, they would be arrested, tortured and killed.  I speak on behalf of parents who have seen their children die for their freedom in Venezuela; on behalf of the millions of Venezuelans crossing the border, victims of an unprecedented humanitarian crisis; on behalf of the millions of exiles for the economic, political and social crisis; of young people without a homeland who cannot return to their country; of all families destroyed, separated and trying to survive in exile; on behalf of all who die because they have neither food nor medicine.  You can't keep denying reality. Dialogue helps Maduro. And I wonder why Spain has not joined the complaint to the International Criminal Court to investigate Venezuela for crimes against humanity as France and Germany have done, for example. Maduro has had his time and we must help Venezuelans regain hope, freedom and dignity.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the minimum wage in Venezuela was recently raised by 3 000%. That sounds like a wild dream for workers in a normal country, but in the meantime, inflation has skyrocketed by 83 000% this year. Prices doubled in 26 days, 80% of the population is affected by poverty. This represents a total failure by the present regime, which has lost the moral and political credentials to run the country, a regime that has caused the largest wave of migration in Latin America’s recent history. There is a climate of violence and total impunity. We need to take a decisive approach with clear conditions, namely: freeing all political prisoners; allowing humanitarian aid to enter the country unimpeded; and, lastly, the holding of free and credible elections. But I cannot agree more with your point, Ms Mogherini, that the people of Venezuela are simply asking for democracy, and the crisis will end with the restoration of a normal, open and pluralist society which guarantees the rights of every citizen. It is as simple as that.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, once again to express our deep concern for what is happening in this great country of Latin America. Venezuela, having experienced no natural disaster, now has about 87% of its population affected by the true social and human scourge of poverty, living more than 61% of Venezuelans in extreme poverty, as evidenced by our resolution. This situation is not tolerable and has to be reversed! The social, humanitarian, economic and political picture in Venezuela is well known. This Parliament, moreover, has been intensely debated by the situation, having sent a mission to its borders last June and even awarding the Shakarov prize last year to the Venezuelan opposition. And it is the same opposition that is the target of arbitrary persecution and detention, international arrest warrants, expulsions from the country or hard-working exiles. In addition to these facts the death of Councilman Fernando Albán occurred two weeks ago in unknown circumstances and while in the custody of the National Intelligence Service. They are therefore intolerable situations that must be immediately reversed! I will end by making the call for European and international humanitarian aid to be strengthened on the ground and in neighbouring countries.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I just want to remind you that in recent months we have dealt with the situation here in Venezuela several times. The situation is getting worse, colleagues are very precisely describing the economic and huge tragedy that the Venezuelan people are experiencing today, and the question is up to you, Madam High Representative, whether we are able to force dictator Maduro into international law, international diplomacy, to at least allow troops who are able to provide humanitarian aid and those international organisations that want to provide humanitarian aid to their country, thereby reducing the huge disaster for the Venezuelan people. However, as long as Maduro is a dictator, then it must be perceived that tragedies such as the assassination of an activist, the politician of Albania, will be a reality, and no one will do anything about it. So, in my opinion, much more pressure needs to be put on and at least help people in this huge economic tragedy.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, we have reiterated this today: the situation of protracted political deadlock in Venezuela, which has led to a humanitarian, social and economic crisis affecting the country and has led to a real mass exodus, is becoming increasingly worrying. More than two million people, including many children, have left the country to escape dramatic life situations and the repression of an increasingly authoritarian government. It is true that aid is needed to support neighbouring nations in meeting the enormous humanitarian effort to ensure a dignified reception for all refugees, but we need a long-term peaceful solution, and that is why Europe will need to step up its international mediation effort with the Venezuelan Government in order to put an end to the violation of rights and the restoration of democracy. Mrs Mogherini, I agree with your proposal to set up a contact group to check whether the conditions are in place for a political process leading to a democratic solution involving all regional and international actors.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Maduro and his Government, with the repression they exercise , documented with thousands of complaints – with the blocking of the aid they need, with the forced exodus to which they force the citizenship of a poorly administered and governed country, with their opposition to transparency in front of the international community, force them to move from words to deeds. Because we are faced with more than symptoms of the commission of a crime against humanity against Venezuelans. That is why I would like to request that the Union and all its Member States join the request that has launched a preliminary investigation by the International Criminal Court into the activities of the Nicolas Maduro regime. That's not enough. I also support new selective sanctions against their hierarchies and any initiative that promotes a dialogued solution, necessary. But it requires one condition: the release of all political prisoners, the cessation of harassment and repression, and the restoration of legitimate usurped institutions. Nothing further from the noble liberation promoted by Simon Bolivar than the cruel dictatorship of Nicolás Maduro.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this House systematically omits without condemnation the threats of military intervention and the constant destabilisation actions promoted by the United States against the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and the Venezuelan people. A strategy associated with the European Union and which has as its central element the sanctions and the economic and financial blockade, affecting the economy of Venezuela and the living conditions of its people and also the overwhelming majority of the Portuguese community. Actions that are intensifying as the Venezuelan Government seeks to implement measures to combat terrorist actions, along with economic measures, including combating hoarding and price speculation, in order to ensure the improvement of the living conditions of Venezuelans and also of the Portuguese community. Relations with Venezuela and its legitimate government must be based on respect for its sovereignty and independence, the Charter of the United Nations and international law, as well as respect for the right of the Venezuelan people to decide, without external interference, their future.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: "Madam High Representative, I am very sorry for cutting your word for it, but I give it to you right away, thank you very much. Mr President, Madam High Representative, the economic collapse, the humanitarian drama that is currently taking place in Venezuela stems from a political problem which should only be resolved by this route, and i therefore greet Mrs Mogherini for the intention, as I said earlier, without softening the restrictive measures imposed by the European Union on Venezuela, to set up a contact group in charge of managing the crisis in the country. The recent twists in the diplomatic policy of some Member States, seeking to replace the sanctions regime individualised by dialogue, serve only to fuel the deception of Mr Maduro's government, which for the past four years has eluded heads of state, the Vatican, the European Union and its own people, with simulated dialogue that have only served to buy time and try to weaken external pressure and demobilize the opposition. These ad hoc attempts at dialogue with the illegitimate and dictatorial regime, which is part of the problem and not the solution, only serve to weaken the Union's joint position and fuel the oxygen balloon of a government that has transformed a democratic and prosperous nation into a narco-state that condemns its own citizens to the most abject tyranny and misery. I end, Mrs Mogherini, recalling Fernando Albán and thinking about his murder and also thinking of Corina Machado who is fighting for her own life at this moment.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying that, luckily, I have seen in the Member States and in the Council more unity than in this Chamber. Sorry, I am being blunt, but I want to start from just describing the situation as I have seen it in the past four years and still saw it last week. There is no Member State asking for a review of our sanctions policy and there is no Member State arguing that we should currently engage in mediation. We have to start from a point of clarity and truth about this. We can be against something but if nobody else is proposing that something then it’s a pure exercise of rhetoric. I think we need to discuss things as they are. Things as they are currently are as I described them at the start – and maybe some of you joined the debate after my initial contribution – that we are keeping our position exactly as it has been in recent years, on the need for freeing the political prisoners, the need for elections, the need to have the constitution fully respected and applied, and so on and so forth. We are keeping our sanctions in place. As I said, that was quite something because it was the first time we had introduced targeted sanctions in Latin America, which was not a decision taken lightly by our Member States. They were united on that, and they continue to be united in that respect. In the meantime, we are saying two things, and I think we can agree on these two things. One: that the solution has to be peaceful, and I would have liked to have heard that a bit more clearly in some of the speeches from around the Chamber, because the idea of some form of military pressure or intervention is floating around. I think that, as Europeans, we are fully united on the fact that, in Venezuela, any sort of military pressure or intervention could actually be counterproductive because we know the nature of Maduro’s attitude. That is all he is waiting for. Come on! The negative outside effect could strengthen the fight against the outside. And we are worried: not worried, or at least I am not worried, about having an ideological fight as to whether we support one kind of ideology or the other, but we are seriously concerned about the situation of a country that has millions of people in a difficult situation, among them one million European citizens. So we care: we care about finding a solution. How can that solution be found? The European position – which I think has been reflected well in the great majority of your positions – is first that any solution can only be a political, peaceful solution; and second, and equally importantly, that it has to be a democratic outcome – a democratic outcome, involving all Venezuelans because, as I said earlier, we are not, and we will never be, in favour of an external imposed solution. It has to be a Venezuelan solution and it has to involve all Venezuelans. This is the difficulty of the simple exercise of looking for democracy. This is the balanced, united position that the European Union has stressed in recent weeks. We will now try to explore whether the conditions exist for establishing the contact group. As I said, I would not want to raise expectations, because I think this is extremely complicated as an exercise. However, I think it’s worth trying not to initiate a mediation process or a dialogue but to see if the conditions are in place to establish a contact group that could start working on establishing the conditions – which are currently not there – for re-launching this political process. I said this very clearly at the beginning, perhaps some of you were not there when I said it. I want to say something else very clearly, even if I ought to be sitting on the Council side to say it, namely that I have seen no divisions among Member States on this position. I have seen a very clearly united stand behind this effort that we are now starting to explore. One last point on the International Criminal Court (ICC) investigation. Some of you raised this. Currently, a preliminary examination is being conducted by the office of the ICC prosecutor and, as you know, the European Union is a strong supporter – probably the strongest supporter – of the ICC’s role in bringing perpetrators to justice. So we now trust the ICC prosecutor’s assessment on whether or not the Rome Statute requirements to initiate an investigation have been met in the case of Venezuela. We trust the ICC, as an institution, to carry out the preliminary examination that is currently being undertaken, and then we’ll take it from there.

name: Presidente. –
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) (or Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 25, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I want to start by giving my condolences to the family and friends of Fernando Albán, a tortured and murdered councillor at SEBIN headquarters, even if they want to sell it to us as a suicide. Fernando Albán had been arrested after being charged with an alleged attack on President Maduro. An accusation that seems to extend to anyone who carries a stone in his dictatorial path. The most recent to receive this accusation is Mr. Julio Borges, President of the National Assembly and awarded the Sakharov Prize. In any case, it is not for me to judge the facts, so I support the need for an independent and transparent investigation with international experts to clarify the facts and convict the culprits. Political repression in Venezuela has reached outrageous indices. The Venezuelan Criminal Forum informs us that there are currently 234 political prisoners. A fact that the EU cannot ignore. It is therefore essential to reach a political solution: (a) the immediate release of all political prisoners and the end of repression, (b) establish a new independent National Electoral Council and (c) organize free and fair elections in accordance with international standards and the presence of international observers.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the need for a comprehensive mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (2018/2886(SDR)).

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Thank you President, we appreciate that Parliament has given the Council the opportunity to participate in this debate. This Parliament has indeed always shown great dedication to protection of the rule of law, of democracy and of fundamental rights in our Union.  The protection and promotion of our core values as stated in Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union is a constant challenge. This challenge requires unwavering attention and effort across all institutions and all policy areas. Democracy, freedom, equality, the rule of law and human rights are the cornerstones of the European Union. Each Member State must therefore respect, protect and promote them.  The Austrian Presidency, and indeed all of us, agree that protection of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in our Union cannot be taken for granted. To address this challenge, the Council and a Member State established a meeting within the Council, the so-called ‘annual rule of law dialogue’. The last rule of law dialogue was organised by the Estonian Presidency in October 2017 on media pluralism and the rule of law in a digital age. The next rule of law dialogue will be organised in November by the Austrian Presidency. It will deal with the issue of trust in public institutions and rule of law. From the beginning we were aware that the Council’s response to rule of law issues needed to be reviewed at a regular pace and if needed, improved or adapted to current challenges. The last evaluation in 2016 showed, among others, that the preparation of dialogues should be more systematic and include the organisation of other accompanying events. This would provide for the possibility to assemble broad input at expert level, including the involvement of other EU institutions or other institutional organisations.  The Estonian Presidency and now our Presidency have followed these recommendations and included experts in the preparation of the annual ministerial dialogue. By the end of 2019 the Council will conduct a re—evaluation of the rule of law dialogue and consider ways to further strengthen it. In the meantime, the Council must task it with conducting two Article 7 procedures, on Poland and Hungary. Since the procedure was triggered, every General Affairs Council meeting has discussed the situation in Poland and in Hungary.  Of course, the Council is not acting alone in these matters of fundamental importance. The Presidency notes with interest the commitment of this Parliament and its legislative initiative report on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights. In addition, the Commission plays a vital role in monitoring developments in this field across the Union.  We also wish to highlight the role played by the Council of Europe and the Venice Commission in these questions and I note that in its working programme 2019, the Commission indicated that it would come up with a further strengthening of the 2014 rule of law framework. Let me conclude by stressing that safeguarding democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights goes to the heart of our commitment to this Union. The success of this political project will be measured by its ability and determination to uphold these core values. We will play our part.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, when we discussed – I think it was exactly two years ago – the issue of stepping up our mechanism to strengthen democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, I said on behalf of the Commission that we fully support Parliament’s objectives underlying the resolution adopted in 2016. Like Parliament, the Commission is deeply committed to ensuring that our common European values, including in particular democracy and the rule of law, are respected. I believe the actions of the Commission over the past four years leave no grounds for any doubt on that matter. So we agree on the end, and the discussion between us is about identifying the best means.  The developments which have occurred over the past two years have only made the Commission more convinced of the importance of using the instruments we already have to uphold EU values in the most effective way. The diversity of challenges we are facing requires a diversity of responses at EU level. Among these developments, the deterioration of the situation with the rule of law in Poland led the Commission, in December 2017, to initiate the procedure set out in Article 7 of the Treaty on the European Union. Last month Parliament decided to initiate the same procedure as regards Hungary. These are unprecedented steps in the history of our Union. The Commission has recently launched a number of values-related infringement proceedings, and with regard to the Polish Law on the Supreme Court we have also invited the Court of Justice to impose interim measures. In addition, we have used other instruments, including audits and investigations relating to the use of EU funds, as well as measures through the European Semester to monitor justice reforms in Member States. The Commission has used its powers as initiator of legislation to propose, as a key component of our next Multiannual Financial Framework, a regulation on protecting the Union’s budget in the event of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States. The rules we propose would allow the Union to suspend, reduce or restrict access to EU funding when generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law impair or threaten to impair sound financial management or the Union’s financial interest. These actions show the Commission’s determination to use all of the instruments at its disposal to address value-related concerns. In each case the Commission uses the instruments that we consider can be most effective. However, this does not mean there is no need to improve the EU’s capacity to promote and uphold our common values. On the contrary, we need to make better use of the enforcement toolbox at our disposal. Parliament’s 2016 resolution contained a number of ideas that the Commission supports: for example, setting up an interparliamentary dialogue between the European Parliament and national parliaments. The national parliaments are involved in many of the problems related to the rule of law that we have witnessed recently in some Member States. Such interparliamentary dialogue could, as a first step, discuss the various options and the means currently on the table to ensure that our common values are respected and enforced. The Commission will be ready to contribute to such a dialogue. The Commission also supports the aim of making the variety of existing data and reports more accessible and visible including a national level. The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights has a role to play in this respect.  There are other elements in the resolution which continue to raise questions. For example, the Commission maintains its strong doubts about the need for and the feasibility of an annual report and a policy cycle on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, prepared by a committee of experts. The central role attributed to an independent expert panel raises serious questions of legality, institutional legitimacy and accountability. Furthermore, the recent developments show that the problem we have is not a lack of reporting mechanisms in Europe, but rather a lack of capacity to act and enforce the rule of law and uphold our values in an effective manner. We know the facts. We need to act. For this reason, as was also announced in the letter of intent which accompanied Jean-Claude Juncker’s State of the Union speech and which was just today confirmed by the Work Programme, the Commission intends to present an initiative on further strengthening the 2014 Rule of Law framework. The initiative will draw lessons from the experiences of recent years. It will also take due account of the work of the European Parliament, including your resolution on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights mechanism, and the discussion that has ensued.  To conclude, I can assure you that the Commission is ready to continue the discussion with you to determine how best the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights can be promoted and upheld. This is an objective we share, and one which goes to the very heart of what our European Union is.

name: Frank Engel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, Mr First Vice-President, I congratulate you and thank you for the progress that has been made in safeguarding fundamental rights and the rule of law, but I must tell you again and again that this is not enough and you know it. We do not disagree on the deficiencies we see in this area because they are numerous and they are becoming more and more pervasive. The number of states that would now have to be listed if the list of states in which the rule of law is not what it should be, is increasing. Instead of going back to what we demanded in a resolution a few years ago, I would just like to point out the main observation and the main problem in my view. Unfortunately, we do not agree in Europe on how to govern. And what we need to hear when we go to Hungary or elsewhere, Poland, Romania, Malta, Slovakia - the list will probably grow even longer - is not what we would expect in other parts of Europe. And I would remind you that Parliament has made this observation by saying precisely, for this reason, that we must have a permanent interaction with each other, representatives of all the Member States, on how we can govern legitimately and on what we should not do in Europe if we are to claim common values. common principles, a common governance base. We have to lay that foundation because unfortunately it is not there. We did not expect that when we were formulating the treaties. It is time to introduce it.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Two years ago, this House, by a large majority, called on the Commission to set up a low-threshold interinstitutional mechanism to guarantee fundamental rights. Unfortunately, the Commission has shown no particular zeal to take up this proposal, unlike some Member States, where there has been very positive feedback.  Such a mechanism, also known as the DRF package, would help us to ensure a more effective and sustainable safeguarding of fundamental democratic rights. The starting point is simple. It is true that the Copenhagen criteria have a clear hurdle to becoming a member of the Union. Once this is done, there are hardly any adequate means to punish a non-observance or willful violation. The existing instruments are often too powerful and too under-targeted to influence threatening developments at an early stage.  Once the problems are addressed at EU level, criticism from the Member States concerned is usually stylised as an external threat and it is very difficult to solve the problem. We have seen this time and again in recent years. The new mechanism, on the other hand, proposes interlinking existing instruments, starts at an early stage and puts all Member States – the old and the new – on an equal footing. A democracy scoreboard, similar to the Venice Commission, is developing a format that opens up possibilities for comparison and starts at an early stage. The creation of such a mechanism, I believe, would bring new capacity for action and confuse the culture of debate.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In one, I agree with those who propose a permanent mechanism for verifying the democracy of the rule of law and fundamental rights, namely in criticising the previous practice of the EU institutions in this area. The actions taken by the Commission and the European Parliament were selective, arbitrary and extremely politicised. For example, even the "greatest friends" (in quotes) of my country acknowledged in the back room that another Member State could also be of concern to them.  And that's the way it is. This is by no means the case, for example, malta mentioned here by a colleague. Take, for example, a country that is considered a model of liberal democracy. I mean Germany. For decades, the judicial community in Germany has been demanding reforms that fully implement the principles of democracy, the tripartite power and judicial independence in the German justice system. Calls for judicial reform were made before the 2017 Bundestag elections. Neue Richtervereinigung, for example, issued the so-called Berlin appeal, which included the following statement, and I quote: 'The Federal Republic of Germany, as a member of the Union, may request that third parties comply with the subjective rules in a credible manner if it organises itself in this way. That is why we demand a commitment to ensure that the German judicial system meets the principles of separation of powers, which has long been part of the European standard." However, these demands have not yet been met, and the Deutscher Richterverbund published its position on 11 September 2018 entitled 'The third authority must govern itself', which states, inter alia, that the judiciary and the public prosecutor's office in the German Federal Republic are dependent on the executive and that many Länder decide on the employment and promotion of judges and prosecutors by the Minister of Justice. It is therefore called for personal decisions to be taken within the judicial self-government. This is the request of the judges. Recently, as you know, public opinion in Germany has been appalled by the question of filling the posts of judges at the Constitutional Tribunal in Brandenburg, where, as usual, the various seats are shared between large political parties. This time, the SPD decided to appoint, among other things, a politically engaged writer with no judicial experience, who was so sensible that she signed up for the party a year ago. I could multiply these examples. The same is true in many other countries where judges can be members of a political party. There is political influence everywhere on the choice of judges.  I therefore ask, Mr Timmermans: why, then, has the European Commission not taken action to ensure that the German Federal Republic respects the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. You can answer: because Germany is Germany, and Poland is Poland. But such thinking will lead sooner or later to the disaster of the Union, and perhaps of Europe.  But this catastrophe could also lead to the belief that it is the official of the European Commission or the European Parliament who would decide the rule of law or constitutionality in a country. Moreover, nothing would be a greater violation of the principle of constitutionality and the rule of law, and the proposed mechanism for verifying democracy and the rule of law would be a denial of it.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in today’s EU, independent judges are being dismissed, journalists are threatened and even murdered, NGOs are harassed and intimidated. In the last two years alone, since we adopted the proposal for the DRF Pact, two Article 7 procedures have been launched: one by Parliament and one by the Commission. The Commission has also launched infringement cases and took a Member State to court. The Council organised hearings on the rule of law in that same Member State, and Parliament created the rule of law monitoring group for two other Member States, as well as a plenary debate on yet another Member State. So a lot is being done – and I have to commend the Commissioner for his actions – but it is piecemeal and erratic. It is too little and, too often, too late. We need a pan-European mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the EU that is comprehensive and not fragmented; evidence based, not politicised; one that monitors all Member States annually and is not ad hoc or incident-driven. Exactly two years ago in this House, we adopted such a proposal: the DRF Pact. We proposed a fully—fledged interinstitutional agreement that we could have agreed on today. So why have the Commission and the Council so far failed to act on our proposal? You work on the rule of law, but your refusal to agree the comprehensive DRF Pact means that forces that demolish our way of life are always ahead of us. So it’s time to act because, Commissioner, I don’t agree with you. The toolkit that we currently have at our disposal is visibly not enough. So, as the Commission and Member States drag their feet, Parliament should move ahead anyway. I propose that we start our own annual DRF cycle, including country reporting and a debate on the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Europe, in tandem with national parliaments, and we don’t wait until the Council and Commission are ready. Because in conclusion, democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights cannot defend themselves. We have to stand up for them or they will perish.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, I actually see Mr Krasnodębski's plea on Germany as a supplement, if a support for what Parliament is asking for, namely not waiting for the calf to drown, not dragging it for eight years and then finally getting a two-thirds majority to be able to start an Article 7 procedure for Hungary, but structured annually, as a kind of visitation committee, as it takes place at universities, to see what the state of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights is in each Member State. It is nice that the Council takes a subject every year and then starts talking to each other in a private way, but it is typical that the Council still shy away from simply inviting the European Parliament to come and explain the report on Hungary. Because that's all it is. So that long as we do not allow ourselves to make real analyses of external institutions, namely the Council of Europe, the UN, the OSCE, and our own Agency for Fundamental Rights, as we focus on making reports, such as mine on Hungary, we are actually going to continue to look away from the problems in our own region.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for some time now the subject of the rule of law has resurfaced strongly in the European debate. That in itself is a good thing, given that the Eu ropean Union is based on a concept of rule of law which does not boil down to law enforcement but includes human rights. I agree with the idea of establishing a preventive mechanism that acts as a levee against possible violations and clearly represents an objective, neutral and above all non-punitive counterbalance to the current instruments. This is all the more so in view of the risk that the issue of the rule of law will become an area of electoral contention or between States, that it will be called into question selectively on the basis of party political considerations, leading in fact to a draining of the rule of law itself. I do not believe that Frans Timmermans' actions are partial. Precisely for this reason I think he could appreciate a mechanism that is animated by such a great, continuous and profound need for impartial expertise.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, a genuinely democratic Europe should respect the sovereignty of each of its European nations, but the European Union does not. It is scandalously interfering in the internal affairs of some of its Member States, such as Hungary, Poland or now Romania. Even more seriously, the European Parliament, in its resolution of 25 October 2016, envisioned the vade-mecum of the political tutelage of the Member States. It recommends that a panel of experts, elected by no one and out of nowhere, be entrusted with the power to rate states as children on respect for different principles. The separation of powers, freedom of expression or the independence of the judiciary. In an involuntary tribute to the French poet, Jacques Prévert, who would have laughed, the resolution instructs this panel of experts to give notes of color to the states. Green to the good guys, orange to suspects and red to the bad guys. For the States that get a red note, the sanction is terrible, it is the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty on the European Union that leads to the suspension of the right to vote of the offending State in the Council. All this is not serious and I regret that we are coming out of these old moons today. The European Parliament would gain credibility if it listened a little more to the aspirations of the peoples instead of being an eternal lecturer. The Europe of nations, which I would like to call for, will treat European states with respect and not with the morgue of this unworthy resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Mr President, if there is one thing that has been so violently exposed in the last year in Europe it is the need for a concrete mechanism that will monitor the state of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in every Member State. It is clear that we need to close the gaps between the rights we demand as EU citizens and the tools that are currently available for their protection.  Having such a mechanism would be a huge step forward and would go some way in allaying the fears of so many citizens in Europe from different States who look to us when their rights are in danger, or when their institutions cannot be relied on or when the promise that is Europe is under threat.  This is not about going after any single state or government. It is about making the protection of the rights we have future—proof. Our focus must be on protection, about building up systems, about helping people and not about punishment.  Having this mechanism will mean that every Member State will be subjected to the same level of scrutiny. It will remove the politics from that equation and create equality among States. It will mean that governments who think that they have carte blanche to do as they please after winning an election will be in for a surprise. It will give Europe the tools to act.  We are not interested in going after one country. We want to change the entire system, and this could very well be the game changer that we need to address this generational challenge facing our Union.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it could well be a game changer to have the encapsulation of the 2016 resolution, which is a less crisis-driven, more systematic, rule of law mechanism and we have talked about it endlessly within our committee and it is something that we very much want.  I have two points that I want to make. One is that, in reaching this objective, we must not dismiss what we are currently doing, and not give an excuse to anyone to diminish the work that has been done, either by the Commission or by Members of Parliament here on these fundamental rights mechanisms under Article 7. To do so would be to diminish the key work that has been done and that will also happen when we have this other mechanism that is less crisis-driven, because what I mean by that is the capacity to act in case of a breach, the capacity to uphold the rule of law, and indeed human rights, will be difficult in this mechanism also. It will be difficult to monitor every Member State, and to act when there is something wrong there, so please, bear this in mind.  So, to ensure that we complete the work that we are doing currently, but then in the future we look at this mechanism, and yes, hopefully we fulfil the 2016 resolution. But don’t throw the baby out with the bathwater. Ensure that we preserve the very tough work that we are currently undertaking and then get to this new fundamental rights mechanism.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Why a rule of law mechanism? Article 2 of the Treaty describes the values on which our Union is founded: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, respect for human rights. And with their signature, all Member States have committed themselves to preserving and respecting them. But if governments disregard the separation of powers, criminalize the homeless, or discredit anti-government media, it poses dangers – for individuals and for the Union as a whole. How can we expect trust in democracy and the state when governments interpret treaties, laws, and court rulings as they see fit, or even simply ignore them? The rule of law mechanism is necessary to protect freedom and democracy throughout Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – In relation to your speech, where I gave examples from Germany, I would like to ask you whether you are ready to apply what you have said to your country and to your party?

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think it is very clear that this mechanism should be fit for all Member States and, from time to time, we will check everything in all the Member States. I think this has been clear from the very beginning.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a former Minister of Justice, I support the defence of the rule of law and it is good that we have mechanisms here in the current Treaty of Lisbon. But I must say that my position on possible changes is restrained, just as the Commission expressed in its 2017 report. In short, if we were now to reach for an amendment to the Treaty of Lisbon and strengthen the control mechanisms in the form of annual preventive reports, I see that, for example, in my country, the Czech Republic, this would lead to populists taking advantage of such changes to combat the ideas of European integration and to use it against the European Union as such. And I think that, as real politicians, we should also see that. In short, strengthening the EU's position on this issue, the question of protecting the rule of law, against the will of citizens and against the will of some Member States, can turn against the very idea of European integration. Then I'd be reticent.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to tell you one thing - the European Union is currently at a crossroads and we are seeing a change in the rules during the game. The countries that joined the European Union had to meet some political conditions - the Copenhagen criteria. You must take into account, fellow Members, a very important fact - the institutions in different Member States are different. Each country should be judged according to the institutions it has. And here were said some very important things - that all the member countries of the European Union should be judged in the same way. For this, however, we must have common institutions, the same institutions that do the same for European citizens. I fully agree with Mrs in 't Veld from ALDE, who said that a mechanism should apply to all countries in a coherent way, taking into account the institutions that those countries have. Unfortunately, we note that - and this has been said before - problems have been found, generally in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. We need to have a balanced position towards the Member States because our citizens may feel discriminated against and discrimination is increasing in Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in my country, the UK, racist and anti-democratic forces led a campaign for us to leave the European Union and won by breaking the electoral law and telling lies. In Poland and Hungary, governments are making serious attacks against the rule of law and preventing civil society from playing its crucial role, required for any functioning democracy. In several other EU countries, helping migrants and refugees is now criminalised. Whilst I was relieved to see this Parliament take action against Orbán’s Government recently, I remain worried that the EU is not doing enough to support democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The drifting situation in several Member States should call for much stronger reactions. It’s our moral and historical responsibility. We must rise against fascism and fight against those who attack our common values. So I fully support Sophia in 't Veld’s proposal for a comprehensive EU mechanism that would help us respond to the breaches. In the meantime, we must continue to use the tools at our disposal against illiberal governments.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President of the European Commission, I have been a lawyer and for over 15 years I have been teaching criminal law, forensics and other subjects attached to law school students. Personally, I do not believe that there is a bona fide citizen in Europe who agrees to corruption. We say "no" clearly to corruption. But at the same time I am concerned about the double language at the level of the European institutions. Honest dialogue, I think, is the only solution. That is why, in the context of Brexit and a weak future European budget, I fear, Mr President, that some strong states - and I want to make sure that they will not misuse the rule of law to take European money from less powerful states, such as those in eastern Europe. Legally speaking, there is currently no clear definition of the rule of law and no clear criteria for the violation of the rule of law. The only authority in a position to decide on the infringement of the rule of law is the European Court of Justice, not the Commission, not the Council and not the European Parliament. Otherwise, Mr President, we risk the discretionary application of European rules and, of course, following purely political decisions, the punishment of certain states.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, I believe that in any country if we go down the street to ask citizens 'do you want it to be the rule of law with you? Do you want your rights respected?", obviously they will answer "yes". The problem that is and has been touched by many colleagues here - how do we define the rule of law? Because we have constitutions, we have constitutions - and a colleague from the Czech Republic said "the will of the people, democracy, after all, it is the will of the people" - if the constitution is respected, if the Constitutional Court of that state approves, verifies and attests all the legislation that is voted on in Parliament - an institution also voted by the people - then the rule of law is respected. Of course I agree to check all the states, not as we, Romania and Bulgaria, the CVM and we will not get rid of it. The question is to know the instruments, how they are measured and cannot yet the Commission, which is a named body, to cut funds, for example, because it is a conditionality that is not covered by the Treaty and I do not think we are amending the Treaty.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Timmermans, in order to restore in Europe the mutual and future confidence of the European Union, it is essential to strengthen the rule of law, yes, but also to combat corruption and to disappear from the map those referendums contrary to European values and convergence in European rights, such as those which seek to say no to refugee quotas or to ban same-sex marriages in the Constitution.  This Parliament asked years ago for a structured mechanism in the face of the current fragmentary and erratic landscape where nationalpopulism and iliberal democracy flourish that exploit fear of unrest, but also the deterioration of the rule of law. And it is imperative that there be a permanent mechanism for the development of Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and Article 7, so that it is not possible for a minority of countries to block until respect for the rule of law is impossible. We have the last opportunity to establish this permanent and structured mechanism of respect for the rule of law, not waste it! Vice-President Timmermans, Commission, do it!

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the one hand, assessments of respect for fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law should be made periodically in all the Member States of the European Union and are even welcome. On the other hand, we must be very careful with such assessments based on sometimes subjective and arbitrary concepts and criteria, especially when we try to introduce them as conditionalities in the granting of European funds. Is there a legal basis for the introduction of such a mechanism? Do we know to what extent it violates or interferes with the treaties in force? There are some questions to which we must find clear answers and discuss clear, non-arbitrary notions and, only then, to call into question such a mechanism, which we all want, but, of course, no one wants to be a political instrument.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Timmermans, you said here earlier that the problem facing the Commission is not to receive the necessary information, but to how to act on it. Allow me, with all due respect, to contradict you. From this chain you have omitted the middle stage, that of analysing and evaluating the information received, and that is the real problem we face here. Due to the lack of accurate and thorough analysis, there have sometimes been positions and statements that did not reflect reality and that led to the use of a double standard in assessing key situations.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will address you today not as a Member of the European Parliament, but as a European citizen and supporter of all the principles underlying European construction: unity, solidarity, economic and social cohesion, balanced development of all European regions. And as such, I express my total disagreement with any instrument or mechanism that may block the right of Member States to access European funds. We do not forget that the Member States need these European funds in order to have a balanced development of all our regions. Colleagues and Mr Timmermans, I remind you that here, at European Union level, we all have the same rights and obligations. And if we still have the same rights and obligations and we are talking about the establishment of such a mechanism, I wonder why do you not establish a mechanism for cooperation and verification at the level of all the Member States, and not only at the level of Romania and Bulgaria? Be careful, because we will introduce some mechanisms that interfere with the European Treaties and that speak of double language and a double standard at European Union level, and this will seriously affect the unity and future development of this important construction.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is important for the functioning of the European Union and is of course based on Article 7. However, a basic condition, Mr Timmermans, for the functioning of Article 7 is that this mechanism must operate within the competences of the European Union and not as a mechanism for the exercise of the competences of the Member States. We know that the basis for the functioning of the European Union is Article 5, that is to say the principle of givers of powers, that is to say that the European Union and its institutions have as many powers as the Treaties themselves give it.  Therefore, this mechanism cannot be used to intervene in matters which do not concern the competence of the European Union and the question of the establishment of the very functioning of the judiciary of a Member State is exclusive competence. Otherwise, if this principle is not respected, if the principle of separation of powers is not respected, then it is easy for many sides here to accuse the Commission of playing a political game. You can act and you must act when there is a breach of Community law and when you have the power to intervene in this matter. If your scope of competence is outside, then you risk being criticised by those who do not respect democracy many times, but who will step on the fact that you are acting outside the competences of the European Union. In any case, the Court of Justice of the European Union can decide the scope of competence and whether you are right.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I agree with most of you on the need for an ambitious and, above all, more coherent systematic mechanism to protect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Europe. But let me reflect: the rule of law can be undermined in many ways, also through the abuse of the rule of law itself. Therefore, this mechanism should also monitor cases of abuse or, if you prefer, arbitrary use of the rule of law, which can also lead to situations of violation of fundamental rights. For example, it is only from this perspective that the dramatic reality that today in the Spanish State the former president of the Parliament of Catalonia has been in pre-trial detention for not banning certain debates and certain votes in the Catalan Chamber. Only in this way can we analyze the dramatic reality of having political prisoners absurdly accused of rebellion, when all they have done is promote democracy and debate, never violence or subversion. Mr Timmermans, the abuse of the rule of law also jeopardizes democracy and fundamental rights and, as much as you deny it, this is what is happening in the Spanish State.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would very much like to know why they do not answer our parliamentary questions when we talk about the importance of fundamental rights in the Spanish State and, in particular, I would very much like to focus on these questions concerning the Franco Foundation. Do you know that the Franco Foundation makes the apology of fascism in the Spanish state? We have a unique opportunity in this Parliament today, and women rapporteurs in this Parliament, and I look at some present, we have achieved a joint resolution to fight neo-fascism in Europe, which will have the support of five parliamentary groups. On the basis of this resolution to be voted on On Thursday, we will also have new mechanisms for greater coordination in the defence of fundamental rights. But I would like you, Commissioner, to answer our questions. These are questions for the defence of the rule of law as well and that is present in this vote, which will also be an open door to this fight against intransigence and fascism still present in many Member States.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr First Vice-President, from an affirmative perspective, I believe that this instrument must, first of all, be based on a very clear legal basis, which prevents ambiguities and conflicts with other instruments or provisions of other mechanisms. Secondly, as regards the guarantee of applicability, this mechanism must be explicitly applicable to all Member States without exception and this must be stipulated expressis verbis, as the assessment of alleged systematic infringements must be the result of a neutral and objective process accepted as such from the time the mechanism was established. Then the council's role is essential, Mr First Vice-President, the Council with the two-thirds mechanism prevents what the Court of Auditors of the European Union said - the arbitrariness and potential discretion in the hands of the Commission, as well as Parliament's approval of a decision thus adopted. Finally, the adoption could be finalised, if the proposal is balanced and just, on the occasion of the next rotating presidency, but with the guarantees that other colleagues have asked for here in Parliament - neutrality, objectivity, no moving targets and no double standards.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the most ridiculous thing I’ve seen today is a tweet just put on Twitter by Ms in 't Veld where she writes: ‘EU Commission Vice President @TimmermansEU sees no need for a comprehensive mechanism for safeguarding the rule of law in Europe. Apparently everything is just fine’. I can stand a bit of political rhetoric, but here you just make yourself ridiculous. Have you not seen what we’ve done over the last couple of years? Have you not had the time to look – even glance over – the Commission Work Programme, where we announced that we will take these measures, and still you come up with that tweet? Have you not had a debate with me on these issues so many times over the last couple of years, and still you come up with that tweet? How can I take that seriously? And by the way, do I really have to explain to this Chamber what the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism is, where that comes from? Do I really have to explain that Article 2 is binding on every Member State and that, as a result of Article 2, the separation of powers is an essential element of the working of the rule of law in the Member States? Do I really have to explain that to you, Mr Marias, still, after all these years? I think not, frankly speaking. And do I still have to hear, every time a country is criticised: ʻOh, you shouldn’t be criticising us – double standards – look somewhere elseʼ. Is that the nature of this debate? I hope not. I hope we can find a mechanism that is more structured. I hope we can improve the rule-of-law mechanism. But be very careful that you don’t give an excuse to those who don’t want to be under scrutiny, who want to have the freedom to do whatever they like with the rule of law, that they can say, you know: ʻAs long as there’s no mechanism, don’t look at us’. The Commission takes its responsibilities extremely seriously, and we have done that over the last four years. It’s not always been easy, but we will continue to do that. This is our responsibility. This is what we take seriously. Article 7 is a very concrete measure. The lists of infringement procedures are very concrete measures. Asking the European Court of Justice for interim measures to safeguard the independence of the Supreme Court in Poland is a very concrete measure, and the Court of Justice has acted on that request of the Commission in a very concrete way. This is what we are doing very concretely, and I would not want what we are doing concretely to be relativised by saying: but we need a more comprehensive mechanism. There could be very good arguments for a more comprehensive mechanism, but it’s not an alternative for what we’re doing; it’s additional to what we’re doing and it should not weaken what we’re doing. Finalement, une remarque, parce que j’ai entendu M. Lebreton citer Jacques Prévert, ce qui m’a un peu étonné étant donné l’orientation politique de Jacques Prévert et celle de M. Lebreton. Je voudrais donc le confronter avec quelques lignes de Jacques Prévert qui représentent pour moi aussi l’accomplissement de l’intégration européenne depuis la Seconde Guerre mondiale. C’est aussi une très belle réponse à ceux qui croient que le nationalisme proposerait un futur pour l’Union européenne. Et je cite Jacques Prévert: «Soyez prévenus vieillards, soyez prévenus chefs de famille, le temps où vous donniez vos fils à la patrie comme on donne du pain aux pigeons, ce temps-là ne reviendra pas, prenez-en votre parti, c’est fini, le temps des cerises ne reviendra plus», Jacques Prévert.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as background to this discussion, let me assure you once again that the Austrian Presidency and the Council as a whole attaches great importance to upholding democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. They are at the heart of our concerns, as has been mentioned a few times today. I agree with Commissioner Timmermans when he stated that we should seek a better use of the given instruments. Of course, this does not prevent us from constantly reviewing and improving these instruments. However, let me say a word regarding the doubts about the efficiency of these instruments and, in particular, regarding the Article 7 procedure, which were raised, directly or indirectly, by several Members of the Parliament. I would not describe it only as piecemeal; on the contrary, it is a very important instrument, which has several stages to tackle the issue at stake in different ways, starting with the dialogue and hearings, peer reviews and recommendations, up to sanctioning. In any case, it would be premature at this stage to draw negative conclusions about this very complex procedure, which is being used, as you know, for the first time. To conclude: we, the Council, will continue to follow this debate closely, and I can assure Members that I have paid particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Our debate is of the utmost importance because it sets the record straight. I hear those who denounce Parliament's alleged inability to respond to authoritarian excesses in Europe. But we have solutions besides the Article 7 procedure.  In October 2016, two years ago, this assembly voted for a mechanism for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. We have urged the Commission to make it a legislative proposal, but our request has remained unanswered. However, serious violations have only increased in the last two years. This mechanism would include a scoreboard that would continuously indicate the situation in all states. Parliament and the Council will debate country-by-country recommendations annually. It is a systematic and comprehensive surveillance, which allows Europe to react before it is too late. This proposal already exists with respect to our economic governance. The Union has a strong legislative base here to scrutinise economic and fiscal rules. We simply ask for the same intransigence and firmness when it comes to our core values, when it comes to the fundamental rights of our citizens.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Assessing whether democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are being breached systemically depends on analysis of the available facts, duly proven. It also frequently depends on subjective points of views adopted for political and other reasons that filter into the assessments being made. Unless this is recognized, there can be no worthwhile approach to spotlighting and correcting breaches. Mutual trust among Member States and their legal systems underpins what the EU stands for. Yet the ideological consensus that used to prevail among Member States seems to be breaking down. The risk has increased that allegations of breaches of our fundamental values get instrumentalised from within polities for partisan reasons. They are then promoted at European levels to foment criticism directed at the government of the day. I have seen this happening for my country Malta. And in this House. I cannot rule out that it might be happening for other Member States. We cannot allow procedures by which allegations of breaches in fundamental values are investigated to be politicised and made suspect. The urgency therefore is to construct a mechanism that can be accepted by all as objective, fair, transparent and deliberate in correcting any such breaches.

name: Presidente. –
text: L'ordine del giorno reca, in discussione congiunta, - la relazione di Carlos Coelho, a nome della commissione per le libertà civili, la giustizia e gli affari interni, sull'istituzione, l'esercizio e l'uso del sistema d'informazione Schengen nel settore delle verifiche di frontiera (COM(2016)0882 - C8-0533/2016 - 2016/0408(COD)) (A8-0347/2017), - la relazione di Carlos Coelho, a nome della commissione per le libertà civili, la giustizia e gli affari interni, sull'istituzione, l'esercizio e l'uso del sistema d'informazione Schengen nel settore della cooperazione di polizia e della cooperazione giudiziaria in materia penale (COM(2016)0883 - C8-0530/2016 - 2016/0409(COD)) (A8-0349/2017), e - la relazione di Jeroen Lenaers, a nome della commissione per le libertà civili, la giustizia e gli affari interni, sull'uso del sistema d'informazione Schengen per il rimpatrio di cittadini di paesi terzi il cui soggiorno è irregolare (COM(2016)0881 - C8-0532/2016 - 2016/0407(COD)) (A8-0348/2017).

name: Carlos Coelho
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos and Commissioner King, Mr King, ladies and gentlemen, we all want to strengthen the security of our borders, better protect our citizens and defend free movement. For all this, we need to improve the Schengen Information System.  It took us about six months in the interinstitutional negotiations on the SIS, half of what we had taken in the previous reform. In this half year, we have fought for more security, for more freedom, for more Schengen for the benefit of European citizens. This reform of the Schengen Information System adapts the system to the challenges posed by migration, responds to new threats from terrorism and organised crime, takes advantage of technological developments and strengthens respect for fundamental rights, in particular data protection. At a time when the European Union is accused of not responding in a timely manner to the needs of citizens, the implementation of this reform begins early next year. For the first time, moreover, we have a deadline for this reform to come into operation, as well as mechanisms that ensure greater control and transparency over costs. Measures of the most elementary common sense, it will be said, but that have always encountered a lot of resistance, but this time it will be different. Member States and the Commission must meet deadlines and budgets. Within the estimated cost schedule, the new SIS must be fully operational. The impact of this reform is profound. The new Schengen Information System will change the way border police authorities share information in Europe. We don't need more information, we need better information. We will better protect our children, not only when the worst has already happened and we do not know their whereabouts, on the contrary, through new alerts for children at risk. We will be able to prevent these abductions or realities as dramatic as genital mutilation, but we will also improve the safety of all through closer monitoring of so-called foreign fighters and other criminals, through new means of obtaining information, inquiry checks, through better biomedical data such as fingerprints and facial images. It will be possible not only to carry out research with these elements, but also to search throughout Europe for perpetrators of unknown crimes, but whose fingerprint was found at the crime scene.  We will improve controls at our external borders. We are carry out the largest ever revision of the bans on entry into Schengen. It will be virtually impossible for anyone refused by Portugal to be able to enter Germany, but certain requirements will have to be met.  We improve the responsiveness of the system, increase its processing capacity, and strengthen your defenses against potential attacks, security issues, or simple failures. And we ask for more effectiveness from the Member States. The response times of the Siren Offices have been shortened and requests for information in cases relating to children or terrorism require immediate response. Last but not least, we put The SIS at the heart of European action by providing access to Frontex and Europol, further increasing the value of its action. I am confident, Mr President, that tomorrow this House will approve without reservation the third reform of the Schengen Information System. I believe that more Europe, which more SIS allows better information and better coordination, allows more security and more freedom.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, let me first of all thank Mr Carlos Coelho, Commissioners King and Avromopoulos and all the shadow rapporteurs who worked with us on this result, and of course the Council, in particular the Estonian and Bulgarian Presidency. I think we have achieved a very good result. The Schengen Information System is a crucial part of our security policy. It is a part that actually works very well, but about which we often hear very little. It is crucial that national authorities, the police, the judiciary can access information about, for example, wanted persons, persons who need to be monitored discreetly, who need to be apprehended, missing persons and missing children, but also stolen items such as cars, passports or weapons. Let me mention some numbers to tell you what happens to that system. It is consulted five billion times a year. We've included over 70 million of these kinds of alerts in that system. 450 times a day in the EU we have a hit based on this system. We have arrested 40 000 suspects on the basis of this system, 150 000 people refused at the border, 28 000 missing persons found, 200 000 objects recovered. These are all very impressive figures, but we can always do better and it always has to be better, and that is why this reform of the Schengen Information System. Carlos Coelho has already said a number of things, so let me go a little deeper into one specific part, which is to include return decisions in the Schengen Information System. This is an important step, because we all know that today we are struggling to actually return people who have not been granted asylum in Europe and who actually have to return to their country of origin. At present, only 37% of cases succeed. This means that in almost two thirds of cases, people who have come here, who have not been granted asylum, will still stay. That number, that percentage must definitely go up, if we want to maintain support under the common asylum policy. This needs to be improved and the Schengen Information System can help.  Now, when a Member State has decided not to grant asylum and a person has to go back to the country of origin, we offer a voluntary return, so to speak, put a check mark behind it and believe that it is good. There are two problems here. First of all, we don't know if that person actually left. Secondly, if that person turns up in another Member State, the authorities there often do not know that a return decision has already been taken in another country and we start from scratch. We are solving these two problems today. Once someone has actually crossed the EU's external border, the original Member State is informed and corrected so that we can focus our energies on the people who are still here. From now on, police forces can see in the system whether someone has already been identified as a person who has to return to their country of origin, so that cooperation is much easier to make that happen efficiently. This is an important step towards making the return policy more efficient. At the same time, we must therefore be careful. It is precisely for this reason that we in the European Parliament have ensured that the guarantees in this area are also seriously strengthened. When a return decision is suspended or postponed, the alert is removed. The principle of non-refoulement and the Geneva Convention are explicitly incorporated. Safeguards in the field of data protection are being greatly improved, both in terms of data retention and cooperation with third countries in this area. So in summary, Mr President, we have managed to bring the return policy one step closer to real efficiency, while at the same time ensuring that the safeguards and rights of individuals are respected at all times. That is a very good result and we should be proud of that.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very pleased to be here with you tonight for the final debate on our three proposals for a reinforced Schengen Information System. I would like to thank wholeheartedly the rapporteurs, Mr Coelho and Mr Lenaers; the shadow rapporteurs, their teams and all those involved on this file for enabling us to have this debate tonight. This agreement was the result of intense work and I would like to congratulate them for it. At the core, the Schengen Information System is about one thing: trust. The trust to share sensitive information with EU partners. The trust to follow up on alerts shared by EU partners. The trust to rely on the Schengen Information System when the security of our citizens is at stake. The SIS today contains over 80 million alerts on wanted and missing persons and objects. Just last year it was accessed 5.2 billion times. Since 2013, when we first had SIS in its current form, it has led to 50 000 arrests and the tracking of 200 000 serious criminals. These numbers are clear testament to its value for our Member States. It is no exaggeration to say that it is the centrepiece of our security cooperation in Europe and our most important instrument for information exchange in the European Union. It was against this background that we proposed – in December 2016, as you will remember – to further strengthen the system. But the question is: why change a system that performed so well? Because with the dramatic improvements in information-sharing during the past three years, a stronger SIS can open a new chapter in our cooperation on internal security and can contribute to the coherent application of the rules and principles governing the Schengen area. The new rules will help with the effective enforcement of entry bans for third-country nationals at the external borders by making the entry of their data into the SIS compulsory. With the introduction of a new alert category for return decisions, the SIS will also provide an efficient tool for the implementation of EU policies on return. Member States will now be obliged to enter alerts where a person or an object is sought for a terrorist offence. The role of Europol will be strengthened, as it will now have access to all alerts and supplementary information exchanges, while Member States will be obliged to inform Europol of any alerts related to terrorist offences. The operational teams of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency will also have their own access to SIS in order to carry out checks at the hotspots. The new SIS will make better use of biometric data, with the possibilities of using palm prints, facial images and DNA profiles in specific cases, when safeguards are met. This will build on the Automated Fingerprint Identification System we introduced to SIS earlier this year, which has already led to a 25% increase in the number of alerts containing fingerprints. In parallel, the reinforcement of SIS will strengthen the protection of personal data by aligning the SIS provisions with the new data protection framework. There will also be important improvements for the work of law enforcement authorities and strong links to our work on interoperability, which Julian will tell you more about in a minute. Interoperability, like our security initiatives on electronic evidence, explosives and terrorist content online, is vital for the security of our citizens, and it is essential that they advance rapidly to adoption before the May elections. What I would like to leave you with is that, with this debate tonight and tomorrow’s vote, Europe’s most widely-used secure database will become even stronger.
