A strengthened SIS will provide police and border guards with the information they need to do their jobs and help keep Europeans safe. It is the most concrete example of all our work to change the culture on how we cooperate on security in the European Union: a Europe that protects; a genuine and effective Security Union to ensure the security of our citizens. With this in mind, I encourage you to support this important initiative when you vote tomorrow.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Schengen Information System (SIS) is the centrepiece of our network of information exchange and the main law enforcement database that we have. But its real strength lies in the fact that it is used. It is used every day. It has been integrated into the everyday work of over two million police officers and border guards across Europe, whose job it is to try and keep us safe. It is an undoubted success. In addition to some of the figures that we’ve already heard, between 2013 and 2017 the SIS also contributed to over 28 000 missing persons being found; to the tracing of more than 180 000 persons needed to assist with a criminal judicial procedure; and to almost 200 000 cases concerning stolen objects – vehicles, identity, travel documents and firearms – being solved, all using the SIS. I would like to join the speakers who have already thanked Mr Coelho, Mr Lenaers and all those who worked on reaching agreement on these proposals for improving the system. The improvements that we’ve agreed – that you’ve agreed – will make a real, positive contribution to the fight against terrorism and serious and organised crime. As we have heard, they will make the exchange of information more efficient. The new obligation to enter an alert in relation to a terrorist offence will be applicable immediately. Together with the provisions on information sharing in the directive on countering terrorism, this is an important step towards information sharing by default, which many of you in this House have argued for. New alert categories, like the new inquiry check, will provide key investigative tools for law enforcement authorities. The proposed changes will also allow the SIS alerts to be used for unknown persons wanted in connection with a crime on the basis of fingerprints or palm prints discovered at the scene of the crime – for instance, when fingerprints are found on a weapon that has been used – all subject to certain safeguards. The new SIS will strengthen support for the prevention and investigation of theft and counterfeiting by providing for alerts to be issued on a wider range of stolen and falsified goods and documents. In parallel to these measures, we’ve also been working with the Member States to make the system more user friendly for frontline officers, and we have thus seen the number of checks made against the SIS increase by 40% in 2016, compared with the year before, and by a further 30% year-on-year in 2017. Dimitris Avramopoulos has already mentioned the Automated Fingerprint Identification System (AFIS). To date, 12 Member States are using AFIS to identify people at the external borders or on their territory. This has already led to a number of hits on people who would not have been identified otherwise, such as, to give one example, the man who claimed asylum on arrival at Schiphol without identity documents. After a fingerprint check on AFIS, it was found that there was a warrant out for his arrest in Germany. That’s the kind of practical result that these new systems, incorporating biometrics, can deliver. We are now working with the other Member States to ensure that they too implement biometrics. Under the new proposals, the use of AFIS will be mandatory for all Member States by the end of 2020, which in itself will mark an important milestone in the fight against multiple or fraudulent identities. But, as Dimitris Avramopoulos underlined, there’s still more to do on this. So, finally, let me briefly link the strengthening of the SIS with our wider work towards the interoperability of EU information systems for security, border and migration management. The reinforced SIS sits at the core of our proposals on interoperability, i.e. our work to ensure that national authorities have the information they need, when and where they need it, with all the safeguards offered by our fundamental rights framework. By closing down the gaps that terrorists and criminals can exploit, we can cut down on identity fraud and strengthen our external border security and our internal security. I very much welcomed the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) Committee adopting its negotiating mandate on interoperability last week, and I look forward to the start of trilogues soon on this important subject. Thank you for your support.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, we have already heard it, the Schengen Information System is at the heart of security cooperation within the European Union. The adjustments we are going to propose today are actually desperately needed to increase our security in the fight against terror. Hence the facial recognition and the use of fingerprints. They are all necessary adjustments. But today I am particularly pleased with what my colleague Gérard Deprez has achieved. The preventive warnings for children at risk of being victimised by a parent abduction, child marriage or genital mutilation. That reform was desperately needed. Just like the reform we are implementing for the children in migration, for the children on the run. Finally, it will be possible to use DNA profiles to identify and detect them more quickly. Ladies and gentlemen, this third reform of the Schengen Information System will undoubtedly increase our security in Europe.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The Schengen Information System, like the Schengen area, is itself a European success story. It represents the most tangible achievement of European citizens, internal borderlessness, while not jeopardising their security. After all, in 2015 only, the competent national authorities inspected persons and objects nearly 2.9 billion times for safety on the basis of data stored in the SIS. The new proposal to be voted on tomorrow will further strengthen this security element of the Schengen system so that it can respond adequately to the challenges posed by new migration and terrorism. It is to be welcomed that the procedure for the search for missing children will finally be given greater attention, faster and more effective, the success of which can often depend on the first twenty-four hours. The procedure against illegal migrants awaiting deportation or subject to entry bans will become more effective. Storing portraits makes it easier to identify criminals and terrorists. The renewed system is in line with the aspirations of the European People's Party, as it reflects all its convictions that there is no freedom without security. And this next-generation information system will increase our security. At the same time, we must not forget that our internal borderlessness can only be maintained as long as we can guarantee the security of our external borders.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me first of all thank the rapporteurs, Mr Coelho and Mr Lenaers, with whom we worked closely and had a good working relationship. I can say that the Schengen Information System that we negotiated together is a valuable tool which can help build resilience against terrorist threats and can help keep our citizens secure and safe. The effectiveness and efficiency of the system can always be further strengthened, but I believe that what we have achieved is a good balance to ensure the safety of our citizens across the European Union. As the S&D Group we have welcomed the revision of SIS. However, we wanted to strike the right balance between gathering data and the fundamental rights of our citizens. This is a system primarily designed for the purpose of police and border control, and with this in mind, it is crucial to establish a system that will not jeopardise the right to privacy, the right to the protection of personal data, and procedural rights in criminal cases. On behalf of my Group, I have pushed for proper safeguards for the biometric data stored in the system. Our focus was to establish uniform rules for securely addressing and processing Schengen Information System data. We have given special attention to the safety of all civilians and included preventive alerts for vulnerable third-country nationals and victims of human trafficking, but also for missing children or children at high risk of parental abduction. For me, it was pivotal not only to address the fight against human trafficking and child abduction but also to ensure that their fundamental rights with regard to their personal data are protected. Information exchange in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and in the field of border checks is essential, particularly since the great majority of individuals involved in perpetrating terrorist attacks in Europe within the last decade have been EU citizens. Many were foreign fighters; most were already known to the European authorities. Let me emphasise a final point about SIS II. SIS II is based on the principle of mutual trust and requires Schengen states to enforce each other’s SIS alerts. It means that states have a duty to check an alert’s lawfulness and proportionality, particularly if its enforcement would violate the fundamental rights of the person involved. Based on this principle, the relevant authorities should check first whether any action would violate the person’s fundamental rights, because the improvement of the system should never come at the expense of the protection of the individual’s fundamental rights. We have the tools to guarantee the safety of our citizens; now we need to make sure that Member States implement properly this regulation. Thanks a lot, and once again thank you to the rapporteurs.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased with the legislative package on the Schengen Information System. This increases the efficiency of the SIS database in terms of border security, monitoring the return of illegal immigrants and police cooperation. Moreover, this database is crucial for our security in the light of the free movement of people within the Schengen area. However, an evaluation revealed shortcomings, ranging from quality problems, a lack of training among police officers to insufficient information on signalling and delays in the follow-up of hits. These proposals are now eliminating these shortcomings, but it goes beyond purely cosmetic adjustments or technical improvements. Now, people can only be searched in the database by, for example, their name or date of birth. But in the future, criminals can be tracked down by their fingerprints. So we're done with identity fraud. Also important is that fingerprints, found at the crime scene, can be entered into the system. This increases the chances of criminals fleeing. A more efficient and user-friendly database is absolutely necessary so that our police forces and border guards can do their job properly. Together with the interoperability of databases by linking all kinds of databases, we are taking a new step forward in the fight against crime, people smuggling and terror. I therefore call on all the political groups to vote in favour of these much-needed amendments. After all, safety is a matter for all of us.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, there are many European citizens - and I am in this way - who rejoice and enjoy freedom of movement in the European area. But what the citizens know less and what our two excellent rapporteurs Carlos Coelho and Jeroen Lenaers know perfectly - I would like to congratulate them - is the central role that the Schengen Information System (SIS) plays in guaranteeing this freedom. For the obligatory corollary of freedom of movement is the effective control of external borders and increased cooperation between police forces within the European common area. Commissioners Avramopoulos and King, as well as Jeroen Lenaers, recalled indisputable figures on the current effectiveness of the Schengen information system. But this efficiency, however great it was already, still had too many shortcomings that we had denounced. So it was necessary to improve it. That is what is proposed to this house in these three reports. Firstly, from now on Member States will have to introduce a report into the SIS for anyone involved in terrorist offences or crimes. Europol will be instantly notified, which will allow the rapid initiation of cooperation between European police forces. Secondly, from now on, Member States will have to introduce a report in the SIS for anyone who has been banned from staying on European territory. This is not currently the case and this significantly impedes the enforcement of decisions to leave the territory. Thirdly, from now on, Member States will be able to include in the SIS a report for missing children, children at risk of abduction, girls threatened with forced marriage or genital mutilation. With these changes, ladies and gentlemen, the SIS will no longer only be a repressive tool, which remains necessary, but will also become an effective means of protecting the most vulnerable, which should please us all. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you, if you are worried about improving the Schengen information system, then maybe you will ask the President of your group, Mr Verhofstadt, who invited Lyudmił Kozlowski, who was banned from entering the European Union by the Polish special services, as the Ukrainian services subsequently confirmed, that he was a dangerous person. The President of your group calls her an alleged Polish dissident and shows her in this Parliament in defiance of the ban issued by the Polish authorities. How do you comment on this?

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: answer 'blue card'. Mr Verhofstadt was absolutely right to do what he did, because in the case you mentioned, the reporting in the Schengen information system by the Polish authorities was a real diversion and that is why we did not accept it and we granted that person a right of access.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the Schengen information system is an indispensable tool to guarantee freedom of movement in the Schengen area and the security of citizens. My group supports proposals that improve the exchange of relevant information between Member States, an essential element in the effective fight against terrorism, organised crime and child abduction. But extending the use of this file for return decisions will help to increase the criminalization of migration. On the other hand, threats to public order are too vague concepts that allow some Member States to abuse them by entering alerts into the system on strictly political grounds. This is particularly the case in Poland, which prohibits Ukrainian human rights defender Lyudmyla Kozlovska from entering the Schengen area via this type of alert. Guarantees are therefore essential so that these files do not become a political instrument in the hands of unscrupulous states, nor a Big Brother with all our biometric data.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, will SIS II be the new European Big Brother? The Schengen information system created in 1990 was the counterpart to the abolition of border controls. It mainly concerned stolen vehicles, missing persons and third-country nationals banned from residence. A simple tool for police cooperation. Its scope has continued to expand in terms of included reports, data collected and the number of people who have access to it. More than 5 billion consultations, 76 million reports and more than 2 million users. I am concerned about the rights of those who were reported and who had nothing to complain about. The ratio is not good and the scope will be further expanded, including those suspected of intending to commit an offence. Suspicion of intent: this is a new criminal standard that is quite far from the presumption of innocence. We will be able to integrate anyone - we just heard it - into a crime file without the people who even know it. All third-country nationals subject to a return order or a refusal to enter the country will also be denied. This is an additional step in the criminalization of so-called "irregular" migrants, the vast majority of whom are people in distress. Alphanumeric data collection, facial images, digital or palm data, and even DNA in some cases are also being increased. Yes! our citizens have a right to security, new technologies can help but not at any cost, not by developing a climate of widespread suspicion at the expense of fundamental rights, especially in the wrong hands. For us, it's no!

name: Giancarlo Scottà
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, why continue to want to put the citizens of Europe in the background? The European Commission's proposal, although it can be improved, was already acceptable. In view of this, however, Parliament's action has weakened a text that could, given the wide differences between Member States, particularly in the area of the judiciary, strengthen cooperation between the competent authorities of the States in order to tackle irregular immigration together. Once again, therefore, we have missed an opportunity. The right to seek asylum has never been called into question, but we, as a direct expression of our citizens, have the task of ensuring the security of our territories. Therefore, within a framework of full guarantee with regard to the protection of people's fundamental rights and the principles enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, we must work on a review and reorganisation of the discipline linked to the issue of irregular immigration, looking at the reality of the situation more frankly.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, nothing illustrates the long-term aim of the European Union more clearly than the increasing weakening of the national borders by Schengen. The Commission brags that the Schengen Information System is the most important information exchange system in Europe. No doubt it is. The vast body of information kept on you, me and everyone else who has ever crossed a European border makes George Orwell’s 1984 nightmare look kind, generous and liberal.  Schengen is supposed to keep those inside safe and control who comes in from outside. It does neither. Terrorist slaughter has taken place inside the Schengen Area, committed by evil men who go between Europe and the Middle East at ease and at will. Schengen stops none of it. Still, the Commission wants to hold more information on all of us. It is further to weaken powers of the nation states. Without control, borders dissolve. Without borders, nations dissolve. That is the long-term aim of the European Union.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I support these proposals, of course. A whole universe of security summarized in a minute. This demonstrates the low quality of our parliamentary system: three reports, two Commissioners. So, making a synthesis effort, I'll say four words. Congratulations to Carlos and Jeroen and I'll take these four inputs: interviews, prints, facial images and DNA profiles. They are decisive in improving the safety of Europeans, they are necessary to make adequate use of the system revision and this will facilitate, Commissioner King, their commitment, which I share, to interoperability in the 2020s.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, since it was launched in 1995, Schengen is equivalent for Europeans to the free movement of people and is therefore one of the most precious assets of the Acquis and European construction and must be protected. And we are taking a step in that direction with these three Regulations in a joint debate: external borders, police and judicial cooperation, and also return. Three Regulations that are incardinated in strengthening security in the management of external borders, also to better control migration flows, which connects with the entry and exit system, the visa information system, and even Eurodac – biometric registers, with all new technologies.  But we have also emphasized some elements that are very relevant. The first, which we are making available to the interoperability of databases, elements affecting people's fundamental rights, and the guarantee objective is indispensable for this Parliament and cannot be ignored or forgotten.  Secondly, That Schengen is called into question because security threats have resulted in temporary suspensions in a good number of Member States and it is imperative that the indispensable objective is the full restoration of the free movement of persons and, therefore, the preservation of the Schengen asset. Thirdly, that this data interoperability can also serve to better protect people, particularly the most vulnerable, for example children, minors crossing the Union's borders and cannot disappear afterwards, as Europol's terrible report has shown — no less than ten thousand missing children. And finally, that the Schengen system cannot be fully linked to the return of irregular immigrants, because, if it is true that we must strengthen security, it is also true that we cannot give up the vision we call holistic, comprehensive, general of the migration phenomenon, of the migratory event, in order to give it the proper treatment that this European Parliament has so often called for in its resolutions.

name: Kristina Winberg (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Information exchanges are basically good, especially in the case of third-country nationals. We need to be in control of who moves within the borders of the European Union. I will therefore vote in favour of this proposal. But don't forget the failed internal border controls. Sweden has this week been heavily criticised for its lack of border controls in a classified report. Failed by the EU on 95 points. But we do not know exactly what this is about, and we must not know either. However, even effective border controls do not solve all problems. An asylum process in Sweden is approximately 500 days in time. Many of those who are rejected refuse to accept the decision. The EU should call on Member States such as Sweden to make return more effective with shorter working times and more detention places, which is unfortunately needed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, uncontrolled illegal immigration and the need to combat terrorism oblige states to increase controls at their borders. That's very normal. At the same time, however, they are also seeking to improve the Schengen Information System. One of the improvements is the addition to it of information referring to biometric characteristics. This data is particularly sensitive and should not be recorded in the system unless it has been carefully examined and analysed.  Particular attention should be paid to biometric data from vulnerable groups, such as young children. On the other hand, it is also necessary to ensure the security of this data so that it is not used in a way that infringes fundamental rights. Furthermore, we should bear in mind that the purpose of this system is to protect us from terrorism and organised crime and not to create a 'big brother'.

name: Innocenzo Leontini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, improving the effectiveness of returns is essential in order to maintain public confidence in the European Union's immigration and asylum policies. Thanks to the revision of the Schengen Information System, it will be possible for the first time to set up a system for the exchange of information between Member States on return decisions. This system will make it possible to verify whether third-country nationals have actually left the territory of the Member States. In addition, the new SIS will make it possible to combat terrorism and organised crime more effectively, through mandatory reporting of people linked to terrorist activities, sharing the DNA of wanted criminals and greater cooperation with Europol. For all these reasons, I fully support the excellent work carried out by Mr Lenaers and Mr Coelho, which aims to further strengthen the SIS at European level and to fill some of the gaps that have been present so far at national level. I hope, in order to provide the police and coastguard with the most appropriate tools, that the new legal framework will become applicable as soon as possible.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the efforts of the last few years of the European Union - because they have been efforts - have actually faced new things, migration management, integrated border management, cross-border crime. We had an SIS system, the change that we now want to make if there is a vote - and I hope that this new regulation is voted on - is absolutely started from a finding. In 2016, the Commission made an assessment - and I think we need to make such assessments, because things are changing - and the Commission's conclusion was that we must do it and it came up with a proposal before Parliament to amend the SIS regulation. The rapporteurs and we all tried to find a situation, they were colleagues who criticised. We do not have ideal situations - of course we can think that there will be people who will be suspected without guilt or making their mark and not agreeing with some people - but the important thing is to increase the safety and security of citizens in the European Union - speak 'the space', not only in the Schengen area - and I think the report, by the Commission proposal and the amendments made , achieves its goal. Obviously at some point we can improve after an analysis, but now I think the aim is to increase safety - and this is where the report is going - and I hope it is voted on, because we need to increase safety. Cross-border crime has increased and we need a safer system.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner King, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has The new regulation of the Schengen Information System is a major step towards the European Security Union in order to massively strengthen the impact against terrorism, serious crime, organised crime, illegal migration – yes – and the abuse of asylum at the EU's external borders, as well as in the day-to-day work of the police and judiciary, Europol, Frontex and Eurojust. The use of facial recognition, biometrics, fingerprints and handprints and DNA will become a matter of course from 2019 to 2020. This is a success for Europe. The next step will be the full networking of all EU databases. Because that is our goal: every official, every official must be able to identify dangerous persons at all times and be able to act immediately. And that is the interoperability that has been achieved. Congratulations to the Commission and the rapporteurs. Let us continue this effective work consistently, and we owe it to the people of Europe!

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by greeting the rapporteurs and in particular Mr Coelho who, over the last few years here in the European Parliament, has contributed in an extraordinary way to finding balanced and fair solutions in such a difficult sector. Those who think it is possible to guarantee freedom in a context of insecurity are roundly mistaken. There is no better culture broth to favor the emergence of titanic solutions than a picture of insecurity.  Insecurity is often the desire for excessive protection that immediately leads to the valorization of tyranny, and therefore we must be well-informed that a free society must also be a secure society and we must strike a balance between these two dimensions, between the dimension of protecting citizens' security and the size of , of course, respect for the fundamental rights of those citizens. However, the work that has been done here is precisely in this sense: the modernisation of an essential instrument, the SIS system which is the fundamental instrument for ensuring the strengthening of security, particularly at the external borders, and, at the same time, safeguarding the fundamental rights of European citizens. We only have reason to be satisfied with this job.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, we know that Schengen is one of the great success stories of Europe, but, of course, this story needs to be upgraded so that our citizens can live in complete freedom and use this freedom of movement. Fascinating are the figures you mentioned here, both commissioners, on the number of entries to SIS1, in SIS 2, on the number of cases detected. So the numbers are really fascinating and that SIS 1 and SIS 2 are certainly good, however, they definitely need to be upgraded to prevent all possible situations happening at the borders. However, I would like to note that the internal security of citizens of the European Union cannot be good unless the external border is secured.  I would not be consistent if I did not take the opportunity in this debate to mention Croatia, which has the longest external border in the European Union, of 1350 km, and which is not yet the Schengen border. So once again, I know we are working on it, I know that we meet the criteria, but we certainly expect that even though we are already using SIS 1 and SIS 2, we will finally approach this free Schengen zone so that we too can help keep the European Union from being a fortress, but that we know who is on our territory, who is entering through our borders. I believe it is in the interest of all of you from other Countries of the European Union.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly I would like to thank Carlos Coelho and Jeroen Lenaers, the rapporteurs, for the great job and balanced solution. These three regulations establish not only significant improvements for the Schengen Information System but create the new order. They open up the possibility to exchange more information among Member States’ agencies and to improve the security of our borders against terrorists by real time checks and the sharing of information. They support the effectiveness of the prevention, detection and investigation of criminal offences. On the other hand, they also make it possible to speed up searches, with the help of an adequate alert system, for missing children. These improvements strengthen trust and boost cooperation between Member States. Also, thanks to common technical standards, rules and semantic interoperability, they guarantee the efficiency of using the digital tools to collect the data – not more but better data – for a legitimate purpose and in an adequate way. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab You talked about efficiency, about a smooth system. I wanted to ask if you, who know the casus of Lyudmia Kozlowski expelled from Polish, do not think that there is a certain vulnerability, that some safeguards against political exploitation would have to be added to the SIS? Shouldn't we create the possibility of a possible appeal, a request for clarification, for those who are not allowed to enter the Schengen system, for those who are not allowed to enter the Schengen system? What do you think?

name: Michał Boni (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you for your question. The Schengen Information System should not be used under any political pressure or used for political purposes. As I said at the end of my speech, there must be a legitimate interest. When, as in the case of the Polish authorities, the security of the country is used as an alleged reason for the suspension of the mobility of Lyudmia Kozłowska, I believe that this is a violation of the Schengen rules, and I agree that there are possibilities for appeal – perhaps we should still discuss them.  By the way, I would just like to say to a colleague who has already spoken about the case of Ludmina Kozłowska that, firstly, she was invited not only by Mr Verhofstadt, but also by the German National Assembly, by many institutions. And even at today's press conference, when asked about this issue, the Ukrainian Foreign Minister did not give an answer saying that it is any kind of threat to Ukraine, and the Ukrainian authorities have never officially made this clear, and we spoke about matters related to Lyudmia Kozlovska in the official Ukrainian delegation in Kiev a month ago.

name: El presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I beg you to adjust to the times, please. Sir, Sosnierz, you've taken the floor before by lifting a blue card, I see now that in the 'catch de eye' shift you're going to step in again. Since this shift has numerous requests, I ask you to give up the blue card and take the floor in due course, in the turn that will now, in no time, begin.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the security of the european Union's external borders is fundamental and the Member States have a responsibility to protect their citizens. In order to improve Schengen information systems, Member States and Europol need to have closer cooperation and consistent information exchange, and this system is the solution. The common information system is in force in all 28 Member States, including Romania. The European Union can enjoy the active role played by Romania, a country that shares information through these common systems. Romania acquired the right to join the Schengen area when it signed the Treaty of Accession to the European Union, and this should no longer be delayed by the invention of a number of reasons by other Member States. Including in his speech today, President Juncker argued that, by the end of his mandate, Romania will be part of the Schengen area. And I want to point out, President Juncker, that you have only six months left.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, the concept of Europe as an open space without borders is one of the fundamental values that has brought thousands of citizens together and encouraged further integration with each other. From the challenges of the migrant crisis in 2015 to terrorist threats, the Schengen area has become a primary security political issue. The loss of trust in the system has erected walls where they have been demolished for decades.  The Republic of Croatia aims to enter the Schengen area by 2019 and takes care of Europe's external borders to the Western Balkans and responsibly fulfils its tasks along the way. That is why we have a good understanding of the importance of continuously improving the system between Member States, in order to avoid gaps in place during and after the migrant crisis.  Schengen will work best if we defend Europe's borders together, so as not to close ourselves internally. The Croatian side is certainly advancing in this direction by successfully implementing the Schengen Information System and other Schengen instruments. Encouraged by this progress, I believe Croatia will achieve its strategic goal and join the common space by 2019 and continue to protect Europe from future threats.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, congratulations to Mr Coelho. Schengen is undoubtedly an effective system in defending the European Union, in protecting borders against terrorism and organised crime. However, it is very important that it is constantly improved and that all participating States cooperate as closely as possible. Romania has been part of the SIS since 2010 and institutions such as the General Inspectorate of the Romanian Police or the Border Police Inspectorate have enjoyed great respect in working in an effective manner in the fight against cross-border crime. Romania also plays a decisive role in the security of the entire European Union and acts as a de facto Schengen state professionally defending more than 2 000 kilometres of border. Unfortunately, Romania's access to the Schengen area for 7 years is restricted by a political decision with economic-maritimo-protectionist sub-sublows, especially from the Netherlands, and this opposition successfully fuels the sceptical phenomenon in Romania. I hope that, in the very near future, Romania will become part of the Schengen area, as is right and just.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, although Romania and Bulgaria have been meeting the criteria for accession to the Schengen area - Romania since 2011 - and, although a resolution has been adopted in the plenary of the European Parliament since May to support the accession of these two countries to the Schengen area, it is October and the prospect of accession does not appear to be a close one.  I just want to draw attention, Mr President, to a reality that we sometimes hide or deny. The lack of Europeans' confidence in the European institutions also stems from such situations, in which the citizens of the Union find that, at this level, we are still talking about bureaucracy and political interests which, it seems, take precedence over the interests of the individual.  Nearly twenty million Romanians are deprived of a right belonging to them, as our country has fulfilled the required requirements. In addition, we are talking about the thousands of Romanian operators who trade and who find themselves having to wait for tens of hours to enter the Schengen area in motor vehicles in order to be checked and checked. I would like to thank you for the resolution adopted in this House in May. I cannot, however, fail to notice a lack of operationality of the other European institutions in terms of the implementation of the resolutions adopted in the plenary of the European Parliament, the image consequences for the European Union as a whole being among the most serious.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Mr King, I heard you and Mr Avramopoulos before, and I really thought about what the people of the Aegean islands would say by listening to you. Because you mentioned that you will restrict illegal entry into the European Union, it will be checked, fingerprints will be taken. I'm going to get you out Moria? The Moria hotspot where there are 10,000 people? Dare the police come in and check? Have you been to see what's in Moria? There's no man who dares to come by. Things are out of control. You're going to check on Souda, which is Chios, where the Greek police don't even dare enter? You're going to check on Samos?  Listen, why haven't thousands of illegal immigrants who are currently on the Aegean islands been repatriated? So the inhabitants of the Aegean islands would ask you if they were able to watch the debate. The residents of Evros would ask you why illegal immigrants now cross from Turkey to Bulgaria and then to Greece. Are you going to stop them? Are you going to fingerprint them? There must be seriousness in the operation of Frontex. There is no border guard and there is no maritime border. There is no frontex guard in Evros, which is a land border. There are no answers to these questions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I take advantage of this debate on the functioning of the Schengen Information System to insist that an efficient European security service requires an end to the filters that originate from the nationalism of the States that hold back so many European projects.  The Ertzaintza is the comprehensive police responsible for public safety in the Basque Country. It has enormous knowledge of organized crime and terrorism. It operates in a strategic geographical enclave for the transit of people and goods between the north and south of western Europe.  Therefore, direct operational participation in the SIS, without ineffective and inefficient intermediations or dependencies, is key to providing the resources and knowledge of this Police in the Union's security policies. In accordance with the legislation of the Member State itself and the Community, and from operational logic, the Ertzaintza must have its own representation in all international for a and commissions where security strategies are decided and coordinated; where direct connection points are established between European police and the continuation of many investigations is encouraged. That is why, Commissioner, I would like to know your opinion on this matter.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: " Mr President, the Trump Wall is here, it's with us in Europe, on the southern border of the Schengen area. It is a large fence with blades in Ceuta and Melilla. It's a fence that kills. On Sunday, two people died trying to cross it. Others, yes, arrive, but what is often the answer: hot returns. That is, breach of international law and judgments of the European Court of Human Rights, regardless of whether they are minors, asylum seekers or injured persons in need of health care. Spain and the European Union cannot continue to trampl on human rights or continue to outsource our borders to unsafe third countries. Because the migration issue is key to Europe's future. So let's be responsible, end hot returns, respect human rights and open up safe and legal routes of entry into the Schengen area. Let no one else have to die for having to migrate to Europe.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I ask why is this system, since every Member of this Parliament can challenge the decisions of the relevant authorities, the relevant services and invite excluded people, in the glare of the spotlight, to flaunt them. Mr Boni, i would like to thank you for your comments. Is this your defence of the rule of law? And on what basis do you question the decision of the Polish authorities? If you know better than them, we can save a lot. Instead of all these border services, authorities and special services, let us hire Mr Boni, Mr Verhofstadt, Mrs Rose Thun, to sit at the table and decide for us, we will not have to spend millions of euros on all these services.  You are leaking the system in the name of political struggle. Are you saying this is a political decision? And on what matter did Mr Verhofstadt invite Lyudmił Kozlowski here? In the name of political interests. In the name of the political fight against the Polish government, you are blowing up a system to protect us from terrorists and dangerous people. The Ukrainian services have issued a statement about Kozlowski that they consider her a dangerous person who has sought to change Ukraine's borders. This is most likely a person associated with Russian special services. And that's how the Russians controlled you here again.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much, it is a good thing, because I will take this opportunity to respond to those libels that we have heard a moment ago. This is indeed a loophole in the SIS, because this is indeed a high-profile case with a Ukrainian citizen who lived in Poland, is engaged with a Pole and, for clarification, both are involved in the Open Dialogue Foundation, which stigmatises human rights violations in Eastern Europe.  The Open Dialogue Foundation recently also took into account the state of the rule of law in Poland. However, Ludmiła Kozłowska was immediately expelled from Polish and entered on the LIST of SIS persons who are not allowed to enter Schengen. There was also immediately information – the ones we hear here too – that ukraine's security services considered her a dangerous person. But ukraine's security services immediately sent to the portal, which is spreading it, dementi that there is no such procedure at all in the case of Ms. Kozlowski. These rumors are repeated only by those who draw information from Putin's fake news. I have a short question for the Commissioner. What do you say, Commissioner? Shouldn't we immediately create some kind of security system for such people? Where can they appeal quickly? This matter is indeed very pressing.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when we discuss the Schengen Information System it is important to bear in mind that some Member States are ready to abuse it for their own anti-democratic agenda. Last month, Open Dialogue Foundation President Lyudmyla Kozlovska was deported out of Poland through the Schengen Information System because of her peaceful human rights activities. Although I knew that this excellent human rights organisation had been the target of intimidation and smear campaigns by several governments, I was shocked to learn about what happened to Lyudmyla.  The backlash against freedom of expression and rule of law in several Member States should be very concerning for all of us. I believe we should deeply question the way this system works and how it can be used by Member States that deliberately choose to overlook their human rights obligations and act like authoritarian regimes.  The case also says much about the way we approach our migration policies. Locking our borders at all costs has terrible consequences for human rights. I call on the EU to wake up and rethink its migration policy and come up with a more humane approach.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. Chairman, finishing and strengthening the Schengen Information System are essential as pressure on the Union's external borders does not subside, and security threats to our citizens.   The solutions presented in the reports represent progress in relation to past practice. It is truly astonishing that the Commission has done so little to align the criteria for warnings to refuse entry into the Schengen area. The proposed amendments finally correct obvious errors, and I am particularly pleased that those convicted of terrorism are among the undesirables. The main question is why this has not been done so far.   Croatia has finally gained access to the Schengen Information System, which will ease its path to Schengen membership. I hereby urge all those in charge to do so as soon as possible.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, forgive me, Members, for looking at these reports through the context of what might happen next March and Brexit, but the UK is the third-heaviest user of data on a daily basis through the SIS systems. Having recently joined Lord Willy Bach, the Police Commissioner for Leicestershire, in a series of meetings in Brussels, including with the Commissioner (who was very generous with his time), with parliamentarians and other agencies concerned with law enforcement, it is clear to me that that data and those tools are as important to modern policing as handcuffs. So it is critical over these next few months that we ensure – the UK government and the negotiators here – that that close cooperation through these systems between the UK and our partners here in the EU can continue, to ensure that our citizens on both sides of the Channel can be kept safe long into the future.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this debate. Speaking for myself, I think we can rightly be proud of what we have achieved with Schengen and with the Schengen Information System (SIS). Today’s debate and the vote tomorrow will further reinforce that information system, making Europe’s most widely used security database even more effective and, at the same time, reinforcing data protection safeguards. That is what modernising the SIS means. After the legislation enters into force and the necessary technical changes have been implemented, Member States’ authorities, together with Europol, eu—LISA and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, will be able to make better use of the system in the fight against terrorism and serious and organised crime. We will work with all Member States and all Member States’ authorities and encourage them to use that system and to use it for the purposes it is intended for, in the full respect of our fundamental rights, the fundamental rights that underpin all our work in this area, the values that we are protecting. A strengthened SIS will provide the police, the border guards, those on the front line whose job it is to keep us safe, with the information they need to do their jobs.  Thanks again to the rapporteurs and to all who have been involved on these proposals. I encourage you to support this key file when you vote tomorrow.

name: Carlos Coelho
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I thank you for the nice references of several colleagues. I believe that at the end of this debate it is clear that the vast majority of those who have spoken was to defend the importance of the Schengen Information System, to ensure schengen freedoms, to underline that we need free movement safely and to remember that citizens' rights are also strengthened by strengthening data protection, and we do this in this regulation. I am confident, as Commissioner King said, that tomorrow we will approve the reform of the Schengen Information System. I would like to stress that this is the result of the work of a team made up of members of all the institutions, who have worked very hard and very quickly for this result. I would like to thank the whole team of our Parliament, our secretariat in particular, for the immense effort and dedication they have put into this dossier. I thank the Council Secretariat, the teams of the Presidencies of Estonia and Bulgaria, with which we have worked in a loyal and dedicated manner in the search for the best result, and I want to regret the Austrian absence during this debate on the SIS. A thank you to the European Commission's negotiating team, of course To Commissioners King and Mr Avramopoulos, who have been crucial in drawing up the commitments that guarantee the success of the Schengen Information System, to my fellow rapporteurs—shadow thank you of course for the very constructive collaboration and approach throughout this process, and I end with my colleague Jeroen, my partner in this challenge , of whom we could not have had better cooperation, we were a good team, thank you all very much.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank Carlos Coelho once again. I’m not sure that the term ‘partners in crime’ is the most appropriate when it comes to the Schengen Information System (SIS), but I do very much appreciate the sympathy. I would like to thank all my colleagues who have worked so hard in a good spirit and a very constructive way. It almost makes me sad to think that, after tomorrow, this work will actually be finished. I don’t want to scare Commissioner King but, on the basis of this experience, I am already looking forward to the next SIS reform. We have worked on this legislation in a diligent and efficient way. We have a result that we can be proud of, as Commissioner King said. SIS is crucial for the security of our citizens. It already works well and it will work even better in the future thanks to this reform, not only in the area of security but also in that of migration management. These are two issues that are very important for many European citizens, and the fact that we have this result also shows that the European Union can deliver on these key issues. I think that is very important. I am very happy with the result and I hope we can get widespread support when the House votes on this tomorrow. Thank you very much to everybody concerned, especially my dear friend Carlos. We look forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: El presidente. –
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We all know the importance of the smooth functioning of the Schengen area. It is one of the symbols of a common Europe and a great success of integration – our success. We must not lose this and we must remember to continuously improve this system – while keeping us safe. I therefore congratulate Mr Coelho and Mr Leanars today on their reports, which are intended to introduce new systems and safeguards into the existing Schengen Information System. The existing SIS II regulation only allowed national law enforcement authorities to introduce warnings about refusal of entry and residence into the system. However, this was not an obligation, which was a loophole in the whole system, which the Coelho report eliminates. Attention should also be paid to ensuring that facial images or DNA profiles can be used to more easily identify missing persons, especially in cases where fingerprint data or photographs are not available or are not identigisable. This increases not only the chances of proper identification, but also our security. From my perspective, it is extremely important that the new arrangements improve Schengen and increase the security of Europeans, but do not force us to give up the values and freedoms that are at the heart of the Union, the essence of a secure Europe, a Europe without borders. This has been achieved.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The proposal for a regulation of the EP and of the Council on the establishment, operation and use of the Schengen Information System (SIS) in the field of border controls strengthens the Union's external border protection and internal security. The measures are aimed at strengthening the system so that it is able to absorb more data on persons (in particular biometrics), as well as to make the system technically and information secure. The conditions for access to the system for European agencies are specified and a consultation procedure is established which, in the light of cooperation between Member States, should prevent the same third-country national from having different residence status in the Member States of the Union. The measures should contribute to greater flexibility and efficiency of control bodies at the Union's borders and thus to greater security.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. - The growing sense of insecurity among European citizens has had an expected and justified impact on the reshooting of the Priorities of the European Union, which seeks to address the needs of Member States and their citizens. Given such changed circumstances, I support the intention to increase the security of the Union's external borders, 1351 kilometres of which are under the competence of the Republic of Croatia.  The adaptation of the Schengen Information System II with a view to a more efficient joint resolution of border control security problems should be welcomed. However, it should be noted that security needs must not serve as an excuse to violate accepted standards of protection of human rights or personal data. Improving the system should by no means lead to difficult access to the Union for those legally seeking entry and/or exit. Cooperation is the cornerstone of the European Union's performance and is essential for its security, with Schengen playing an important role.  The inclusion of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia, which of all members has the longest external land border of the European Union, in the Schengen area therefore has an important security component. Croatia has carried out 75 million controls and identified over 4,000 violations in just 4 months since joining the Schengen Information System. This demonstrates croatia's importance as a partner in securing the External Border of the European Union and justifies its accession to Schengen as soon as possible

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – We are discussing, once again, the Schengen system, of which Romania is still not unjustly a part. We meet the technical conditions for securitising our external borders, which are also the borders of the European Union. There are a small number of Member States of the Union that repeatedly oppose Romania's entry into the Schengen area. It is time for these Member States to abandon this opposition and it would be good to do so during the Romanian Presidency of the Council of the European Union. Any Member State may find that Romania exercises control of its borders under very good conditions and fully complies with its obligations with regard to the exchange of information with the other Member States in this area.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Schengen is one of the most important solutions within the European Union, as it allows EU citizens to move unfetched across Europe. However, the Schengen system must also promote the security of Europeans. Therefore, one of the most important issues is the effective return of non-EU citizens who find themselves and reside illegally in Europe. Unfortunately, this system is not fully effective. Often people who are in one EU country illegally are ordered to leave. However, as there is no smooth flow of information on these orders, such persons mostly do not leave Europe but only move to another EU country. Eurostat data confirm that only around 40% of irregular migrants have been asked to leave the EU. For this reason, I wanted to strongly support the creation of an effective EU-wide system for communicating return decisions. The point is that decisions taken in only one EU country reach and enforce all countries as soon as possible. This would undoubtedly improve the EU's internal security and improve the attitude of Europeans towards those immigrants who are legally present in the EU.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Marco Valli's second report, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge in the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, Section II – European Council and Council (COM(2017)0365 - C8-0249/2017 - 2017/2138(DEC)) (A8-0300/2018).

name: Marco Valli
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister, thank you for coming, filling the benches and listening to the indications that this Parliament will now give. For the second time this year, we are talking about the Council's discharge. The management of administrative expenditure is a fundamental issue: taxpayers' resources must be managed efficiently and the work we are called upon to do and do in this Parliament must undoubtedly go in this direction. Unfortunately, however, I have to remind you of the difficulties that have been encountered several times to date, and I therefore say that the Council's expenditure should be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. However, the Council, following the trend of previous years, has not yet given any answers to the comments we made in its resolution of 18 April. In this second report, I therefore wanted to reiterate the outstanding issues. We are waiting to receive, for example, information on the progress made since the Ombudsman's re-election on the transparency of the Council's legislative process, despite the Ombudsman himself asking for feedback on his recommendations by 9 May. I therefore call on the Council to forward its conclusions to this Parliament as soon as possible. I certainly welcome the interinstitutional negotiations currently under way to strengthen the transparency register, but these negotiations will be successful and lead to the Council's accession to the register. With regard to the part linked to buildings policy, despite the occasional exchanges of information between the building services of the two institutions, the Council still does not provide the details we have requested in this regard. I therefore call for all data and related expenditure to be fully accessible to the public, as a sign of transparency towards the citizens we all represent. I therefore repeat my call on the Council to submit progress reports on real estate projects and to present a detailed breakdown of the expenditure incurred so far. The key point therefore always remains the same: respect for Parliament's role in the discharge procedure, as governed by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Financial Regulation. This is a matter of primary importance, as is the control of the expenditure of all the institutions. I am therefore very pleased that the Council considers it necessary to deal with the discharge procedure, and the fact that it is here this evening is proof of this. As we know, informal exchanges are currently taking place between Parliament and the Council to discuss possible solutions to this current impasse. I therefore stress the importance of constructive bilateral negotiations leading to a mutually acceptable solution, while maintaining the distinction in the discharge procedure between the role of Parliament and the role of the Council. I therefore conclude by hoping that the negotiations will proceed and that an agreement will be reached as soon as possible, so that taxpayers' resources are guaranteed and accounted for in the utmost transparency.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and assure him that with regard to his words about feeling disappointed, I was told that they are all watching our debate on TV so there are more people watching than are here in the room. Let’s come to the subject of the debate. This issue has been controversial between Parliament and the Council for a long time. Let me first say something about the specific exercise of discharge for the 2016 budget and then comment on the state of play in general. In relation to the implementation of the 2016 budget, you know of course that the Court of Auditors, in its annual report, and I quote: ‘did not identify any issue concerning the Council’. This will, most probably, not affect your vote this week, which is expected to be the same as in previous years, but it is worth underlining. I would now like to share with you my assessment of where we are on this issue in more general terms. Since 2011, the Council has proposed a memorandum of understanding to Parliament in order to better organise the cooperation between our two institutions during the discharge procedure. For several years this initiative was not followed up by any concrete discussion between our two institutions. Finally, over the last 11 months, some new efforts have been made on both sides. The idea is to reach an understanding which allows a pragmatic cooperation, while preserving the position of principle of both institutions. The Council has contributed to these efforts by revising its 2011 position and sent a new proposal to Parliament in May 2018. Following further contacts and exchanges, the competent preparatory bodies of the Council are currently examining the situation. I can assure you that the Austrian Presidency of the Council is ready to do its utmost to find a solution if there is sufficient political will on both sides to bridge the gap.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Valli, for his work in preparing this report, which reproduces an old and long controversy which we have been having with the Council of Ministers of the Union. The rapporteur reminded us very well of the powers assigned by the Treaties by the European Parliament with regard to discharge, and since 2009 this Parliament has been systematically rejecting the approval of the annual accounts, which will also take place in 2016. It is not a problem of equivalence and reciprocity, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, it is a question of respect for the powers assigned by the Treaties and, in this regard, the European Parliament cannot accept equivalence or reciprocity within the respective competences. We do greet the willingness to find an understanding that is respectful of the competences of both institutions. In the meantime, the rapporteur's report points out some aspects that need to be improved. The Council did not present separate accounts of the European Council and the Council of the Union. Staff costs must be separated by categories, by sex, by function, by grade and by professional competence. And it is also clear that we must welcome the efforts that have been made in the framework of consolidating the European Union's register of transparency, which also affects the Council of Ministers of the Union. It is therefore clear, Mr President, that this situation should be overcome, but it should be overcome — as the representative of the Council has said - on the basis of a mobilisation of political will which may in some way represent respect for the rules, respect for the institutions, respect for the Treaties and the derived rules, such as the Union's Financial Regulation.

name: Arndt Kohn
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. For the eighth time in a row, the European Parliament is likely to refuse discharge to the European Council and the Council of the European Union. Why has this been the case for so many years? Why does the Council consistently refuse to answer the European Parliament's questions in the context of the discharge? Where is the Council when we discuss its responsibility towards the citizens during the debate in the Committee on Budgetary Control? I am all the more pleased that you are here tonight to send out a signal, and I think so too.  The discharge, however, is about all the EU institutions being accountable to the citizens for how they handle their taxpayers' money. Information on the Council's budget and activities can be found in the annual reports. But that is not enough. The figures must be comprehensible and comprehensible to the public. If this is not the case in the annual report, then clarity must be provided within the framework of the discharge. What, please, distinguishes the Council from the other EU institutions and their duty to be transparent in the use of funds? I warmly welcome the discussions between the Council and Parliament and hope for an early agreement, but this must take into account the principle that the European Parliament is the only directly elected chamber to have discharge sovereignty. However, I would be very pleased if, as rapporteur for the discharge of the Council for the financial year 2017, I could recommend the discharge of the Council for the first time in eight years on a new common working basis.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Well, I have a sense of such a kind of déjà vu, because in fact we talk about it every year and this is, in truth, the thing that unites all the political groups in our Parliament, because in practice we have the same problem: the lack of the necessary information from the Council, the lack of answers to written questions, in a word an illustration of the old Polish proverb: he talked grandfather to the picture, and the picture added to it once.  These answers to our unanswered questions are essential to the discharge procedure. We need answers on the main shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg regarding the high amounts transferred or the unclear construction policy. The Council has still not prepared a response to the European Ombudsman's strategic report on the transparency of the Council's legislative process, even though the Ombudsman has asked for a response to her recommendations and proposals for improvements by 9 May 2018. This is also a lack of respect for the European Ombudsman. Finally, Mr President, a large number of staff worked on the Ombudsman's report. Since this has not led the Council to respond, such pointless work is a waste of taxpayers' money.

name: Wolf Klinz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I very much regret that this year, as in previous years, we are once again having to say that we are not giving discharge to the Council. We are not doing this because we are evil to the Council, or because we are insisting here on rights that we do not have. We do so because we believe it is our duty to actually critically check for the taxpayer where his tax payments have actually remained and whether they have been spent wisely. The Council refers here to a gentlemen's agreement of 1970, in which the two institutions stipulated that they would accept each other's payments or expenditure without much critical examination.  That may have been fine 48 years ago. But today, in my opinion, it is a gross violation of the rules, and we should no longer accept it. I am glad that the President of the Council referred to the memorandum of understanding and said that she now wants to continue working on the basis and to reach an agreement with us as soon as possible. It is unacceptable for the Council to treat its expenditure as a state secret and to deny the citizen access to this expenditure and, therefore, the transparency to which it is actually obliged. As my predecessors have already said, the Council must play by the rules of the game, as must all the other institutions. We Liberals attach great importance to sound financial management, good administration and transparency. We can only assess whether these objectives will be achieved if we can ensure an appropriate assessment of the budget and its use. That is not the case. That is why we must once again refuse to grant discharge, much to our regret.  I must add that this decision was taken unanimously in the competent Committee on Budgetary Control, without a vote against and without abstention.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Thank you, Mr President. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Valli, for the work you have put into this dossier. I would also like to thank the Council for its presence. It used to be different. I would like to go straight into what the President of the Council has told us. There has indeed been a non-paper since 2011. As a Parliament, we have – we have to humbly acknowledge this – for far too long, not answered that in concrete terms. When I was the rapporteur, before Mr Valli, I took responsibility and made sure that we gave the Council a response, unanimously supported by all the members of the Committee on Budgetary Control and approved by the Conference of Presidents. In the meantime, there have been discussions between the President of the Council and the Austrian Presidency, Mrs Grässle as Chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control and myself as a former rapporteur. I think we're on a sigh of a solution. I think that the document before us is really acceptable. I must only call on colleagues in the European Parliament to take responsibility. It is the Conference of Presidents and the Secretary-General of this Parliament who must now agitate and ensure that we still reach an agreement under this Austrian Presidency, so that Mr Kohn, if he takes responsibility as rapporteur, can indeed do this discharge exercise with the Council in a fair manner.

name: Jonathan Bullock
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, so here we are once again, with the Council refusing to cooperate with the discharge procedure. This is probably one of the few issues I actually agree with the Parliament on: that there should be more transparency and oversight over the use of the EU Council budget. It of course begs the question: does the Council have something to hide? Well, let’s take a look at some of their spending. The Council spent EUR 55 000 to hold a staff party for up to 1 200 people on their premises in early 2018. The party included butlers, cooks, bartenders, champagne, wine and beer and a bar open until 3am in the morning. All very nice, no doubt. The Council also spent another EUR 25 000 for the staff and their children to have a party at an adventure park in Belgium, and in the previous year, the Council put a tender out to purchase 4 000 bottles of champagne. It’s no wonder the Council doesn’t want parliamentary oversight of their budget. The EU institutions are public entities, paid for with taxpayers’ money. It’s outrageous that, certainly, British taxpayers have to pay for such vain and frivolous events, while at home we have front-line public services cuts. Thank goodness Brexit will mean we no longer have to give vast contributions to Brussels. But because of the Tory betrayal we are having at the moment and the never-ending transitional period proposed, the UK will still be giving billions to Brussels for many years to come. But I urge all colleagues to reject granting the Council discharge. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Bullock, there is a Flemish saying that says: "The pot blames the kettle for seeing black." You are a member of Ukip. Your party, your European party, has spent an incredible amount of money with community money, in which this has actually been done fraudulently. You have even used European money with your party to fund opinion polls in the UK. How do you feel about that? Would you not also act there at your own discretion and to deal fairly with European taxpayers' money?

name: Jonathan Bullock (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the Member’s talking about polls done in constituencies in the UK. What you may not know – I don’t know how informed you are (obviously not) – is that our electoral Commission has looked into this and reported very recently – only a few weeks ago – that there was absolutely no impropriety whatsoever. That was our electoral Commission – not a body we always agree with – but  it said no impropriety whatsoever. And let’s just face it: we in UKIP have voted to get out of this organisation. We don’t want the money. We want to be out of this. We’ve made it clear and we stand by what we say.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, viewers are back in the same play. We have seen and discussed the same thing over the years, with the only exception being that we are seeing the Council here this time. That's a step, too. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Valli, on his position and say that it is all due to the Council's view that he is not supposedly obliged to come and ask the European Parliament for an exemption. We believe that the Treaty imposes this and it is our right to do so, and you as a Council must finally be transparent, open to criticism and, of course, follow the rules of the Treaty themselves.  We have many questions: what about buildings, how construction works are progressing, what about administrative costs. And you will finally have to respond to the European Ombudsman, who has made the issue of the Council's own legislative function transparent. The Council must follow this tactic, because we have a part of the Council, another body which is the Eurogroup, in which ministers are again involved, the States are involved, and it is uncontrolled and at the same time imposes policies on the Member States. So it must be time for you to be transparent about the way you operate.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, thank you very much for your remarks. I have taken good note of them. The Council is not taking it personally, but I guess it is time to change the situation. There is a saying in German that ‘wo ein Will ist, ist auch ein Weg’, or in English ‘where there’s a will, there’s a way’, but my favourite translation is the French one, ‘quand on veut, on peut’. We should bear in mind that the EU institutions can gain and keep the trust of the citizens of the Union only by working together. Let’s change the situation.

name: Marco Valli
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members and thank the Council for the goodwill of the Austrian Presidency in trying to resolve this impasse. My fellow Members have rightly – almost all of them, myself included – repeated the role of Parliament enshrined in the Treaty, and this role is also shared by an overwhelming majority by the citizens of Europe, who vote for the Members of this Parliament and also vote for them to control the money they pay for its operation. It is therefore to be hoped that a solution will be found to this, and the proposal put forward by my colleague Mr Staes is fundamental because this Parliament, like the Council, must take some steps forward in order to resolve this situation. If we manage to resolve it, then we will be able to grant discharge in the future, with the figures in hand. To date, unfortunately, since we do not have these figures in our hands, we cannot make assessments and, inevitably, for the umpteenth time, we will have to refuse discharge. We all regret this, including the citizens.

name: El presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Bart Staes' second report, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge in the implementation of the budget of the European Asylum Support Office for the financial year 2016 (COM(2017)0365 - C8-0288/2017 - 2017/2177(DEC)) (A8-0299/2018).

name: Bart Staes
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we postponed the discharge for EASO in April, and I think we did a good job of doing so. We had plenty of reasons for that, too. There were comments from the Court of Auditors, there was an initial OLAF investigation, there was whistleblower information, and the then executive director of EASO minimized all cases. The European Parliament's attitude was sensible, because the refusal to discharge led to action. During that whole time I was in close contact with the dg home managers and I also had a number of conversations with Commissioner Avramopoulos.  I dare testify here honestly that DG Home took over the case. Pressure was put on the then executive director, who resigned in June.
